PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services, Richmond and Sorell, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the standard of telephone reception in the Sorell and Richmond is sub-standard in that there are often crossed lines, subscribers have difficulty getting a line out, and lines are unclear because of static. We therefore request the Federal Government to have Telecom ensure that the service is improved to a reasonable standard.
And your petitioners as is in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
Education (Amendment) Ordinance 1988 as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 48 of 1988 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910
This Ordinance makes a number of amendments, including provisions prescribing periods of notification for commencement of schools.

The Committee's concerns related to the impossibility of meeting the specified periods of 9 months and 21 months notice required for the commencement of schools in the years 1989 and 1990 respectively, possibly due to the delay in making the Ordinance. The Committee sought advice on the inclusion in the Ordinance of relevant periods which could not be met.

The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding, M.P., acknowledged delay in the making of the Ordinance, and indicated that should any further applications be received which are adversely affected by the Ordinance, favourable consideration would be given to approving a lesser period than the prescribed period. The Committee considered this undertaking accepted and the advice provided.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in this matter.
Electricity and Water Ordinance 1988 as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 30 of 1988 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910
This Ordinance establishes the ACT Electricity and Water Authority and designates its functions.

The Committee's concerns related to laying of information before Parliament on the Authority's business activities but without formal provisions as to tabling and disallowance, and powers of entry and search given to authorised persons.

The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding MP, undertook to amend the Ordinance to provide for Parliamentary scrutiny of the Authority's business activities through disclosure in the Annual Report. The Committee accepted the Minister's undertakings.

The Committee's position regarding power of entry and search given to authorised persons reflects its fundamental concern that delegated legislation does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties (Principle (b)). Indeed, similar, but less onerous provisions in the Electricity (Amendment) Ordinance 1985 were subject to correspondence between the then Chairman and the then Minister before the provisions were finally repealed in 1987 (Electricity (Amendment) Ordinance 1987.)

In the present situation, the Electricity and Water (Amendment) Ordinance 1988, No. 57 of 1988 repealed the provision covering the powers the Committee considered onerous and a breach of individual rights and liberties. The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in these matters.
Civil Aviation (Buildings Control) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 161 and made under the Civil Aviation Act 1988
This regulation largely remakes the repealed Air Navigation (Building Control) Regulations.
The Committee's concerns related to the lack of criteria to determine compensation payable for certain losses, damage or expenses in section 14, and lack of proof of identity of authorised persons.
The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support undertook to bring forward further statutory rules to ensure proof of identity. The Committee accepted this undertaking.

The Committee was not satisfied with the Minister's original response that it was sufficient that a claimant could seek compensation through the courts. The Chairman wrote again seeking to remedy shortcomings by insertion in section 14 of criteria for compensation similar to those in section 13.
The Minister in response indicated that he would seek an amendment at an early date to include entitlements to reasonable compensation and other matters.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in this matter.
Marine Order No. 4, Part 6 (Marine Qualifications-Radio) of 1988, made pursuant to the Navigation (Orders) Regulations made under the Navigation Act 1912
This order reissues the Order relating to persons qualified to operate radio installations.
The Committee's concerns related to the definition of ``Minister'' and ``Secretary'', and a penal provision with no defence.
Marine Order No. 5, Part 9 (Health-Medical Fitness) of 1988, made pursuant to the Navigation (Orders) Regulations made under the Navigation Act 1912
This Order sets out the criteria for establishing medical fitness.
The Committee's concerns related to discretionary powers relating to the Medical Inspector of Seamen.

The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support the Hon. Bob Brown, MP, explained that the discretions were not unfettered powers, but were intended to clarify certain matters. As to general review provisions, it was intended to include a list of decisions subject to appeal in each Part of Marine Orders. The Minister explained, to the Committee's satisfaction, the matters of definition of ``Minister'' and ``Secretary'' and discretions given to the Medical Inspector of Seamen.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in this matter.

Export Control (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment), as contained in Export Control Orders No. 10 of 1988 and made under the Export Control (Orders) Regulations made under the Export Control Act 1982.
These Orders provide for fees associated with the introduction of a fee for service and for revised charges.

The Committee's concern related to whether `proportionately' referred to mathematical calculations of a proportion of the normal fee or whether it referred to a discretion being given to fix proportions.

The Minister for Resources advised that `proportionately' refers to mathematical calculations to reduce the fee by the amount that would normally be payable for the time inspection services were not available. The Committee accepts the advice of the Minister.
The Committee thanks the Minister for his co-operation in this matter.
Marine Order No. 3, Part 3 (Seagoing Qualifications) of 1988, made pursuant to the Navigation (Orders) Regulations made under the Navigation Act 1912.
This Order repeals and replaces the Orders relating to seagoing qualifications.
The Committee's concerns related to a number of discretionary decisions, general review provisions, and delegation without restriction on the level to which powers may be delegated.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The Telecommunications Amendment Bill is part of the first stage of legislative amendments to implement the Government's reform package for Telecom, as announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May 1988-``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises''.

The reforms to Government Business Enterprises are central to the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructure of the public sector. In the present difficult and fiercely competitive international trading environment public sector efficiency is especially important. Many public business enterprises-particularly those in the Transport and Communications portfolio-produce not only final goods and services for the consumer, but also provide intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures.

In 1975, the Whitlam Labor Government took the bold step of creating from the Post-Master General's Department the two major public enterprises, Telecom and Australia Post. Time has proven the correctness of that decision. Australia has a technically advanced and highly reliable telephone service. The telephone network has continued to expand and now well over ninety per cent of Australian households have a telephone service.

However, the increasing importance of telecommunications to our economy necessitates further building on the achievements to-date. Consequently, the Government has decided to continue the process of commercialisation by adopting a reform package which will put Telecom on a sounder commercial footing. Key elements in these reforms are that the Australian Telecommunications Commission will become the Australian Telecommunications Corporation, with a Board of directors, and with a new financial structure and new accountability mechanisms. A myriad of unnecessary Government controls over day-to-day management decision making will be removed.

In future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day-to-day activities of Telecom. Instead, it will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets, and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an on-going basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met.
The Government aims, through this approach, to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the Board and management.

The reform process requires extensive legislative and administrative changes. Legislation will be implemented in two stages. This Amendment Bill represents the first stage. It provides for the change of name to Corporation and the establishment of the Board, new employment provisions, and removal of day-to-day controls.

A second Bill (proposed for passage in the Autumn sittings 1989, and to operate from 1 July 1989) will remake the Telecommunications Act 1975 as the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989, redefine the objectives, functions and powers of the Corporation, and provide for the corporate planning and financial accountability measures. The second Bill will be a companion to a further Bill to provide for new regulatory arrangements for the telecommunications industry in Australia as announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May, ``Australian telecommunications services: a new framework''.

The Bill before the Senate provides for the constitution of the Board, including a Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson and Managing Director and up to six other Directors. Board members are to be appointed by the Governor-General and will be subject to dismissal for on-going under-performance (in addition to current grounds such as misbehaviour, mental illness etc.), in line with the emphasis on accountability for results.

The Managing Director will be appointed by the portfolio Minister after receiving a recommendation from the Board. Terms and conditions of employment for the Managing Director will be a matter for the Board. The Board will consult with the Remuneration Tribunal about the remuneration package for the Managing Director in line with the amendment of the Remuneration Tribunals Act introduced in the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill (Part V). The Board's most important function will be to formulate policy directions for the Corporation, in accordance with the Act and any directions from the Minister. The Managing Director will have the responsibility, under the Board, for managing the affairs of the Corporation.

The change from Commission to Corporation does not change the status of Telecom as a statutory corporation and rights under contract are not affected. The Telecom Board will be a new and separate corporate entity and the Bill takes account of the need for continuation of such matters as delegations. All the provisions dealing with the change of name and the Board will come into operation from a date to be proclaimed, likely to be 1 January 1989.

Employment provision in the current Act will be replaced by simpler provisions which make the Board responsible for determining terms and conditions of employment. Telecom is currently consulting staff associations on how existing terms and conditions will be dealt with in awards or by the Board. As this process could take some time, the new employment provisions will be subject to a special proclamation date. The Government will not proclaim these changes until it is satisfied that the interests of Telecom employees are protected and existing terms and conditions are preserved on change-over.

The Government expects Telecom to make satisfactory arrangements, including issuing Board determinations as necessary, to ensure that no current staff member loses any entitlement, classification or other term and condition of employment on transfer to the Corporation. Also, the Government has taken the additional step of including within the Bill provisions for continuity of employment for all current staff.

The Bill allows for day-to-day Government controls to be minimised in line with the enhanced responsibilities of the Board. There will be appropriate mechanisms to allow the Minister to exercise strategic oversight, through the corporate plan and financial targets. These are currently being developed and will be provided for in the second stage legislation, once necessary asset revaluations are completed to provide for the new financial structure on which targets will be based. Telecom will be free to engage, on its own authority, in such standard business practices as entering into contracts, partnerships, joint ventures, and normal business investment arrangements. In some cases, such as establishing subsidiary companies, the Board will be required to notify the Minister in writing before business activities are expanded. Subject to overall Loan Council scrutiny, Telecom will not be required to obtain Ministerial approval to the Terms and conditions of individual borrowings.

As part of the regulatory measures announced in the Government's statement ``Australian telecommunications: a new regulatory framework'' the private sector will be permitted to carry out maintenance work of PABX from 1 January 1989, in addition to the installation of PABXs currently allowed. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act currently exempts Telecom employees who would otherwise be guilty of interception because of conversations overheard during the course of their work. The Bill extends this exemption to private sector employees lawfully engaged in installation and maintenance of PABX equipment. The provision making it an offence to divulge any information obtained already applies generally to all persons exempted.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or, of itself, additional revenue for the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of Telecom that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of Telecom's services. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

GOVERNMENT BUSINESS ENTERPRISES (MISCELLANEOUS REFORMS) BILL 1988
Introduction
The Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill 1988 gives effect to the first of what will be a wide-ranging series of measures to reform Government business enterprises.
These measures reflect the Government's continuing commitment to improving the efficiency of the Federal public sector.
That commitment was enunciated in the Labor Party's 1983 policy statement, Labor and Quality of Government.

It was reflected in the Government's December 1983 Policy Paper ``Reforming the Australian Public Service'' and again in the ``Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises'' tabled by the Minister for Finance in October 1987.

The policy guidelines established processes for better defining and expressing the objectives which enterprises serve and against which their performance could be evaluated. They also acknowledged the need to reduce the extent of Government controls over their operations.
The thrust of the guidelines is to devolve responsibility-to let managers manage-with appropriate accountability for results.

The Treasurer, in the 1988 May economic statement, referred to this Government's pursuit of wide-ranging policies directed at improving the operation of domestic markets and the efficiency with which resources are used. As part of this, the Government is conducting fundamental reviews of the principal government business enterprises.

The first results of this task were seen in the statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications on 25 May 1988, ``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises''. Under the proposals spelt out in the Minister's statement, the emphasis will be placed on planning and accountability for results.

Enterprises will be expected to plan in advance their major financial and operational goals and the measures required to achieve them, including the achievement of community service obligations; to work towards pre-set financial targets; and to report on success in meeting those targets and other previously identified performance indicators.
Integral to the new arrangements is the clear delineation of responsibilities between the Government as owner/shareholder, the enterprise board and enterprise management.
The board and management will be largely free of government day-to-day controls to achieve the goals and targets set and agreed to by the Government.
The reviews of individual enterprises are continuing.
Key Elements
I turn now to the Bill itself.
Full details of the Bill are provided in the explanatory memorandum. Here I wish to refer to its most significant features.

The Bill establishes new arrangements for the appointment and remuneration of the chief executives of the Australian Shipping Commission, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Other enterprises will be covered by similar arrangements as their reform proposals are brought forward.

Each chief executive is to be appointed by the relevant portfolio Minister after receiving a recommendation from the enterprise board. Consistent with the heightened emphasis on organisational performance and accountability, and commercial practice, chief executives will not have any security of tenure.

Enterprise boards will determine the terms and conditions of appointment of chief executives. Separate administrative provision will be made requiring boards to consult the Remuneration Tribunal in the course of developing remuneration arrangements, and to advise the Tribunal of the arrangements which they make.

The Bill amends the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 to enable the Remuneration Tribunal to provide advice to the boards of enterprises. The tribunal will no longer make determinations in respect of the chief executives of the authorities covered by these arrangements.

As boards will be responsible for determining remuneration, the Bill provides that each authority will be required to incorporate, in its financial statements, a report on the remuneration of the chief executive consistent with the obligations placed on listed corporations by the Companies Act 1981.

The Government's intention is that boards should not be encumbered by Public Service terms and conditions of employment in establishing the remuneration arrangements of chief executives. To this end, the Bill provides that the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976 will not apply to the chief executives of these authorities or other enterprises to be covered by these arrangements. Other legislation relating to the terms and conditions of employment of these offices will be amended accordingly.
Boards will also be able to establish remuneration arrangements for senior executives consistent with the arrangements for chief executives.
These remuneration arrangements will also apply to the chief executives of the Reserve Bank.
There are no considerations for the Budget arising from these proposals.
Conclusion
This Bill is an important initiative in the overall process of the reform of Government business enterprises.

By enabling boards to recruit managers of high calibre and reward them appropriately, it furthers the Government's commitment to improving the efficiency of these enterprises whilst maintaining standards of public accountability.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
SUPERANNUATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Superannuation Act 1976 to provide a new supervisory mechanism for the provision of superannuation benefits to Commonwealth sector employees, in addition to that already available. These changes constitute an integral part of this Government's reforms of Government business enterprises. They will allow certain enterprises to determine their own future superannuation arrangements within guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance.

This contrasts with the current provisions of the Act. At present, in all instances, the detailed written approval of the Minister for Finance must be obtained before superannuation benefits can be provided to statutory office-holders, employees of statutory authorities and certain Commonwealth-owned companies or Commonwealth-funded bodies.

Initially the guidelines approach will apply to Qantas, Australian Airlines, the Australian National Line and Aussat. It will enable these enterprises to play a key role in the further development of this nation guided in their actions in relation to superannuation by commercial considerations. It is envisaged that in the future, enterprises such as Telecom, Australia Post, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation will also be able to make their own superannuation arrangements within appropriate guidelines.

These changes are an important component of the reform packages, announced in the May economic statement, that will make Government enterprises more accountable for their own performance. Managers of these enterprises will be forced to measure up. At the same time, this Government has not overlooked the public interest in these changes and honourable senators will note how the provisions of the Bill relating to contraventions provide a sufficient deterrent to managers who might seek to exploit unduly their new freedoms.

Further, it is intended that enterprises operating under guidelines will be required to publicly report their actions in relation to superannuation as part of their annual reports. This requirement will further enhance the public accountability of the management of Government business enterprises.

This Bill also seeks to correct a deficiency in the former provisions. The Act will now fully implement the decision of both this Government and its predecessor, that the Superannuation Act 1976 should be the exclusive source of legal authority on superannuation for Commonwealth sector employees. This approach needs to be modified when the Minister relaxes his control under the guidelines approach. The Bill allows the Industrial Relations Commission to conciliate and arbitrate on their superannuation arrangements. This is consistent with the commercial environment in which the authorities subject to the guidelines are expected to operate.
There will be no direct financial effects resulting from this Bill.

However, to the extent that these amendments facilitate improvements in the rate of return of Government business enterprises, there should be increases in revenue to the Government in the form of increased dividends from these enterprises.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT
CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

This Government came to office committed to transforming the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) into an effective instrument of industry policy after the previous Government had left the Corporation to languish.

AIDC was moved to the Industry portfolio and in late 1983 the AIDC Act was amended to expand the role of the Corporation. The amendments enabled it to provide finance for the restructuring and revitalisation of industry and for high technology and other growth industries in order to improve the international competitiveness of Australian industry.

AIDC responded well, the focus of its investment activities altered significantly, the Corporation engaged in an intense process of self-examination and it emerged revitalised and reorganised with the board and staff determined to make a significant contribution to the Government's industry policy objectives.

AIDC's ability to provide both loan and equity capital across the spectrum of new and old industries is a key characteristic which differentiates it from other financial institutions. AIDC is now making a solid contribution not only in its day to day business activities but also to the heavy engineering plan, raw materials processing under the textiles, clothing and footwear package and the anti-malaria joint venture.

As a consequence, the Corporation has experienced a period of very strong asset growth, of over 250 per cent, in the four years to 30 June 1987. However, its capital base has emerged as a factor that could jeopardise AIDC's future contribution to industry development especially in terms of its equity investment program, which is essential if it is to make its full contribution to industry policy objectives. At present AIDC has paid up capital of $100 million and $93.6 million in accumulated reserves. However, budgetary circumstances have ensured that additional capital contributions have been the exception rather than the rule. A provision introduced in 1983 requiring the Corporation to pay a dividend of 50 per cent of net profit after tax has also slowed the growth of reserves.

In line with prudent commercial practice AIDC apportions capital to the various components of its business, appropriate to the risk/return profile of each class of business. This is essential in order to maintain AIDC's credit standing. However, this places a constraint on the level of capital intensive equity investments although they are highly desirable from a policy viewpoint.
Confronted with the capital problem, the Government examined a number of options:
(a) continue as at present; or
(b) provide a substantial capital instalment from the Budget; or
(c) raise equity capital from the private sector.

In evaluating these options it was important to maintain AIDC as an effective financial instrument of industry policy. For this reason option (a) was unacceptable. It would have undermined the progress achieved by AIDC over the last five years returning it to the situation it confronted before this Government came to office. It would also have had a disastrous impact on the morale of the Corporation and its ability to retain key staff. AIDC's loan portfolio would have soon ceased to grow and the investment strategy would increasingly have been determined by the need for short term profitability. New investment in the more innovative and useful areas, particularly equity investments, would have had to be abandoned.

Given the public interest roles expected of AIDC, which remain the raison d'etre for its continued presence in the public sector, it would be preferable if the whole of the required capital could be found from the Budget-option (b). However, the budgetary realities facing the Government inevitably mean that the Government would not have been able to provide the capital required.

The third option, involving raising capital from the private sector, could have been implemented in a number of ways. Capital could have been raised in the Corporation itself either by issuing voting or non-voting shares. A listed unit trust holding non-voting shares in the Corporation could have also been established. However, these approaches would have either raised insufficient capital or would have altered the essential focus of AIDC's activities.

The Government therefore has decided to allow AIDC to establish a listed subsidiary company to conduct most of its loan and investment business with up to 30 per cent of the equity to be offered to the public. It is expected that initially up to 20 per cent of equity will be offered for some $50 million.

AIDC remains a statutory corporation 100 per cent owned by the Commonwealth. The Corporation will retain its developmental charter and continue to be subject to general policy guidance from the Government.

The subsidiary's objectives will also be directed towards and will cover AIDC's statutory charter. Directors of AIDC will compose the majority of the subsidiary's board. Under the reorganisation the bulk of the business of the Corporation will be transferred to the new wholly owned subsidiary.

Assets and liabilities associated with the national interest activities of AIDC will remain with the Corporation. It is intended that AIDC will also remain as the borrower for the group. In return for the transfer of assets and liabilities the subsidiary will issue shares to the Corporation.
The subsidiary will then, at a time determined by market conditions, issue shares to the public and be listed.

The transfer of the assets and liabilities is to be tax revenue neutral. No tax or stamp duty, State or Commonwealth, is to be paid in respect of the transfer. The subsidiary is also to be placed in the same tax position as the Corporation in respect of the transferred assets and liabilities.

It would be inappropriate for any taxes or charges to be levied in respect of the transfer, given that the activities of the subsidiary will be those previously carried out by AIDC. In any event the cost in terms of taxes and charges normally associated with such a transfer would have been so large as to defeat the whole purpose of the reorganisation.
Throughout the reorganisation and the raising of share capital from the public appropriate ministerial control will be maintained. I will:
against criteria set out in the Bill, nominate the subsidiary to which the Corporation will transfer its business;
specify the assets, instruments and liabilities not being transferred, all other assets, instruments and liabilities being transferred to the subsidiary;
fix the day the reorganisation takes place;
determine the net value of the transferred business;
determine the total nominal value of shares issued to the Corporation; and
have the power to issue directions in relation to the first share issue to the public; the market will determine the price of the shares for any subsequent issues.
The rights of those staff members transferring from AIDC to the subsidiary have been fully protected under this Bill.

The establishment of the listed subsidiary should not be construed as a partial privatisation of AIDC, but rather it is an opportunity for the public to share in the national development objectives of AIDC. No Commonwealth assets will be sold off and the Corporation will remain 100 per cent owned by the Commonwealth.

No single private person or associated group will be permitted to hold more than 10 per cent of the subsidiary's voting equity. This condition and others will ensure the continuing effectiveness of AIDC and the subsidiary in meeting industry policy objectives. These objectives will remain unchanged as will the strict commercial approach to its business that has been a hallmark of the Corporation over past years.

In contrast to privatisation measures in Britain, the additional capital raised from the public by the subsidiary will remain with, and contribute directly to, the growth and financial performance of the AIDC Group and not flow to consolidated revenue.
To further assist AIDC the Government has also decided to forgo the 1987/88 dividend which would normally be due to be paid by 31 December 1988.
The Bill also amends the mechanism by which future dividend payments to the Commonwealth will be determined, bringing AIDC into line with other Government business enterprises.

Instead of paying 50 per cent of net profit after tax each year, AIDC will recommend a dividend to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who may approve the recommendation or direct the Corporation to pay a higher or lower dividend.
Similarly, the remuneration of AIDC's chief executive will be determined by the board in consultation with the Remuneration Tribunal.
I will also now appoint the chief executive of the Corporation on the recommendation of the board.

The Bill increases the capital payable to the Corporation from $150 million to $200 million, of which $100 million has been paid up. The forgone 1987/88 dividend will be counted towards the paid in capital of the Corporation.
The unpaid capital will be available, subject to appropriation, to enable the Corporation to discharge its obligations.
However, it is intended to be available only if the Corporation has exhausted all other options in discharging its obligations.
The Bill also contains other consequential and minor amendments that will assist both AIDC and the subsidiary in performing their functions.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill I am introducing today is to amend the Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act 1974 to: implement the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration; and include minor additional provisions to facilitate arbitral proceedings.
Background

The model law provides a legal framework for the conduct of international arbitrations. It was adopted by the UNCITRAL in 1985 as part of its work in promoting the unification of international trade law. In 1986 the Government established a working group to examine the model law. The working group comprised representatives of the State and Northern Territory Attorneys-General, the Law Council of Australia, the Attorney-General's Department and the Institute of Arbitrators Australia. (Quorum formed).

Mr President, I commend the keeping of a quorum during the second reading because I do not feel up to reading it in the absence of a quorum. The working group recommended adoption of the model law, together with related minor additional amendments to the Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act 1974. The working group's recommendations were considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in 1987.

This Bill, which implements the model law, will not replace the present domestic law on arbitration. It will supplement the existing system by enabling international arbitrations to be conducted in accordance with the model law. The Bill will also allow the States and the Northern Territory to enact identical legislation should they so wish. To date, the model law has been adopted by Canada, Cyprus and California and is under active consideration by the United Kingdom, Hong Kong and New Zealand.
Content of the Bill

I refer now to some of the more salient features of the Bill. Once again, I remind the Senate that when I say `I' it is actually Senator Bolkus, who, were he able to read, would be reading this speech.

The Bill will implement the model law by amending the Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act 1974. The Act currently gives effect to the 1958 Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards-the New York Convention-which establishes rules governing the recognition and enforcement, in Australia, of international arbitral awards and agreements. Implementing the model law by amendment to this Act will ensure that all relevant Commonwealth laws relating to international arbitration are comprised in the one instrument. In the event of any conflict being found to exist between the provisions of the model law and the New York Convention, the latter will take precedence.
The Model Law

The model law provides an internationally agreed legal framework for the conduct of international arbitrations. It regulates the arbitration agreement, the composition of arbitral tribunals, the conduct of arbitral proceedings, the recognition and enforcement of awards, and recourse against arbitral awards. International recognition of the model law means that its adoption should assist Australia's efforts to establish itself as a centre for international commercial arbitration. In this regard I note that both Melbourne and Sydney have facilities for conducting international arbitrations with the establishment of the Australian Centre for International Commercial Arbitration in Melbourne and the Australian Commercial Disputes Centre in Sydney. The model law also complements the UNCITRAL Arbitration Rules, which are increasingly being used in the conduct of international ad hoc arbitrations. In a more general context, party autonomy is respected and facilitated by the model law. Parties will no longer be frustrated by unknown provisions of national laws which may conflict with their intentions in respect of their arbitration. While the law in Australia at present is relatively modern it may be unfamiliar to some foreign parties and may be perceived to be undesirable by them. Another aspect of the model law worthy of mention is the delimitation of court assistance and supervision. While the model law recognises the supportive and corrective role to be played by the courts, it will limit judicial intervention and supervision of an arbitration to a greater degree than under present Australian law.

I will now mention-I again remind the Senate that the `I' in this case is not me; it is in fact the Minister for Consumer Affairs, who apparently is not able to read-some of the supplementary matters provided for by the Bill. The first of these is the manner in which the model law is to be implemented. The Bill will implement the model law on an `opt-out' basis. This means it will apply to all international arbitrations unless parties agree, in writing, to exclude its operation. The facilitative provisions of the Bill will however apply on an `opt in' basis. In this regard the Bill will clarify and increase the powers of arbitral tribunals in respect of matters such as the payment of interest on awards, costs and the consolidation of arbitral proceedings. In relation to consolidation, arbitral tribunals will be able, at the request of a party, to consolidate proceedings where, for example, they deal with a common question of fact or law or where the relief claimed arises out of the same transaction. The Bill will thus enable parties to an international arbitration to choose the model law to govern their arbitration, with no additions or amendments, or the model law with all or any of the additional provisions.
Financial and Regulatory Impact Statement

The International Arbitration Amendment Bill will have no direct impact on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure. A favourable indirect impact on Commonwealth tax revenue may be expected as the provisions may increase the attractiveness of Australia as a centre for international arbitration, though the extent of this is difficult to quantify.

I commend the Bill to the Senate. Again, for the purpose of avoiding any misunderstanding, I explain to the Senate that the `I' referred to there is Senator Bolkus, who would, had he been able to read this speech, have been commending the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Bolkus) adjourned.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill provides for a number of measures aimed at fine-tuning the operations of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC). Before proceeding to outline the specific measures contained in the Bill, I wish to place in context the origins and role of the Commission. When this Government came to office activity at the Federal level in the area of occupational health and safety was virtually nil. This was despite the fact that Australia had an unacceptably high incidence of work-related death and injury which would not be tolerated in other Westernised nations. To give honourable senators an idea of the magnitude of the problem, each year in Australia 550 men and women die as a result of work related accident or disease. In a work force of seven million this incidence rate of 77 per million can be compared with figures produced in the 1984 International Labour Organisation Year Book of Labour Statistics which showed an annual fatality rate per million workers of 22 in Sweden, 24 in the United Kingdom, 20 in Japan and 37 in the United States of America. Conservative estimates show that more than $6 billion a year is wasted in Australia through loss of production and associated costs because of occupational injury and ill-health. The human costs, of course, cannot be quantified.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government came to office with a firm commitment, written into the Australian Labor Party platform and reaffirmed in our accord with the trade union movement, to redress this situation. While occupational health and safety regulation was, and still remains, the responsibility of the States, we recognised the need for coordination of effort through an agreed national strategy. In 1984 we set up an interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to advise on the appropriate framework for such a strategy. The interim Commission recommended the establishment of a statutory Commission constituted along tripartite lines. The Government accepted this advice and NOHSC was set up in 1985 following the passage of enabling legislation through Parliament.

The primary role of the Commission, which has adopted as its working title Worksafe Australia, is to provide a national forum for the development of national standards and strategies in cooperation with the States. The tripartite structure of the 17-member Commission, which includes representatives of the States, of industry and of the trade union movement, provides a consultative framework for development of uniform standards and avoidance of duplication of effort. Through its research arm, the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety, the Commission aims to provide research, testing, statistical collection and analysis and training of occupational health and safety professionals. Although NOHSC has existed as a statutory body for less than three years, it has made significant progress towards the development of a national strategy.

The Commission's achievements include development of a uniform national data set of comparable statistics on the incidence and nature of occupational health and safety problems. This has been a massive task involving all State and Territory Governments in the collection of uniform data, with minimum disruption to existing systems and without adding to the reporting burden on employers. The Commission is also in the process of developing national standards and codes of practice, which detail preventive action required to avert deaths, injuries and diseases on a range of issues. It has already declared codes of practice for occupational overuse syndrome-previously known as repetitive strain injury-and for asbestos. At its September meeting the Commission is expected to declare a code of practice on timber preservatives. Also, work is continuing on agreed standards, codes and guidance notes for safe manual handling, lead, noise and mechanical equipment safety. I emphasise that these standards and codes are advisory in nature-a point which has been misconstrued in some quarters.

The structure of NOHSC reflects the Government's belief that improvements in occupational health and safety standards in Australia can be best progressed by cooperation, not coercion. By providing a national forum for the development of cooperative arrangements between the States, the Government aimed at laying the groundwork for the progressive shedding by the States of their complex, and often conflicting, web of regulations. By issuing advisory codes the Commission aims to reduce rather than increase the degree of regulation concerning occupational health and safety in this country.

The Bill proposes a number of amendments and consequent changes to the composition of the Commission and its executive to incorporate the Chief Executive Officer as a member. It also makes provision for the duties of director of the Institute to be performed by the Chief Executive Officer, or for the positions to be separately filled. This will allow maximum flexibility in appointing available and suitably qualified personnel in a field where expertise is scarce and where we must compete for such expertise in an international market. These amendments to the Act will facilitate and consolidate the significant improvements in the national Commission's operation and reflects in a practical way the Government's continuing commitment to improving the safety and quality of working life in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate relates to the package of Bills by which the Government proposes to create an Australian Capital Territory (ACT) government for the first time. The Bills are the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill 1988, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988 and the A.C.T. Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988. In addition, cognately we are debating three Bills that have been introduced by the Australian Democrats. The Liberal Party will not be supporting the Democrats' Bills, and I shall refer briefly to our reasons for that. In some respects we have considerable sympathy with what the Democrats' Bills seek to do. In part, they seek to set up freedom of information, administrative review and an ombudsman.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironic, really, that the Democrats should be attempting to do all these things at this stage of the development of a package of government for the ACT. In a sense, they are persisting in attempting to do exactly what many people in the ACT are complaining about, that is, to impose Federal Government views on the people of Canberra. I do not have the slightest doubt that these matters will be brought into existence, but that will be done by the ACT Government which we are establishing, and that is the right and proper way for them to come about. I think we should ensure that our intervention in this is the minimum required.

Another matter that the Democrats have raised relates to the protection of the national interest. It is our view that the national interest is protected by the legislation that has been brought in, and planning power is retained by the Commonwealth for those matters to which that ought to apply. Planning in other respects will go to the ACT Government, although I am critical of some aspects of the way that this matter has been handled, and I will refer further to this later in my remarks.

In relation to this matter, many representations have come from the community, and they have been referred to. In fact, most of the matters to which I wanted to draw the attention of the Senate have already been raised here. Therefore, I will restrict my remarks, as against what I might have said had I been the first or only speaker on the topic. I will deal with some specific matters rather than canvass the whole story, because there is certainly a great deal for the Senate to do on this matter, and others, before any of us will have the opportunity to spend Christmas this year with our families and not our parliamentary colleagues.

The Democrats also have before the Senate a constitutional Bill. I think this matter also may well develop as time passes, and I think the ACT Government may well ask for such a measure to be brought about. However, I again put this in the category of imposing more upon the people of Canberra than is necessary at this stage. This again comes into the category of doing the very things that we are saying ought not to be done and ought not to be dealt with by the Federal Government.

This most recent proposal to grant self-government has been under discussion only since 19 October, when the legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives. It was then brought to this chamber on 7 November. However, to merely look at those historical dates does not really give an indication of the history of this matter and what in fact has gone on. I intended to refer at some length to comments made recently about our delaying the legislation but, in view of Senator McMullan's comments yesterday, I do not feel that it is necessary to say more than that we have kept to the Government's timetable. No delay has been caused by the Opposition which would impede this matter proceeding to an election in March of next year, or whenever the Government wishes to hold it. As I said, I think most people have been fairly conscientious and diligent about looking at the legislation and giving thorough consideration to the amendments which are brought forward. As Senator Jenkins has said, and is quoted on the front page of today's Canberra Times as saying, the Australian Democrats have `buckets' of amendments. To have not looked at them in great detail and with thoroughness would not have been giving the matter the attention that it deserves.

I am pleased to support this legislation, which will finally bring to the people of the ACT a real say in the development of this Territory, a real say in the decisions which affect their lives, through elected representatives who will be responsible for the decisions that are made in this Territory and who will be answerable at the ballot box for the decisions that are made covering all matters: housing, health, education, industry and development, welfare and so on-matters which in other places are dealt with by State and local governments, but in which we have not had a say in the past and on which we have not had people making the decisions who were answerable to this electorate. It is somewhat ironic in a sense that right at the heart of the national capital that has been the case for so long.

It would be wrong to leave the impression, though, that everybody in the ACT is unanimous in their support for what is happening. Some years ago it was very clearly the case that most Canberrans were against any form of local government. Not only a Canberra Times survey just last weekend, but also correspondence I have been receiving from constituents in recent years indicates that people have come to an awareness of the need to have a responsible government here dealing with these issues. Frequently in letters people write about one thing or another but they indicate in their comments that it is wrong that we do not have a say. What that really means is that they want a system of government whereby they will be able to have a say, and that has been a significant change. I think just about every commercial organisation and other organisations in Canberra have written and expressed views or presented submissions in one way or another over the last few years indicating their support for a form of self-government for the ACT.

As I said, the debate is not new. It has been going on for a long time. The first attempt to form an administration was in 1928, when three members of the Federal Capital Development Commission were elected on a property franchise. That Commission, of course, had no administrative or executive powers and existed for only a couple of years. In 1930 an advisory council of four appointed and three elected members was established. That lasted until 1974, with variations in the numbers of those who were elected and appointed. But throughout the years there has been debate on the question of what has loosely been referred to as `self-government' for the ACT. The debate has been within the community and within the Federal Parliament and the governments that have had the responsibility for running the Territory.

In 1934 the Scullin Government expressed the view that `within a few years'-it cannot have imagined how long it would be, I am sure-`we shall be able to give full civic control of the city to the people themselves'. The Chifley Government in 1949 requested the Hobart Town Clerk to examine possible models of self-government which might be appropriate to Canberra. In 1955 a Senate Select Committee on the Development of Canberra recommended a legislative council with State-type functions but no administrative powers, with a multiplicity of local government arrangements as well. Nineteen fifty-seven saw the recommendation by the Institute of Public Administration of a national capital council as a form of statutory authority, and the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) was established at about that time.

All the while the advisory council that had been established was pressing for devolution of real power to a local self-governing body. Mr Anthony, as Minister for the Interior in 1967, proposed that Commonwealth control of Canberra, with a handover of State-type functions and new municipal governments, be formed in Woden and Belconnen. His successor, Mr Hunt, in 1971 suggested that 1980 would be an appropriate target date for the achievement of self-government. Perhaps he was as near to predicting the date as one could get. The Australian Labor Party had a hand in the self-government proposal in the period 1972-1975. The Whitlam Government asserted that self-government would be achieved as soon as practicable after the presentation of the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. That Committee, which was set up in, I think, 1972, in fact had not reported by the time there was a change of government.

The Liberal Party has always recognised the role of self-government and the right of people to have a say in their government. I will not read the extracts from Liberal Party policy that I took out because I do not believe it is necessary to do so at this time. In 1976 a task force was established which later reported on a program of transfer of functions and the necessary legislative and administrative arrangements needed for self-government. A gradual devolution of powers was proposed. However, that was rejected in a referendum in 1978, for reasons which I think are fairly well known to everybody at this time. Three questions were put to the people in that referendum, and there was criticism of them, so the advisory body continued.

The Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, which was a purely advisory body, continued to function until it was abolished by the present Government in 1986. Although it was strictly speaking a purely advisory body, I think it would be wrong at this stage not at least to acknowledge the significant electorate and constituent work done by members of the House of Assembly. Perhaps the honourable member for Fraser, John Langmore, and I know better than anyone else exactly how much work was done in the community by the members of the House of Assembly. We have been able to judge that by the vast increase in our work since the Assembly was abolished in 1986. Perhaps the Assembly ought not to have been abolished then but should have stayed in existence until another form of government was established. Perhaps, though, the Assembly's abolition at that time helped to heighten the awareness of those involved in the community of the need for self-government. I guess it is not possible to make a conclusion as to exactly what should have happened at that time.

The principal reason for the time taken in the resolution of this matter and for the failure to establish self-government in 1986 has been the difficulty in finding an acceptable electoral system. There has, of course, always been debate about the extent of powers and the way in which powers should be transferred, and that is understandable. However, it is the electoral system which has been at the centre of debate in recent times. The Bills we are now debating propose to grant to the Australian Capital Territory responsibility for virtually all of those areas which would in other jurisdictions fall to the States or local government, except initially in regard to the police, courts and legal administration, about which we are moving amendments.

I believe that the debate on the electoral system has been important and necessary. While many other aspects of self-government which we are seeking to establish can perhaps be changed more easily, it is less likely that the electoral system will be able to be changed in the future. Therefore, it is important to get it as correct as any electoral system can be. There is no doubt that there is not a perfect electoral system. I had prepared notes on the various systems which had been proposed and was going to talk about each of those in detail. However, I do not think that is now necessary. We have had proposals for a one-electorate system, a two-electorate system, single member electorates, tiered systems with some members elected at large and some in single member electorates, and combinations of just about anything else one can think of.

The proposal the Government came up with this year was the d'Hondt system, a system that is widely used in Europe. In our opinion that system was not suitable to this electorate. I do not believe that the system we have now decided on is, in fact, the d'Hondt system but a significantly varied one which I think really should not have that name; it is an Australian Capital Territory electoral system suitable, in my opinion, to a city State. It does not have within it every aspect of an electoral system that I would regard as essential but, again, as I said, there is no such thing as a perfect electoral system.

The only other thing I want to say in regard to the electoral system is that there is no doubt in anyone's mind that the negotiations have been genuine and sincere. The Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties have paid great attention to working out a system suitable to the type of community that Canberra is-a community loosely described by me and others as a city State. The other thing to take into account in determining the type of electoral system the Australian Capital Territory will have is that it will have a one-chamber legislature: there will not be a House of review. So some of the aspects of an electoral system with a House of review needed to be included in the unicameral system.

Earlier I referred to the National Capital Development Commission and planning. I have been unhappy with the way in which the Government has handled the abolition of the Commission. I recognise that the planning arrangements have to change once self-government comes into effect. However, my particular concerns about the way it has been handled relate to the staff of the Commission. The Commission has served Canberra well for the 30 years that it has been in existence and I believe that the success of this city and the way it is planned flow from the diligence with which it has proceeded with the work it has been given. I recognise that not everybody in Canberra agreed with all its decisions. There was no possibility of that ever being the case. Planning for the national areas will remain with an authority answerable to this Parliament and planning for Canberra will be with the ACT Government. As I have said, it is the way the staff have been treated that has upset me most of all. I have had a number of letters and representations. I quote briefly from one letter which referred to how staff were dealt with and to retrenchment:
The basis of selection of such staff-
that is, those who would be retrenched and those who would remain-
has not been adequately explained, but it is certainly the case that no opportunity to nominate for such an offer-
that is, retrenchment-
was ever given to staff in general.
The letter continued:

I seek your help in obtaining objective, equitable consideration to extending additional offers to the small number of staff who would prefer to have this option made available to them. A forced transfer to ACT Administration because a current function continues there, or resignation if dissatisfied is no choice at all.

I hope that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is here, will take notice of this plea from some members of the staff of the NCDC and ask that the matter be looked at again with a view to dealing more equitably with the people whose jobs are being disrupted as a result of the changes taking place.

For a long time the people of Canberra have been apprehensive, quite understandably, as to the financial arrangements which would exist. The cry that self-government would cost more is something that many of us have heard over many years. I think that that was principally because people in Canberra did not have much idea what it really cost to run the place and where the money came from. People in the rest of Australia thought that we were heavily subsidised. The accounting arrangements have been so structured that it will now be possible to know what is raised here and what is spent here. The books have been put in order in that respect, with the assistance of the Commonwealth Grants Commission in recent reports on the Australian Capital Territory. Adjustments may have to be made, but it will be the responsibility of the ACT Government to determine what moneys will be raised and how they will be spent. Those people who do the raising and spending will find themselves answerable at the ballot box on the next occasion that people have the opportunity to express a view.

Clearly, we can now see the financial arrangement that will exist in the Territory, which arrangement is significantly different. The Commonwealth has made some commitment for the next few years and there will be a government to negotiate as to what is fair and reasonable for the Territory for the future. It will now be up to the ACT Government to make representations to the Grants Commission. It will not be a bureaucratic function, which it has obviously had to be in the past. There are transitional arrangements which will have to come into effect. There has been talk of some Federal assistance with the establishment of the Assembly and its support services. The ACT should be treated similarly to the Northern Territory in that regard. The Northern Territory had an existing body when self-government was transferred to it.

A number of issues in Canberra in recent times have highlighted for many people the reason why they want accountable members in this electorate. The closure of schools, the provision of health services and the debate over the development of section 19 in Civic suffice to indicate some of the things that have caused people to come to a view that it is necessary to have more say.

Another factor has been the Government's precipitate and quite wrong abolition of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the ACT after the last election. I have spoken about that in this place on several occasions previously and I shall not go into the history of it again. But there is no doubt that that was a decision that ought not to have been made. The system for the variation of the city plan of Canberra which was put in its place has not been satisfactory in my opinion. That is no criticism of the staff who service that committee or the members who are on it. I think it has not been possible for it to function in the way that the Joint Committee on the ACT functioned from the time of its inception to the time of its demise at the election in 1987 when the Government failed to reinstate it. I think there still needs to be some arrangement whereby there can be structured communication between the ACT Government and the Federal Government on matters of interest between the two groups for the development of the capital because the national capital areas are still of great interest to those of us who live here.

I wish the ACT Government success, as others have done. I shall certainly be taking a great interest in it. I am pleased to support the Bills that are before the Parliament and hope that we can get the matter concluded as expeditiously as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
