TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is obviously an important occasion in the history of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I am glad that we have finally got to this point. It seems that this debate and the lead-up to it have been going on forever. But one would have to say that in the course of the last few weeks goodwill has been shown by the Opposition. I thank Senator Hill for his acknowledgment of the contribution of the various people and organisations who have been involved in the process. I also put on record my gratitude to Senator Hill for his constructive approach to the resolution of many of the issues raised in the development of this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins expressed some concern as to how this legislation was developed. She said that there was little, if any, local input. If one reads between the lines of what Senator Jenkins had to say I guess that there is an inference that it is all some sort of bureaucratic plot. The Government has been concerned at all times to have openness in the development of these proposals. We distributed a comprehensive discussion paper which was widely circulated in the ACT. It must have been widely circulated in the ACT because it generated a great deal of public comment. Those comments from individuals and groups were important in the development of the final package. I would also like to take the opportunity to remind Senator Jenkins that the Government has been striving for a long time to ensure some sort of tripartite support for these proposals. We have exposed our thinking on all the issues and all the ideas at every stage of the process in an attempt to collectively develop a package which could bring democracy to Canberra. In doing so, I think everyone would concede that the Government has made concession after concession in an attempt to make sure that we got a consensus. The Opposition has contributed, I believe, in a positive and cooperative way. The Australian Democrats are still talking of the need for more concessions, particularly in electoral matters. I find it a bit difficult to understand how we can give more. I hope that Senator Jenkins can carefully consider her position on that.

There is no doubt that the time is right now for the ACT to accept the responsibility of self-government. The cost to the Commonwealth of achieving democracy for 270,000 citizens in Canberra is minimal; it entails a short term guarantee only-preserving the existing financial arrangements for two years; not an increase in financial support, just a preservation. The only other cost would be an establishment grant which, of course, occurred in the case of the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island and, indeed, Papua New Guinea when it was on the road to self-government. The time is also right from the point of view of directing Canberra's future. The development of the national capital, in the Commonwealth's view, is virtually finished. The public sector can no longer be the only means of maintaining any impetus for development in the ACT. Its future must come from the private sector, from ordinary citizens. If that is to happen, then obviously self-government is the only way which will ensure that the citizens of Canberra have a say in managing that fundamental change. All the necessary reforms to prepare for self-government are already in place. The administrative matters, apart from some law and order functions, are handled in one organisation.

Senator Hill did say during the debate that he considers 17,000 for the public service in the ACT to be a very high figure. He has said that there must be more accountability. The Government would agree that the community should have more control over its own government; that is obviously the essence of the whole proposal. The fact is, however, that the ACT's public service, by comparison with other States and Territories, is far from fat. On a per capita basis, the ACT has fewer public servants engaged upon State and municipal matters than any State or the Northern Territory.

The financial arrangements will treat the ACT on the same basis as the States-they will recognise the special circumstances arising from Canberra's role as the national capital. Importantly, as Senator Hill pointed out, the ACT's own government, rather than the Federal Government, will represent the ACT community in negotiations for Commonwealth-State financial arrangements. Under the new financial arrangements here, the ACT will pay for its own planning and development. Members of the community must have a say in how their money is spent. This concern is addressed in new planning and development arrangements detailed in the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill. The Territory will be responsible for normal metropolitan planning, development and land management matters. The Commonwealth's interest as the custodian of the national capital for all Australians will be protected through the development of a national capital plan. The ACT will not be able to do anything that is inconsistent with that plan. In addition, the Commonwealth will continue to own the land, while the ACT will manage it on the Commonwealth's behalf using the existing leasehold system.

This new process means that there will be a clear and unambiguous division between national and local responsibilities. Each level of government will be fully accountable for its defined responsibilities. As Senator Hill pointed out earlier, debate on the proposed electoral system has been exhaustive. I think I am one who could bear witness to the exhaustion of the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exhaustive or exhausted?

—It has exhausted many people. The d'Hondt system is the end product of those exhaustive negotiations. The first point I would like to make about the d'Hondt system is to acknowledge that it is a compromise. It was not the Government's first choice; it was not even the Government's second choice. The Government believed that the best system was one which is used to elect people's Houses throughout the Commonwealth and that is, of course, the single member constituency system. The Opposition and the Democrats would not support that proposition. The Government believed that the next best system was an amalgam of the single member constituency system and the Senate system whereby half of the members would be elected under the single member constituency system and half would be elected under the Senate system. This proposal was also rejected. Hence, in searching for common ground, the d'Hondt system was selected.

SPEECH.PARA: While acknowledging that this system was not either the first or second choice of the Government, it is a sound electoral system which is used in countries throughout the world. It is a people's House system and its reputation in Western democracies is high. The positive process of negotiation between the Government and the Opposition on this question means that the system as now proposed-once again I thank Senator Hill in acknowledging his contribution in suggesting modifications to the original proposal-is appropriate to the unique needs of the city State of the Australian Capital Territory.

Senator Jenkins raised with me this morning a number of questions in regard to the system. I can best summarise the position by saying that she has given me a number of scenarios which would circumvent, if you like, the d'Hondt system and render it difficult for Canberra democracy. Over the last half an hour I have had departmental officers looking at the points she raised. I am not in a position to give an exhaustive and exact answer to each of her questions. All I can say in light of the very brief time that I have had to look at them is that the possibility of the scenarios raised ever occurring is so remote as to enable us to disregard them out of hand. I would think that the prospect of 20 parties all gaining around 5 per cent of the vote would rate in the area of a million to one and perhaps a billion to one. I have not calculated the odds, but I do not think I will bother. Having sat down in my office for a few minutes to look at what Senator Jenkins put to me, I do not think we ought to modify the system to account for that possibility.

I cannot claim to have been a student of every election in the Commonwealth of Australia in the last 100 years, but I have taken a pretty keen interest in elections over the years. I cannot recall any election, even at local government level, where such a result even came close. Obviously, one would expect occasionally to see such a result in local government elections, but it just never occurs. So I am not going to get overly worried about the fact that the legislation does not take into account that possibility.

I conclude by saying that the type of government proposed for the ACT is a careful balance between giving the ACT appropriate legislative and executive control over its own affairs, adjusting to make sure that the ACT is treated equitably in money terms compared with the rest of Australia, unequivocally preserving the Commonwealth's interest in the national capital and, at the same time, ensuring a genuine political separation that insulates Commonwealth politics from those at a territorial level. I am confident that further discussion at the committee stage on particular issues, as foreshadowed by both Senator Hill and Senator Jenkins, will be positive. With continued goodwill and unanimity of purpose on all sides, the people of the ACT will at last be able to decide their own affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reply briefly to remarks that have been made on the three Bills put forward by the Australian Democrats. Needless to say, we are very disappointed that neither the Government nor the Opposition appears to be willing to support any of these Bills. It has been said by speakers for the Government and the Opposition that they have some sympathy with the Bills, that they are principled and that the principles are correct, but there is no need for them or there is no need for them at this time. We in the Australian Democrats dispute that point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill to provide open government, probity and citizens' rights is based on the proposition that open government, probity and citizens' rights in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) are of fundamental concern to residents of the Territory and are matters that should be assured to those residents during the present time of constitutional development of the Territory and that it is fully appropriate for such assurances to be given by the Federal Parliament at this time. The Bill brings together in a convenient and readily acceptable form the key elements of concern to citizens generally. As far as open government is concerned, we in this Federal Parliament can assure the people of the ACT that they can have freedom of information, the review of administrative decisions and access to an ombudsman. We can also ensure that they can have such standard practices as open meetings and publication of minutes of meetings, and so on.

As far as probity in government is concerned, our proposal recognises the advantage to the legislature, to the Assembly itself, of being able to readily call upon a body with appropriate expertise, so that the ACT Assembly would have that right given to it by the Federal Parliament. Conflicts of interest are dealt with in this Bill. Also we see civil rights as including protection against the acquisition of property on other than just terms and as being something that this Federal Parliament should ensure that the people of the ACT have.

As for the second Bill, relating to the protection of the national interest, we agree, and it appears that Senator Reid agrees with us, that the people of the ACT should have the maximum degree of autonomy consistent with the national interest. We feel that the Federal Parliament itself may need, through a short-life ordinance, to ask the ACT Assembly to pause in its review of a certain situation, but this should be done openly by the Federal Parliament-by the legislature itself-and not by any executive arm of government. We believe that we should be able to pass on that right to the people of the ACT through their Assembly.

The final Bill, relating to the establishment and amendment of the new Constitution, is based on the proposition that the citizens of the ACT should have a mechanism available to them by which the ACT Constitution can be repatriated, after which it would be amended by local decision. So we are not taking that right away from the people. We are guaranteeing them the right to have their own Constitution.

As I said before, it is disappointing to the Australian Democrats that it appears that these Bills will not have the support of either the Government or the Opposition. I presume we will be shortly moving the second reading amendment, the Robson amendment, and I would hope again that the Government and the Opposition would look very carefully at this one. It is a system which works very well in Tasmania. It is essentially fair. If we had had it for the Senate the Robert Wood syndrome, which seems to be a syndrome that worries the Government and the Opposition a great deal, would have been dealt with. Robert Wood would not have been elected had this system been working, which involves the rotation of candidates in such a way that people are voted for, certainly not Party lists.

Senator Richardson referred briefly to a matter that I flagged to him earlier this morning. I ask that he seriously consider the four points I raised there. He referred briefly to one of them. I think those are matters that we should consider very carefully and I hope that will be done in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Government amendment (15). It contains important subject matter. Part of the self-government debate has revolved around the appropriate functions to be transferred from the Commonwealth to the new self-governing Assembly. No doubt the Committee will be aware that in the Government's original Bill there were a number of controversial areas which were not to be transferred. I refer, for example, to clause 22 (1) (b) where the establishment of courts was not to be transferred; in respect of paragraph (c) the provision by the Australian Federal Police of police services in relation to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) was not to be transferred; and in regard to paragraph (f) the admission of persons to practise as legal practitioners for regulating the practice of persons so admitted was not to be transferred.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of negotiations the Government has put this amendment before the Committee which will have the effect of transferring paragraphs (1) (c) and (1) (f). In other words, the Government has been prepared to effect a transfer before 1 July 1990 of police functions and of matters relating to legal practitioners and regulating their practice. We support that. In relation to the Australian Federal Police, in case there is any confusion, in advocating that we are not suggesting that the Assembly should rush out and set up its own police force. In fact, if it sought to do so this Parliament might take some action. What is being proposed and what is dealt with to some extent in consequential amendments is an agency agreement between the Territory and the Australian Federal Police to provide services for the Territory. That seems to us to be a sensible solution. No doubt it will require some negotiation, but not only does it seem sensible to us in the form of police matters, but we suspect that it is also sensible in terms of cost efficiency. Therefore, on that basis we have argued for, and now obviously support, the Government's intention to move across both those functions.

That leaves one controversial area which the Government by its amendment is not seeking to transfer, and that is the establishment of courts. We have had discussions with the Australian Democrats on this matter. We find it difficult to come across a valid argument that would prohibit transfer of the courts as at a specified date in the future. We are not arguing-at least, we have not argued for some time-that they should be transferred immediately, as we concede that there might be difficulties in relation to tenure of the judges and other administrative matters. As I said during the second reading debate, we have attempted to take a cautious approach to the whole process of self-government. Therefore, although we may have suggested it earlier, in recent times we have not insisted that the courts be transferred as at this time.

Having had the opportunity to peruse at least one memorandum of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, and recognising also that the Law Society has now said to us that it does not want to see a specified date for the transfer of the courts, in my opinion a valid argument has still not been put before me as to why the function of the courts should not be transferred at some future specified date. It does seem strange to have a situation where, basically, all functions relating to self-government except the courts are transferred. I hope that the Government will try to give a reason for excluding the courts from this provision. I invite the Government to explain to the Committee why it is not prepared to go the way that we have been advocating and why it specifically wishes that the establishment of courts, and therefore the functioning of courts, in the ACT remain in Commonwealth hands and not in the hands of the territory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall endeavour to give the reasons for the Government's position on the transfer of the courts and the proposal to look at this matter again in 1990 and make a decision then. The reason for that is that there are issues to be resolved in the interim. I shall take a few moments to go through some of the issues. The first concerns the consequences of having a combination of judicial functions in the hands, quite possibly, of only one person-the Chief Minister in the new Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Government. Under the self-government Bill the Chief Minister will have all of the executive powers virtually in his or her own hands. The other Ministers will have only the responsibilities allocated to them by the Chief Minister. There is to be no administrator of the Australian Capital Territory. The appointment of judges and magistrates, therefore, would have to be made by the Chief Minister. The Chief Minister, or perhaps another Minister if the Chief Minister decided to allocate the function, would also be responsible for prosecutions and for legal aid. That adds up to the possibility of a great many functions being concentrated in the one person. The Government is concerned at the consequences of that sort of a consolidation of power.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the question of the security of tenure of judges and magistrates. The Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act makes provisions for the removal of judges. They are the same provisions that apply in the Constitution for the removal of Federal judges, which is by the Governor-General on an address from both Houses of Parliament. The Magistrates Court Ordinance provides:

. . . Magistrate may be suspended from office by the Governor-General on the grounds of misbehaviour or incapacity, but that removal of a Magistrate from office requires the same procedure as applies to the removal of a Judge.

Those provisions may not be appropriate on transfer of responsibility to the ACT, because the Governor-General, acting on the advice of Commonwealth Ministers, would have to become involved in a Territory issue which might arise entirely out of local Territory political conditions. Provisions should be in place to provide a guarantee of security of tenure for judges and magistrates. This is a matter which perhaps could be resolved in the course of the next 18 months prior to the Government's reviewing the position. I think the existing magistrates would have some reason to be concerned about their security of tenure if provisions were not put in place, and one would imagine that the resident judges of the Supreme Court of the ACT would also have some concern.

Obviously, they would have the option of resigning their Territory commissions and retaining Federal Court commissions. I am not sure how one would work out that handover. When the Northern Territory assumed responsibility for its Supreme Court, the Northern Territory Supreme Court as established by the Commonwealth Act was abolished. A Supreme Court created by a new law in the Northern Territory took its place and arrangements were made between the judges of the former court and the Territory Government they they would accept commissions to the Territory court. This ensured continuity. The handing over of the Magistrates Court in the Northern Territory was not complicated by the existence of equivalent removal provisions. The Cabinet decision to review this position in the middle of 1990 would give us a reasonable period in the interim to try to sort out the problems which I have just outlined. The Government believes those problems to be of such import as to be worthy of further consideration prior to the handover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily concede-I thought I did so when I spoke a few moments ago-that the provision for a period of time to allow negotiation and settlement of these matters is a sensible course of action. To that extent the Government has persuaded me. However, when I consider the reasons that have again been stated by the Minister as to why the Government is not prepared to agree to the transfer of the functions of the courts as at a specified forward date, they do not seem to stand up. They seem to be arguments not against transferring the function but against transferring the function at this time. I have to say that the argument about the separation of powers is invalid. State governments appoint judges. I do not think that a case has been made out that the fact that in this instance the Chief Minister will do it will in any way distinguish the ACT system from what is already in existence in all of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, questions of security of tenure need to be resolved over a period. Had the Government included paragraph (b) in this instance it would have been stipulating that by 1 July 1990 it would resolve the question of security of tenure. Even this Government, I would have thought, could resolve such a simple question within that time frame. The third reason the Minister gave was concern about joint commissions. Again, joint commissions are not at all complex to organise. I would have thought that the commonsense approach to the judges in relation to joint commissions would simply be that they be given a commission by the Territory for Territory matters and a commission by the Commonwealth for Commonwealth matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, with your indulgence, I seek leave to adjourn this matter until the end of the Committee proceedings to enable us to have a further hurried consultation.
—I do not object to that, but does the Minister wish to further consider the matter at the end of the proceedings of this Committee, or at the end of the package of committees, or where?
—I think at the end of this one would be sufficient.

—I do not object either. While the Government is considering that, I would like to ask it to consider at the same time another question with regard to this clause. Why were paragraphs (d) and (e) of clause 22 (1) included? Why were they given special mention and why were other aspects not also identified, such as bankruptcy? Does not clause 27 of this Bill really deal with that anyway? Clause 22 covers matters excluded from the power to make laws. Why has the Government chosen these and not others?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the only exclusive power of the Commonwealth. The others are concurrent. On armed forces and coinage issues, paragraphs (d) and (e) are required to place the ACT in the same position as the States in respect of their legislative power. The States are excluded from legislating on these matters by sections 114 and 115 of the Constitution.
—As the States are also excluded from making laws on other aspects, why did the Government particularly choose these ones and not others also?
—Which powers is Senator Jenkins talking about?
—I am referring to section 51 of the Constitution, where they are all listed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess to not having the Constitution in front of me and I do not have an instant recall of the whole of it. As I understand it, the honourable senator is speaking about concurrent powers and not exclusive powers.

(6) Page 3, at end of Part 1, insert the following new Part:
``PART 1a-ADMINISTRATIVE UNION OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY AND THE JERVIS BAY TERRITORY
Declaration of Parliament

``6a. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Parliament that the identity and status of the Australian Capital Territory and the Jervis Bay Territory as separate Territories of the Commonwealth should be preserved.
Administrative union of the two Territories
``6b. (1) The Australian Capital Territory and the Jervis Bay Territory shall be governed in an administrative union to the extent and in the manner provided by or under this Act.
``(2) For the purpose of subsection (1), the Jervis Bay Territory shall be annexed to, and deemed to form part of, the Australian Capital Territory to the extent that:

(a) all laws of the Australian Capital Territory (whether made before or after the commencement of this Act) as from time to time in force in the Australian Capital Territory shall, so far as applicable, apply to, and be in force in, the Jervis Bay Territory;

(b) the Administration of the Australian Capital Territory shall be responsible for the administration of the laws of the Australian Capital Territory in their application in the Jervis Bay Territory and for the provision, in the Jervis Bay Territory, of services of the kinds provided by that Administration in the Australian Capital Territory;

(c) moneys raised in the Jervis Bay Territory under laws of the Australian Capital Territory in their application in the Jervis Bay Territory shall form part of the public moneys of the Territory; and

(d) the Jervis Bay Territory shall be deemed to form part of the Australian Capital Territory for the purpose of any law of the Australian Capital Territory relating to the election of members of the Territory legislature.''.

I have not moved my amendments (1) to (4) as they are contingent on amendment (5). The Democrats believe that the residents of the Jervis Bay Territory should receive basic democratic rights-rights which are concurrent with those of residents of the ACT. Although we believe that the people of Jervis Bay should be given special consideration we also believe that as an interim measure it is not sensible to leave them in mid-air, so to speak, without electoral representation. We believe that until that matter is sorted out Jervis Bay should remain conjointly with the ACT so that the people of Jervis Bay are not disfranchised while members of the electorate of the ACT gain self-government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course Jervis Bay is a separate Commonwealth Territory. I really do not believe it is fair to saddle the citizens of the ACT with, in particular, the financial responsibility of Jervis Bay. Jervis Bay exists for a reason-to provide a seaport for the ACT; at least that is the theory, I am told. Quite obviously there is no great commonality of interest.
—It is the ACT's naval base.

—The ACT does not need its own navy, just yet. It has not so far been suggested. Clearly there is no great commonality of interest between the two communities. I do not really believe that anyone in Jervis Bay feels a great sense of kinship with fellow citizens in the ACT. However, the Commonwealth Government really has to be totally unfettered in its right to administer Jervis Bay in the most efficient way possible. The Commonwealth can provide services to the ACT on an agency basis. Senator Hill was discussing this a moment ago in relation to one of the Government amendments. The Government is confident that goodwill between it and the ACT Administration will be such that the ACT Administration will continue to provide community services to Jervis Bay under agency arrangements. Therefore, I do not see any need for the Government to agree to the Democrat amendments.

—We have discussed this matter with the Australian Democrats and have indicated that we are unable to support their amendments. We recognise that Jervis Bay is a separate Territory under a separate Act. We think it should be dealt with differently. We are not too sure exactly how it should be dealt with in the future but I think to bring it within this package of Bills would only further complicate what might be done in the future. Therefore, consistent with the step by step approach we mentioned earlier in this debate, we think that the correct decision has been made to exclude Jervis Bay in this instance.

—I ask whether the Minister would be prepared to give some kind of assurance in regard to certain elements of ACT self-government to the people who live at Jervis Bay and who pay taxes and are tied up with the ACT at the present time. If they are now not to have any input in regard to those self-government elements, what proposals does the Minister have in mind for those people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of how the citizens of Jervis Bay might also have some say in the determination of their own affairs is a matter that we have still to address. What I can say to Senator Jenkins and, indeed, to the Committee is that I will undertake to make sure that that matter is dealt with expeditiously, whether it be by means of some sort of consultative council or something else. The Government has made no decision. Therefore, I cannot announce any such decision, but I can say that as soon as this ACT self-government legislation is dealt with, I will undertake to deal with the problem of Jervis Bay very quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 4, clause 8, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
`8. (1) There shall be a legislature for the Territory.

`(2) Until the legislature referred to in subsection (1) otherwise determines, that the legislature shall be called the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly and shall consist of 17 members.'.

We have moved this amendment because we believe that it is the role of the Australian Parliament to determine matters of consequence where the national interest is included. We do not believe that either the longer term title of the ACT legislature or the number of members making up the legislature are matters of national interest. Our proposed new clause 8 (2) therefore reads:
Until the legislature referred to in subsection (1) otherwise determines, that legislature shall be called the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly and shall consist of 17 members.

In other words, we are suggesting that the first local Assembly to be set up in the ACT should have that name and should consist of 17 members but that that Assembly be able to alter its name and number of members, if in due course, it sees fit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Government has been concerned to put in place a system which meets the needs of the Australian Capital Territory. If one looks at the public concern expressed in the course of this debate over the last year or so, one sees that clearly one of the concerns most often expressed is the need to make sure that the new government is not too big, that it does not have too many Ministers and that it does not cost too much money. Government is an expensive business these days-I hope that in dealing with the Remuneration Tribunal in the next 24 hours, we do not think it is too expensive. Nonetheless, government has often been expensive. I think that what is contained in the Bill now in fact directly meets that community concern. On that basis, the Government cannot see why it should alter the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was also our view. We saw the existing clause 8 as, in fact, a compromise. For the number of members of the legislature to be increased would require regulation. Therefore, there would be a Commonwealth input. However, as is stated in the clause:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . regulations shall not be made . . . except in accordance with a resolution passed by the Assembly.

Therefore, there would be Assembly input as well. We are also anxious to restrain any rapid enlargement of this body. Therefore, consistent with the cautious approach we have adopted, we have reached the conclusion that the existing clause is, as I said, a satisfactory compromise. We had indicated that to the Australian Democrats. Therefore, we will not support their amendment. I make it clear, as I did earlier, that a number of Democrat amendments that we have indicated to the Democrats and the Government we would support have been adopted by the Government and included in its amendments. We thought that that was a way of simplifying this process. If I get up a number of times and say that I am not supporting the Democrats, I would not want it to be thought that there were not amendments of theirs which we believe are well-founded and which we support. But they tend to appear in the Government's amendments that have already been passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very charitable of Senator Hill to say that. Subclause (3) of clause 8, as it stands in the Bill, refers to regulations. I presume that it means the regulations referred to in clause 73, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Act . . .

I draw the Government's attention to the fact that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills referred specifically to clause 73, calling it a Henry VIII clause. Certainly, in ruling out that clause as part of our amendment (7), the Democrats feel very strongly that it is not pertinent that regulations should be made by the Federal Parliament on matters which will concern the ACT Assembly.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not proceed with amendment (8). My amendment (9) relates to clause 11, although we have dealt with that clause. It was dealt with in another way by the Government. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 4, clause 11, leave out ``Presiding Officer'' (wherever occurring) insert ``presiding officer''.
It is appropriate that the term `Presiding Officer' be a description of the function and not an implicit indication of a preferred title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats' concern to have the Commonwealth legislate on who can be an appropriate acting presiding officer, leaving aside the obvious inability of the Executive to do so, does not sit well with their concern to leave matters to the commonsense and good judgment of the ACT legislature. —This is one of those instances where there was considerable negotiation. I think that all parties had the same objective. I thought that a form of words had been settled that achieved that mutual objective. We understand and support what the Democrats are seeking. When I read the provisions of the Bill I thought that there was ambiguity that needed to be overcome. The Government has moved an amendment to remove the word `as' from clause 11 (2), the effect of which is that `Presiding Officer' can be nothing more than descriptive. In fact, the self-governing Assembly is obliged to provide the presiding officer with a title, which is what, I think, the Democrats are seeking. If there is any confusion at all I think it is clarified by the definition `Presiding Officer' that appears in the Bill. It is not for me to say, but I think Senator Jenkins can rest easy on this matter: her concerns are now adequately incorporated within the amended Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concede that the Government's amendment has sought to correct that matter, but I wish to continue with my amendment.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Page 6, clause 15, lines 1 to 39 leave out the clause.

I wish to have the whole of clause 15, as it stands, deleted from the Bill. Clauses 5 to 9 of my first Bill would have dealt with this matter in a much better way. The Bill to which I am referring is the Australian Capital Territory (Protection of the National Interest) Bill 1988, which is no longer on the agenda. However, clauses 5 to 9 of that Bill deal with this matter so much better than it is dealt with under clause 15 of the Government's Bill.

I believe this is a major national issue, not just a territorial matter. The ongoing relationship between the national authorities and the territorial authorities should be spelt out absolutely clearly. The principle to be observed, as far as possible, is that there should not be intervention in the legislature of one level of government-that is, the Australian Capital Territory Assembly-by the Executive of another level of government. I believe that an after the event tabling of a statement of reasons is not adequate protection. I ask the Government and the Opposition to look very carefully at this matter. I would be very pleased if a deferment were sought on this particular clause so that the Government and the Opposition may examine clauses 5 to 9 of the protection of the national interest Bill to see whether they would be preferable to what is in the Bill before us as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see a need to defer consideration. I have not discussed this with the Opposition, and I will be interested to hear what Senator Hill says. We are dealing with an unique position. The Commonwealth has ultimate responsibility for the Australian Capital Territory under the Constitution. That makes it separate from anything else. Therefore, given that there is no Administrator there has to be a last resort power. Clearly, it is not going to be exercised every day of the week. It would be a game parliament-it would not be a government; it would be a parliament-that took that decision. As honourable senators know, when Governors-General take decisions to sack governments we tend to get a bit of a reaction. I do not think that that would be any different in this circumstance. Given the constitutional position, there has to be a last resort power. I do not know of a better way of doing that than what we have here.

—The Opposition is satisfied with the clause as it stands. I indicated that to Senator Jenkins. We believe that it adequately protects the national interest. We recognise that there are some people in the Australian Capital Territory who feel that it goes too far. Nevertheless, as the Minister has said, and as I said in the second reading debate, there is a constitutional responsibility on the part of this Parliament in relation to the national capital. Therefore, a provision such as this in clause 15 is essential. We believe that the wording in this instance is adequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —By looking closely at clause 15 of the Bill we see that it says:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If, in the opinion the the Governor-General, the Assembly:
(a) is incapable of effectively performing its functions; or
(b) is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner;
the Governor-General may dissolve the Assembly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity this afternoon to make some comments about a price watch organisation on Queensland's Gold Coast and the overreaction of one chain of stores, which was shown to have less competitive grocery prices than other chains. The price watch organisation surveys grocery prices monthly at the stores of four different food chains on the Gold Coast. The prices of 36 grocery items are surveyed and the items are typical of those which a low to middle income family would buy. Using the statistical data supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the 36 items are weighted to reflect the relative usage of the particular groceries. For example, most families would buy a carton of milk more often than a jar of coffee. Milk thus has a higher weighting than coffee.

SPEECH.PARA: The survey is carried out by trained volunteers. Before any calculations are made, their returns are checked by an experienced person in a price watch organisation. About three or four days after the survey takes place, the total weighted basket prices for the various stores are given to local newspapers and other media outlets on the Coast. This allows Gold Coast residents to compare the pricing structure of various stores. It also allows individual stores to see how they rate in comparison with their competitors. There are significant variations in prices from store to store. In the October survey the basket cost ranged from $64.53 to $71.53. Earlier this month the prices for the 36-item basket of goods ranged from $66.66 to $70.36.

In the surveys, stores in the Coles chain have not on the whole fared well in relation to their competitors. This obviously struck a raw nerve in the Coles organisation because this week Coles placed the same double-paged advertisement in the Gold Coast press and in a metropolitan daily newspaper-the Gold Coast Bulletin and the Brisbane Sun. The aim of the advertisement was to portray Coles as quite competitive. Unfortunately, certain aspects of this advertisement were quite misleading.

The first matter I wish to raise is that this advertisement, without any evidence, claims that price watch groups distort the facts. If Coles has any evidence to back up this claim, the organisation should produce that evidence. If it does not have any evidence, and I believe it does not have a scintilla of evidence, the organisation should not wrongly try to denigrate community organisations. The price watch organisation on the Gold Coast is competently run and it provides a worthwhile community service. If Coles, or any other store, is dissatisfied that its prices do not compare favourably with those of other stores, it should first look at its prices rather than try to besmirch the organisation which, using voluntary labour, is able to provide the public with price comparisons.

The second matter I wish to mention is that in its advertisement Coles has compared two stores: Coles New World at Labrador and Woolworths at Broadbeach, both suburbs of the Gold Coast. There is nothing wrong with comparing these two stores, although they are many kilometres apart. A better comparison for Woolworths, Broadbeach, would be the nearby Coles Pacific Fair. But that would not suit Coles whose Pacific Fair store has higher prices than its nearby competitors. In fact, the November survey showed that Coles Pacific Fair was more expensive than Woolworths, Broadbeach.

But as I said, there is nothing wrong with comparing the two stores that were in the Coles advertisement. What is wrong is that Coles has deliberately implied that because one of its stores was less expensive than one Woolworths store, all Coles stores are cheaper than all Woolworths stores. The evidence is clear that this is not so. Indeed, the evidence in the Gold Coast region is that on the whole Coles stores are among the most expensive. All five Coles stores which were surveyed in October were more expensive than the average price of the 13 stores surveyed. Four of those five were more expensive than any of the other stores. For the November survey, two Coles stores were below the average price for 15 stores surveyed. Three were above average and it was a Coles store which was the most expensive. The evidence clearly shows that the comparison of one Coles store with one Woolworths store is not sufficient to reach the conclusion that all stores from one chain are less expensive than all stores from another chain.

A further matter worthy of mention is the actual list used by Coles in its advertisement. Unlike the price watch basket of goods, the Coles list does not at first glance appear to be typical of what a low to middle income family would buy. Over $10, for example, was spent on coffee, another $2.65 for tea and $6.08 on three different types of cereal. And unlike price watch, the prices are not weighted according to their relative usage. I am not saying that the group which carried out the research for Coles deliberately chose articles to give the Coles store an advantage, but that could easily be done.

In summary, I mention the following points. Firstly, the price watch organisation on the Gold Coast is a competent body. If stores do not like the results of the price watch surveys they should first look at their pricing policies. To denigrate a voluntary organisation carrying out a community service does not reflect well on an organisation such as Coles. Secondly, the assertion by Coles that New World is a competitive place to shop is not borne out by the evidence. Some of its stores in the Gold Coast region are far from competitive. Thirdly, the price watch survey will continue and will, from time to time, change its basket of goods so that any store which happens to obtain a list of the price watch basket's contents cannot artificially lower its surveyed prices by concentrating its efforts on only the goods in the basket. The results of each survey will be made public. Fourthly and finally, if Coles is concerned that some of its stores are more expensive than those in other chains, the remedy is in its hands-it should reduce its prices. If Coles is not competitive, the price watch organisation will not shirk its community responsibility to let the public know.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:DEFENCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988NAVAL DEFENCE AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Tate:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that it might suit the convenience of the Senate for the defence legislation Bills and the Naval Defence Amendment Bill 1988 to be debated cognately.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that this course be followed? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures contained in the two defence legislation amendment Bills before us-the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988-are welcomed by the Opposition. They have been a long time coming. While the proposed amendments are a step in the right direction, they do tend to highlight the urgent need for attention to more substantial matters. The bulk of Defence Legislation Amendment Bill No. 2, for example, is made up of odds and ends of housekeeping which were not perfected the first time and which have been left until now to be tidied up. I will deal with these first.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposals such as the decriminalisation of the wearing of articles of service uniform, the exemption of Small Arms Factory employees from firearms licensing laws and the removal of the upper limit on the amount of reparations that may be ordered by a court martial or Defence Force magistrate are quite simply good housekeeping. Each one simply rectifies what has become a Dickensian situation. Likewise, provisions to place the position of the Vice Chief of the Defence Force on a statutory basis and to include instructors in the Australian Cadet Corps are matters with which we are in accord. As for the amendment establishing arrangements for salvage claims made by naval crews, this too is really just an overdue formal recognition and regulation for the Navy of what has been maritime practice for centuries-that is, the right of salvors to claim salvage.

The Opposition welcomes the amendment to the Defence Act 1903 which requires a senior officer to render 12 months service following promotion before he or she may retire. But we welcome it not only as a money saving measure. We welcome it because it may also ensure that the forces keep the expertise of their senior officers a little longer than they are currently managing to and because it removes posting difficulties caused when a senior officer leaves shortly after promotion. The final issue dealt with in the second Bill is the ironing out of a few administrative matters relating to the 1948 Defence Force retirement benefits (DFRB) and the 1973 Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) schemes.

While on the topic of the DFRDB, I shall move to a consideration of a slightly more substantial amendment in the first Defence Legislation Amendment Bill. The proposed option to commute a pension three months before retirement, commendable and welcome as it is, only points to the range of greater and more pressing problems which have not been addressed. The proposed option of early commutation will help to ease the all too common situation where an officer must wait for up to three months after retirement for his or her pension. In the past, pensioners have had to bridge this gap with expensive loans. But there is still much to be reviewed and improved in the area of benefits and allowances-retirement, death or otherwise. And what of the 2 per cent which was lopped off the Australian Defence Force (ADF) superannuants' pensions in 1986? Like the Australian taxpayer, the Defence Force pensioners are still waiting for the Government to honour its promise and share its prosperity.

It is small wonder that in its report on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force-the Cross report-the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommends a review of the DFRDB scheme to consider allowing optional deferral of pensions after age 55 with an incentive bonus; removing the 3 per cent a year penalty on those who separate early; and increasing the resignation benefit on termination before completing 20 years service to include an interest credit relative to the member's contributions.

I turn now to the question of housing. In 1980 $25,000 was about 55 per cent of the median purchase price of a home. Since 1980 the rise in the consumer price index has been 73 per cent and the defence service home loan is now effectively worth a paltry $14,500. It is ridiculous to keep the loan ceiling in 1988 at its 1980 level. Ever since I came into this Parliament I have been urging the Government to review it. My efforts were recently vindicated by the recommendations of the Cross wastage report which urge an immediate increase in the amount of the loan, draw attention to the need to restore eligibility to those post-1985 enlistees who are currently ineligible for a loan and outline an alternative defence service homes scheme based on a framework of grants and subsidies.

Let me turn then to the second amendment in the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill which seeks to increase the Defence Housing Authority board membership to two. I particularly commend the appointment of Mrs Lorraine Sanderson to the Board. It is good to see a recognition by the Government of the need for service spouse input to Government policy in this area. After all, it is the families of service men and women whom this issue immediately affects. This provision should have gone through Parliament last year. The Opposition was ready and willing to facilitate the legislation but this time last year the Government clearly had other priorities, although I pushed for such an appointment from the inception of the Authority. I sincerely hope, however, that the Government will not rest on its laurels and that this appointment establishes a precedent for further spouse involvement in government consideration of service conditions. It is not enough to set up a national group of service spouses if their views are not channelled into purposeful implementation.

The appointment of a new financial expert to the Defence Housing Authority board, however, puzzles and concerns me somewhat. Given the list of current board members and their respective qualifications, I would have thought there was a sufficiency of financial expertise already there. I can only wonder whether Defence central is playing its checks and balances game again. This country has suffered more than enough from that game as the Cross report on the management of Australia's defence demonstrated and the recent Cross report on personnel wastage reiterated. I shall be watching the performance of this board very closely.

The proposed amendment to the Defence Housing Authority leads me to raise some more concerns about the future of the Authority. Funding of the Authority is one such concern, since questions in last month's Estimates committee hearing brought me no closer to resolving whether the Government's $750m funding commitment to the Housing Authority was a grant or a loan. The matter must be resolved and be resolved quickly. I sincerely hope that it will be resolved in favour of a grant, since a loan would incur additional costs for the Authority and, presumably, there would be a reduction in the amount of housing which could be built or purchased at a time when housing needs are increasing due to the naval expansion westwards and the Royal Australian Air Force and Army expansion northwards.

I come now to the third amendment in Bill No. 1-the introduction of open-ended engagement conditions within the Services. This is certainly a measure worth trying since it has the potential to bring a valuable flexibility to what has traditionally been a major decision for a three-, six-, or nine-year engagement. It may also give service personnel a feeling of greater control over their own lives and it may promote a greater feeling of choosing a career rather than signing on for a term. I also hope that this measure will encourage personnel to stay longer than they are doing since precious little else encourages them to do so at the moment.

The amendments in this legislation ignore the need for amendments to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal legislation. They ignore the need to undertake automatic regular reviews of pay and allowances independent of government and departmental intervention. In addition, while the Government openly encourages work-based child care as an added incentive to productivity and morale in other work environments, it completely ignores the desperate ADF need for child-care facilities. The little that has actually been achieved in this area has been achieved by the initiative of families themselves who have had to go cap in hand to the Government for financial support and, even now, only one of those centres has received any such support.

On that note I would like to turn for a moment to the consideration of the Naval Defence Amendment Bill, which is being dealt with cognately in this debate. The Bill seeks to enable civilian employees of the Defence Department who are currently employed at Garden Island in the Office of Defence Production to be transferred to a new company called Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd to be established next year. I want to establish from the outset that the Opposition is not opposed to this Bill. Quite the reverse. We support it because it seeks to provide privatisation of a kind not unlike its Williamstown counterpart. Our hope is that through a degree of privatisation, Australian Defence Industries will follow in Williamstown's footsteps. Having established Opposition support, however, the point that I would like to make in relation to this Bill is that while defence service men and women must pressure and fight and beg the Government for their allowances, the Defence Department's civil employees at Garden Island are being looked after very nicely, thank you very much.

Clause 4 (3) specifically protects the terms and conditions of service for Garden Island employees and ensures that their leave and superannuation entitlements are preserved. This is as it should be. Apart from sharing the concern of my colleague, Mr Tim Fischer, that this clause should not result in so much flexibility as to enable the continuation of rorts and inefficient work practices, I recognise that the interests of Garden Island employees have been adequately protected. However, I cannot help contrasting the lot of these civilian defence employees with that of their counterparts in the forces. If the needs and conditions of service for service men and women were monitored half as closely and looked after half as diligently as those of civilians, the Defence Force would not be suffering its current wastage crisis.

If the Government had devoted more time, money and effort to the defence personnel portfolio instead of being so unbending on equipment, a lot more meaningful action could have been taken than these insufficient and insubstantial few amendments which are before us today. The Cross report, for instance, recommended amendments to Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal legislation, telephone and postal subsidies, Medicare levy exemption where a spouse is in employment and amendments to the DFRDB and the defence service home loans legislation. But of even greater urgency than these legislative amendments is the resolution of the 150 to 200 matters awaiting determination in the Department of Industrial Relations. Some of them have been waiting for up to two years. Recently I have highlighted the notorious example of our men on the Iraq-Iran border who have received the Nobel Peace Prize for their work but who have still not got their allowances.

As I said earlier, the Opposition welcomes all of the proposed amendments but they are a poor lot when we review the matters to which the Government should be addressing its efforts. The realities in the Defence Force today are that men and women are doing a marvellous and demanding job defending Australia, but they are lacking the support from their Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for facilitating the passage of these Bills. I came into the chamber at the point when Senator Newman was talking about child-care. I want to digress very briefly by commending my colleague the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Ros Kelly, for the work she has done in relation to recognising the needs of women in the defence forces. She has done a great deal. Perhaps I should undertake to obtain from her a list of the issues that I know she is following up, particularly in relation to child-care.
—No, it is not good enough.

—As Senator Newman knows, I live in a defence city. I can honestly say, putting politics aside as we do occasionally in this place, especially at 1.05 p.m. on a Thursday, that women in Townsville frequently commend the role that she has played since taking on her portfolio.
—She has not got the defence children to the top of the list yet.
—Order! Senator Newman. This is not a duet.

—That is not the perception. I would just like to put on the record that I believe that women, both in the Services and Defence Force wives, are very appreciative of the role that the Minister, Ros Kelly, is playing. I take this opportunity to commend her.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Newman that these Bills are fundamentally good housekeeping measures. As I indicated, I think Mrs Kelly does have a concern for child-care. But I take issue with Senator Newman in respect of what she said about individual matters raised in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force-the Cross report. This is an area on which Mrs Kelly and the Minister for Defence, Kim Beazley, have spoken very clearly in the debate in the other place. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the Statutory Instruments (Tabling and Disallowance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill, which principally seeks to amend certain provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act, has the effect of closing two potential loopholes that would be open to a government which with ill intent wanted to avoid the scrutiny and disallowance provision safeguards of this Parliament. An enormous amount of law is now made in the form of delegated legislation, principally through regulations, and does not receive the same attention as legislation-that is, it is not required to be passed through both Houses of this Parliament. It is important, therefore, that there be an adequate safeguard procedure and that procedure is the disallowance mechanism which is contained principally in section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act. The effect of this section is that delegated legislation must be tabled in the Parliament. Within 15 days a motion for disallowance can be moved and then, I think, within another 15 days that motion must be disposed of. In other words, either House of Parliament has the capacity to disallow regulations so that they are no longer law.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances brought to the attention of the Parliament-and I think to some extent it was relying on previous advice given to it by the then Secretary, Mr Peter O'Keefe, now a Clerk-Assistant of the Senate-that there are ways in which this disallowance mechanism can be avoided. Two ways have been raised and they are dealt with by the provisions of this Bill. The first is that it may be possible to circumvent the scrutiny procedure by not tabling regulations and remaking the identical regulations on the day after the expiration of the 15 sitting days tabling period. That could have the effect of indefinitely keeping the regulations in force. Clause 6 of the Bill before us seeks to close that loophole.

The second loophole is closed by ensuring that regulations are not remade whilst subject to disallowance. I do not think either loophole has been used in recent years. However, I am told that such a device was used on a number of occasions in 1910. Nevertheless, the Parliament obviously has a responsibility to ensure that government meets not only the letter of the law but the spirit of the law. Because governments do not always meet the spirit of the law, this Act is being passed by the Parliament to close these loopholes.

It seems appropriate, Mr Deputy President, to take this opportunity to pay a tribute to the work of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, its staff, and the Clerks. That Committee, as you know, has a responsibility on behalf of the Senate to scrutinise delegated legislation and to ensure that it is in accordance with the statute, that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal, and that it does not contain matters more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

I think it is reasonable to say that this Committee is the only body that effectively scrutinises the mass of delegated legislation and, therefore, it performs a magnificent service for the Parliament and for the democratic process itself. As you would also be aware, Mr Deputy President, this Committee has received great credit internationally for the work that it has done in ensuring that governments do not abuse their powers to make delegated legislation. It seems that this is just another occasion on which the Committee and its staff have brought to the attention of the Parliament ways in which the procedures can be tightened.

We obviously support the legislation. We support the principal amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act and the consequential amendments that follow. We believe that potential loopholes-I am not suggesting that they would necessarily be used by this Government or a successive governments-are closed by these amendments. For those reasons, the Opposition supports the legislation.
