SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today and tomorrow as he is attending meetings of the National Crime Authority Intergovernmental Committee and the Australian Police Ministers Council. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Tate in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer to the answer that the Minister gave to a question I asked yesterday concerning Army rations.
—The non-answer.

—The non-answer; thank you, Senator. In that answer the Minister completely ignored the implications that the shortage of ration resources would have on dozens of Army exercises, and he claimed it was only an internal matter for the Army itself to work out. Apart from the cancellation of dozens of Army exercises due to a lack of ration resources, is it also a fact that due to a lack of money for repairs and maintenance, replacement of stores and equipment, travel and subsistence, freight and cartage, petrol, oil and lubricants, training in Land Command will cease at the end of this month? Is it also true that in addition to these current problems the Government has directed that $300m is to be lopped off the logistic vote over the five-year defence program and, of this, the Army's share is $105m? Is it also a fact that this inability to do the job through a lack of funds is a major cause of soldiers quitting the forces? And will the Minister now admit that these severe financial strictures will gut land forces capability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not admit that they will gut the land forces capability. I apologise for running in late and trying to get down some parts of Senator Newman's question. I might say that, fortunately, today's question is somewhat shorter than those that I have been getting lately, which have gone on at some length. The question of wastage in the defence forces or indeed the Army, to which Senator Newman just referred, has, I think, received quite considerable publicity in recent days, particularly since the publication of the Cross report on Personnel Wastage in the Defence Force. In answering the question yesterday I think I covered the matter of rations about as far as one could cover it, and I do not really believe that I need to go into that question any more.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the rest of Senator Newman's question is concerned, all I can say is that over the past few years the Government has provided very considerable sums for logistics support for the defence forces. There is no suggestion from the forces themselves that they are unable to function or that their capability has been gutted.

Certainly there have been problems with wastage, but it should be pointed out that wastage is a problem for peacetime armies around the world: it is by no means restricted to Australia. Nonetheless, in addressing the concerns expressed in the Cross report the Government will give a considered response and I am sure it will come up with at least some solutions to the difficulties faced by not only Australia but all Western countries with respect to their peacetime armies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister, amongst a number of platitudes, said that there has been no suggestion from the forces themselves that they are having any problem in this area. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the questions which I have put to him now are based entirely on the evidence and advice which the Army has supplied to the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not suggested that no-one in the forces has been unhappy at times with some government decisions. I do not know an area of government where that does not happen. I said that the forces themselves have not suggested that their logistical capabilities have been so impaired that they cannot function. I repeat that: they have not suggested that that is the case. Certainly, people in the forces have suggested that we could do more in this area or that. Indeed, that is suggested across the range of all portfolios that all Ministers represent. I only wish that we could do everything that everyone wants on every occasion but, in a period of restraint, which this Government has shown over the last few years and which the honourable senator's Party at least preaches is proper, we have done what I believe is the best possible in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen reports in the media that a Mr Peter Foster is marketing a product called `Diet Patch' which he claims is a weight loss product? I ask the Minister whether he is aware that Mr Peter Foster has been described in the British media as:

QUESTION.PARA: A rogue who has been involved in a whole series of dodgy enterprises ranging from fight fixing to magic smoking cures and a man who has been branded a cheat and a liar by a judge.

Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this is the same Mr Peter Foster who marketed a product called Bai Lin tea in Australia and also in England where fraud charges were laid against him after investigations by trade practices officers? If this is the same Peter Foster, was a warrant issued for his arrest in the United Kingdom after he forfeited his bail? Is the Minister aware of the statement by the Queensland Minister responsible for consumer affairs that he is `monitoring the situation' and, if so, has the Minister asked the Trade Practices Commission to investigate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the product to which Senator Black refers which Mr Peter Foster is supposedly promoting in Queensland. Apparently the product works on the basis that two drops are absorbed into the skin, thereby removing hunger pangs. I notice that Senator Boswell is rather interested in this-I cannot understand why! Mr Foster is promoting this product which he claims has this miracle cure. It is also in liquid form and it consists of 99.6 per cent alcohol and water. Senator Black referred to some of Mr Foster's previous history. It is true to say that Mr Foster did flee Britain leaving a warrant for his arrest and $50,000 bail, and he was involved in fraud relating to the marketing of Bai Lin tea.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be said that this activity of Mr Foster's has been advertised in a number of newspapers including the Sunday Sun of 20 November this year. There have also been articles relating to the reaction from the Queensland Minister responsible for consumer affairs, Mr Vin Lester, to the claims and the product as promoted by Mr Foster. In fact, Mr Lester claims that Peter Foster is one of the State's most colourful con men. Obviously that is a big wrap for anyone in Queensland!

The particular problem that has been highlighted for consideration by the Trade Practices Commission is that the advertisements in relation to this product claim that the product has been tested by the Queensland Institute of Technology. I am advised by the Trade Practices Commission, which has contacted the Queensland Consumer Affairs Bureau, that this is not so. The Trade Practices Commission also had direct contact with the Queensland Institute of Technology, which also denied that it has tested the product. What has happened is that a market research branch of the Institute, Q Search, was approached to undertake limited market research on the product and establish consumer reaction to it. So we seem to have a breach of particularly section 53 (d) of the Trade Practices Act. That section provides that a corporation shall not represent that it has sponsorship or approval that it does not have. I am currently awaiting more information from the Queensland Consumer Affairs Bureau with respect to this, but the Trade Practices Commission is in daily contact with it on this matter. The position is that, if no action is taken within Queensland on the substance and the misleading advertising, I will ask the Trade Practices Commission to act very promptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. As a result of changes recommended by the World Heritage Bureau, the original boundaries nominated for World Heritage listing in north Queensland have been altered by excising 31 areas and adding eight, without making new regulations under the Conservation Act, which means that new areas are not protected and that legal logging has since taken place. It also means that there are areas still protected which are now no longer part of the nomination. In view of this fact, and considering that the Minister's office has had no contact with the Queensland Government since 30 September, thus ensuring that a joint management authority is impossible and that Federal legislation will be required for a management plan, does the Minister believe it is misleading to go to the World Heritage Bureau in December without bringing the appropriate regulations before Parliament and without introducing legislation allowing Commonwealth Government management of the listed site? Is he not, in fact, pre-empting proper parliamentary procedure by taking his amended proposals to Brasilia without the endorsement of the Australian Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it staggering that Senator Boswell could say that the reason that there cannot be joint management of the wet tropics rainforest is that my office has not been in contact with the Queensland Government since 30 September. The great difficulty we have had throughout this whole exercise is that the Queensland Government has, time and again, failed to respond to my pleas and pleas from other people in this Government to sit down to talk about joint management. The Queensland Government will only do so if the Commonwealth will agree to its core area concept of three small core areas in which there is no logging throughout the rest of the wet tropics. This of course includes quotas of virgin forest to be logged because the industry cannot survive even on the much reduced quota of 60,000 cubic metres now given to it by the Queensland Government without going into virgin areas. The Commonwealth has made it clear from day one that this is not acceptable. Not only is it not acceptable to this Government but also the Queensland Government would not be spending the extraordinary sums of money in publicity and sending 30 people to Brasilia if it did not realise that this argument was going down like a lead balloon in all quarters.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Boswell and other honourable senators would be aware that the Queensland Government has requested massive boundary changes which we would not accommodate. We were asked by the World Heritage Bureau to review boundaries of the area and we did so. After a careful look we came up with boundaries in which, I think, the area affected was about one per cent or something like it--

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to bring them into Parliament? That is what I am asking.
—I am asked when I will come to Parliament with--
—It is a supplementary question.

—No, it is not a supplementary question. It is part of what Senator Boswell asked. I was getting there. I told him yesterday that he did not have patience and he is again displaying the roguish behaviour of the National Party in Queensland. To get back to that part of the question, that review of the boundaries took place over several months. We finalised a decision on boundaries-I cannot recall the date but it was a month or six weeks ago-to take to Brasilia the week after next.
—I am not worried about Brasilia. I am worried about the Parliament. When are you going to bring them into Parliament?
—What can I say to this man?
—You can answer the question.
—Well if you would shut up for a minute I would answer it.
—Order!

—I respectfully withdraw the words `shut up' and ask Senator Boswell to keep quiet. After the World Heritage Committee has accepted the Commonwealth's nomination, which I believe to be a certainty, then we will promulgate the necessary regulations to give effect to the protection of all the area including the changed area.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When does the Minister plan to introduce legislation for the management plan before he takes it to Brasilia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Boswell, as on so many questions, is mistaken. The fact is that we do not need to have a management plan in place to nominate the area at the World Heritage meeting in December. Senator Boswell has always failed to understand that, first, there has never been a management plan for a great many places on the World Heritage List. Secondly, the Commonwealth has said that it will manage the area of north Queensland wet tropics on its own if it needs to do so. We shall undertake to do that next year. But it is my firm belief, and always has been, that even the Queensland Government will see the light of day and sit down to talk to us next year. If it does not do that after Brasilia, then all it will achieve is a delay of the payment of $75m to the citizens of north Queensland. If it tries to do that, the political odium at the end of the day will be too great, although one might say that, with its popularity ratings down into almost single figures, it does not really matter what it does; it is gone.

—I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce: Why did the Australian Space Office or the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce sign an agreement on space commerce and technology with China? What are the benefits to Australia?
—This is very difficult.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney compliments Senator Aulich's question by pointing out that it is very difficult. I am sure that Senator Chaney would find it so but it just so happens that I am able to answer it. That is a comment on the relative merit of the Government and the Opposition in this place. The Australian Space Office signed a memorandum of understanding with the Chinese Academy of Space Technology on 19 November, during the visit of the Chinese Premier. The agreement reflects the interest of the Chinese in further cooperation with Australia. Of course, it very largely stems from the decision by Aussat to use the Long March rocket for the launch of Aussat's next generation of satellites. It further stems from the fact that Australia and China have complementary interests in the commercial and scientific exploitation of space technology.

ANSWER.PARA: During the visit of the Chinese Premier, I had two meetings with Mr Lin Zongtang, China's Minister for Aeronautics and Astronautics Industry. He told me that China was very appreciative of the Aussat decision and saw it as a base for considerable international commercial and other cooperation between the two countries. As I said, this in part explains the enthusiasm of the Chinese for exploring the possibility of other forms of space technology cooperation. There is no doubt that China benefits from cooperation with a technologically advanced country in developing its own capabilities and recognises that Australia is prepared to cooperate in mutually beneficial activities.

I want to give a couple of examples of the areas of potential cooperation which have been identified so far. The first is an oceanographic satellite which would allow for the identification, exploitation and management of offshore fisheries, and contribute to a number of other areas of marine study. Australia happens to have a fairly well advanced capacity, for example, in remote sensing. That is of considerable interest to the Chinese. The second project is a meteorological satellite which could use one or more of the innovative instruments being developed in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting more and more like Barry Jones every day.
—You are getting more and more like Alley Oop every day.
—Who?

—Alley Oop-the caveman. The second project is a meteorological satellite which could use one or more of the innovative instruments being developed in Australia to improve the scope and accuracy of meteorological measurements from space. Most of these projects will draw on and develop--
—Why didn't you put down a statement?

—I understand the honourable senator's distinct lack of interest in these matters but perhaps he ought to be a little interested in them. These projects will draw on and develop expertise in the Bureau of Meteorology and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in both areas of meteorological and oceanographic technology. A third area of commercial space activity is in the sale by Australian organisations of ground support services for Chinese satellites. That is already happening. Australia already provides these services to the American and European space agencies and for the international organisation Intelsat, and is very well placed to provide the same sort of service in China. In conjunction with the visit of the Chinese Premier, Mr Li Peng, there was also a symposium in Sydney on cooperation in space. That symposium explored--
—Not even Senator Aulich is listening to the answer.
—I am sure that Senator Puplick would be interested.
—Mr President, I wish to raise a point of order. I claim to have been misrepresented, and at a later time I shall seek to redress the situation.
—There is no point of order.
—Will we ask the Minister to repeat the answer?

—On a point of order, Mr President: owing to the fact that Senator Aulich has asked the question, I just want the Minister to know that we would agree to the incorporation of the balance of his answer in Hansard.

—I am very confused by that. Somebody just asked me to repeat the answer, I thought, and I shall do so. Another example of the closer relations in science and technology being developed between the two countries is the symposium to which I referred. It will explore both technological and industrial collaboration between Australia and China. These issues may seem remote for the Opposition. In fact, they are very remote for it since Opposition members are nowhere near to understanding them. It is very useful to have an answer to a question which might help the Opposition's understanding because these are very important issues for Australia's future. An Opposition which essentially is locked into the 1960s may have difficulty in understanding them, but that is the Opposition's problem rather than ours.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Does the Minister agree that attendant care should be accepted as a necessary part of adequate income security for people with disabilities? Is the Government concerned that in the first year of the operation of the three-year trial national scheme $400,000 of funding was returned, unused, to Consolidated Revenue? Does the Minister concede that this was in large measure the result of the restrictions on eligibility, making it difficult for many disabled people who could benefit to qualify? Is the Government prepared to broaden the eligibility criteria for the attendant care scheme so that the scheme can function cost-effectively, efficiently and productively for the benefit of the disabled and the community as a whole by including, for instance, disabled people currently undergoing acute and/or rehabilitation treatment; disabled people living in the community at risk of being institutionalised; disabled people currently living in the community and who, by their reliance on family or friends, lose control of their independence; and disabled people currently living in institutional settings, for example, hostels?

—Senator Powell will know that the Government's attendant care scheme has a particular focus and that issues associated with the broadening of the scheme must be discussed with State governments which, along with the Federal Government, have responsibility for providing services for people with disabilities. Senator Powell has asked a detailed set of questions. I will respond to them in greater detail at a future time, but very quickly.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In light of the first part of the Minister's answer, I ask whether the Government is currently undertaking those necessary discussions with State governments.
—I shall include an answer to that question when I answer all of Senator Powell's questions.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government. I refer to an article in the Illawarra Mercury last Thursday. Can the Minister advise what assistance the Federal Government has provided to the Illawarra Regional Organisation of Councils? Can she also advise on the future of this regional organisation of councils?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Childs for giving me some notice of this question. I was certainly concerned to read in the Illawarra Mercury that the very successful Illawarra Regional Organisation of Councils was considered to have a future that was `under threat'. I take this opportunity to explain very clearly the policy of the Office of Local Government in regard to funding regional organisations of councils. Such organisations are one way in which councils in diverse regions of Australia can come together and focus on the needs of those regions and work together across a broad range of issues, while at the same time maintaining their independence and their commitment to what they see as their immediate parochial needs. Senator Boswell will be interested to know that, thanks to Senator Richardson's initiative, a number of councils in the World Heritage listed area are looking at coming together in terms of cooperating in a community initiative package-but more of that at another time.

ANSWER.PARA: To come back to the Illawarra Regional Organisation of Councils, since 1984-85 this organisation has received $90,000 for secretarial support. We have what we believe is a very fair and equitable procedure of giving secretarial support to regional councils where they form for three years and three years only. We do that because resources are limited and have to be spent in the most responsible and fairest way. Where a regional organisation of councils establishes itself and is accepted by a group of councils in a region, if it is successful and contributing to the economy of the region, those councils themselves will, we hope, choose to contribute to the maintenance of the secretariat. I see no reason why the councils involved-and we are looking at councils as large as Wollongong, Shellharbour, Kiama, Shoalhaven and a number of other councils-if they want their regional councils to continue should not make a necessary contribution.

Bringing councils together in this way is a means of attracting a large degree of recognition to the region. Over the last three years the Illawarra region has attracted $268,000 from the Office of Local Government under its local government development program. This is precisely because, instead of competing with each other in regard to applications for funding, councils have been working on projects of benefit to the region. I hope that councils in the region will continue to fund the secretariat. They have been very successful, but I have a responsibility to other regions and to encourage other councils throughout Australia to take advantage of this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Department of Community Services and Health released doctors' provider numbers to government departments, statutory authorities, private organisations or, indeed, any other groups in Australia? If so, which ones? Secondly, what evidence is there of a written agreement by such parties to abide by the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act 1973, as amended?
—I will have to take Senator Sheil's question on notice and reply by the end of Question Time today.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he can inform the Senate as to how the likely level of private business investment in the present financial year compares with the level recorded in 1982-83.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget Papers give estimates of growth in private investment spending by businesses this year of 12 per cent in real terms, which will take the level of business investment as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) to 12 per cent. Those are coincidentally identical figures-12 per cent of growth and 12 per cent of GDP.

ANSWER.PARA: In Question Time yesterday, honourable senators will remember, Senator Stone asserted that 1982-83 was the `tail end of a business investment boom', and that that explained why the current account deficit as a proportion of GDP in 1982-83 was 4 per cent, notwithstanding the fact that we were going through the deepest recession, or depression, since the 1930s. Senator Stone has often been accused in the past, and I think justifiably so, of making a judgment about the state of the world without bothering to look at the evidence which might either support or contradict that judgment; and then when the evidence is forced upon him he selects that which supports his predetermined conclusion and ignores all that does not.

If Senator Stone cares to look at the figures for 1982-83, he will in fact find that in that year, as a proportion of GDP, private investment by businesses was 10.4 per cent-as compared with 12 per cent for this year-and that in 1982-83 private business investment in real terms fell by 12 1/2 per cent over the previous year. So the so-called resources boom to which Senator Stone was implicitly referring was well and truly over before the 1982-83 financial year, which was, of course, a year of appalling recession. There is no way that a valid argument can be mounted that the 4 per cent current account deficit in the final year of the Fraser-Howard regime was in any way attributable to a business investment boom. Indeed, we had a business investment slump.

After all this, it is no wonder that Dr Hewson said to me on Wednesday of last week, `Don't quote Stone at me'. However, Dr Hewson ought not complain because he cannot even copy out Hansard pinks accurately, as he displayed with a fairly silly press release he issued yesterday which purports to quote me as saying, `There is certainly no likelihood at this stage that it will be as much as than 4 per cent'. Finally, the estimate for private investment spending as a proportion of gross domestic product for this financial year, at 12 per cent, is the highest that it has been in any year since at least 1976-77, higher than it was in the year of the so-called resources boom in 1981-82, when it stood at 11.7 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Is the Minister aware that the Trade Practices Commission recently decided to change South Australia's newsagents distribution system by allowing large retail concerns to sell newspapers on supermarket shelves? Does the Minister agree that this places at risk the investment of thousands of family owned newsagencies? Further, is the Minister aware that this decision has important implications for newsagents throughout Australia in view of a national review of the newsagents system to be undertaken by the Trade Practices Commission early in the new year? Lastly, will the Minister give a commitment on behalf of the Government to present to the Trade Practices Commission's national review a submission against the South Australian decision, which weighs so heavily in favour of a few large retail conglomerates at the expense of thousands of independently operated, family owned businesses?
—An excellent question.

—Senator Boswell says `Excellent question'. It is a good question of a Minister, but I would not think that Senator Boswell would be very keen on questions at all, considering the Party that he comes from.
—That is unkind.
—I know it is unkind; it was intended to be. Senator McGauran, I was not aware of the Trade Practices Commission's decision, and I will try to find out about it.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the attention of the Minister to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on sales of Australian wines. How does the Minister interpret those figures? Does he agree that they indicate that the Australian wine industry is continuing to make an important contribution to improving Australia's balance of payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the most recently published statistics on Australian wine sales, in relation to both the domestic market and exports, issued on 8 November. The figures show that between 1985-86 and 1987-88-that is, over a period of two years-wine exports, in volume terms, increased by 260 per cent, increasing by some 97 per cent in the first year and 83 per cent in the second year. Those two figures compounded give the growth figure of 260 per cent.
—Was that something as a result of your tax or was it something to do with the value of the Australian dollar?

—I point out to Senator Lewis that, in value terms, the growth was even more significant, from just over $20m to over $90m-an increase of 350 per cent. This shows that Australian wine of good quality is being appreciated by overseas buyers as well as by domestic consumers. So far for this financial year the export position has continued to improve. There has been a further 3 1/2 per cent increase in the volume of exports for the first two months of this financial year compared with the same two months of 1987-88. Even more significantly, again comparing those same two time periods, the value of exports has increased by almost 64 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, clearly this is an area which has potential, because the Australian product is both of good quality and competitively priced. The Government notes, as I am sure does everyone else, with considerable satisfaction the enormous percentage growth of exports of Australian wines. Those exports are currently earning somewhat more-that is, $90m-in export income, thereby, even on a net basis, taking probably $70m or thereabouts off our current account deficit. That just happens to be-and there is no functional relationship between these two figures either-the same amount that the Opposition, in opposing the tax legislation pertaining to bringing the gold industry into the same taxation net as all others, wants to hand over to Washington as unofficial foreign aid to the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the fact that the Australian dollar has already risen 7.5 per cent relative to the United States dollar since the Budget was brought down, what adjustments, if any, have so far been made to balance of payments assumptions and to the overall Budget outcome for 1988-89 as spelt out in the Budget papers?
—Have you got a brief on that?

—I can actually remember a few numbers-unlike Senator Hill and his colleagues-fairly well. I will take Senator Archer's word for it that the bilateral Australian-US dollar rate has appreciated by 7 1/2 per cent since the Budget. However, the trade weighted index as of last week-and I have not looked at it this week-was in fact standing at just above 62, against a Budget forecast of 60.
—It is still 62.

—It is still 62, Senator Button tells me. That is, of course, very much less than a 7 1/2 per cent increase; indeed, it is an increase of about 4 per cent. But there have been no changes to the Budget assumptions because of the exchange rate being somewhat higher for the trade weighted index and, of course, higher again for the Australian-US dollar rate. As those facts imply, the change in the Australian-US dollar rate says perhaps more about the weakness of the US dollar than it does about the relative strength of the Australian dollar. However, the forecasts have not been adjusted, and it remains to be seen whether either the bilateral rate or the whole trade weighted index in the end is so far away from the present Budget estimates.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Recalling the partial disruption of the scientific program in Antarctica last summer after the loss of the Nella Dan, can the Minister inform the Senate of the prospects for scientific research in the coming summer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it has to be acknowledged that the loss of the Nella Dan did cause some disruption to our program of research in the Antarctic last year and, in fact, has caused some disruption again to the program this year. Unfortunately that is something I suppose we will not resolve until the new Antarctic ship is completed, which I still expect to be towards the end of next year. Most of the reductions are reductions in programs for marine science research. Despite that, Australia will be conducting a major program of scientific research covering areas such as oceanography, glaciology, meteorology, environmental studies, life sciences, earth sciences and physics-a whole host. Fortunately, because we fairly quickly chartered the Lady Franklin, the replacement ship for the Nella Dan, we were still able to carry out a significant, although as I have admitted, reduced marine science program. A total of 128 scientists will carry out 139 projects at four Australian stations and three summer bases.

ANSWER.PARA: It is significant that 30 of those programs will be concerned with climate change. Obviously the Antarctic is the area in the world, the most pristine wilderness area, which has relevance to studies on climate change. We have new and continuing programs on climate-related projects which will include investigations into the earth's upper atmosphere; gathering data on temperature, winds and gravity waves; obtaining measures of the ionosphere; determining seasonal variations in the earth's vertical electric field and, of course, monitoring the ozone layer above Macquarie Island. Obviously these are exciting programs.

I would particularly like to refer to the prospect this year of more deep ice drilling at Law Dome. We hope this will enable us to study climate change over the previous millennia and look at its relevance to current and future changes. We have provided research grants and logistic support to enable this extensive program to be carried out. I am more than confident that this year's program will contribute significantly not only to our knowledge of the Antarctic but hopefully to the prospects of climate change not just in our region but worldwide.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and relates to the Government's tertiary tax scheme and arises from representations from the University of Western Australia to me as a follow-up to the representations not answered by the Prime Minister, about the position of students enrolling in the science faculty at the University of Western Australia. Can the Minister confirm that science students who enrol for courses carrying more than the number of points required for a degree, and those exceptional students who undertake an even more arduous course of study, will have a tax liability of $1,800 per annum, the amount applying to all standard full time courses? If this is not the case, if students undertaking those extra units of study have to pay a higher tax, does not the Minister agree that this could act as a deterrent to the pursuit of academic excellence in scientific studies which, I am sure he would agree, would be against Australia's best interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note on the more generalised issue. I think the short answer is that it is possible that a person who is enrolled for more than the normal one-year work load, will be charged more than $1,800 a year, but that there will be a considerable amount of discretion left to the institution, and the final decisions will be made by the institution. The written advice that I have is rather long and I will read just a few passages from it.

ANSWER.PARA: The higher education contribution scheme, which is being introduced in 1989, provides for an annual course contribution of $1,800, with each student's actual contribution being based on the equivalent full time study being undertaken by a student in a semester. The Commonwealth provides funding for higher education institutions based on the equivalent full time study load undertaken by students. So there is a symmetry there. But it is left to the institutions to determine within guidelines issued by the Commonwealth the standard annual program for a course. The guidelines provide for institutions to use the minimum credit points for a course, where these exist, or in other courses the normal annual student program.

A student's equivalent full time study in a semester is based on the actual subjects or units in which the student is enrolled relative to the standard program. Where a student undertakes a course involving more than the minimum number of points required for a degree or additional subjects, the additional student load is taken into account when assessing an institution's performance against its funded student load.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister seen the reports in the papers over the last few days about drug usage amongst Australian sports people, including very young sports men and women? In the light of recent actions to ban athletes from elite sports if they are found to be using drugs, is there not a problem of division in the sporting industry? Can the Minister confirm the Government's position on the issue of drug use in sport, and what actions it is taking to address what is obviously a significant problem? What steps can the Minister take to tackle the program regarding national sporting organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the reports to which Senator Crowley refers, most of which I think spring from evidence that was given before the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which is chaired by Senator Black. I think they do give rise to considerable distress. I was quite worried at the evidence of growing use of drugs by some very young sports people, and I think that is something we should be very concerned about. I think the use of steroids by weightlifters is particularly distressing because, given the evidence that is now being presented, it is apparently widespread.

ANSWER.PARA: I will concede that there is some degree of division within the sporting community and among some people who are in the practice of sports medicine, about drugs in sport, but I would not wish to overstate it. I still believe that overwhelmingly throughout the sporting organisations in Australia, and for most of those associated with sports medicine, there is still an abhorrence of the use of drugs by athletes. I would like to take this opportunity to restate the Government's position on this. The Government remains totally opposed to the use of drugs to enhance sporting performance, and that is not a position that is likely to change.

Over the last few years we have been working on a number of ways to enforce that view. Via the auspices of the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Institute of Sport, we have actively supported the policies of the medical commission of the International Olympic Committee and its efforts to clear up this abuse. To that end, since I have returned from Seoul, I had talks with Olympic officials and with officials of the Institute of Sport, to impress upon them the need for, if you like, taking the hardest line possible on the question. If I am to present to Cabinet next year a new proposal on how we will fund sport in Australia, we will certainly be making the receipt of funds by sporting organisations dependent upon their expressed desire and demonstrated capacity to ensure that drugs are eliminated from their sports.

I refer to the national program of drugs in sports, which commenced in 1985. That program has gained worldwide respect. It employs a full time officer and it is overseen by an expert committee which is chaired by Dr Brian Corrigan, who I do not think has a real peer in the field of sports medicine in Australia. It has developed strategies, not just in my portfolio but in the Department of Community Services and Health, and has had a close liaison with the national campaign against drug abuse and the drug offensive. We are making the priorities drug testing, prevention by education, research and, of course, law enforcement and policy development.

The Australian Government Analytical Laboratories has been working to get international accreditation for drug testing. In the meantime it has achieved a notable success. We are advised that it will be able to carry out all national sports drug testing from 1 January 1989-12 months ahead of schedule. I congratulate it on the work it has done in getting to that stage so quickly. In the area of education, extensive resource materials have been made available to schools and more will be made available. As far as grants under the sports talent encouragement plan are concerned, all the talented athletes who get grants from the Government are, of course, subjected to random drug testing. Whatever happens next year in regard to any new submission, that system will be reinforced. I believe that if all sports associated with the reception of government funds cooperate-those that do not wish to cooperate can be made to-within the next few years we can see the elimination of the use of drugs in sport. That is something I intend to pursue with great vigour over the next couple of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to the announcement by Mr Dawkins of the setting up of a Commonwealth Government inquiry into research policies. Will the inquiry be able to recommend the reversal of the proposals for gross bureaucratic centralisation of higher education research? Will it be able to point out that, although the White Paper on higher education professes to be interested in deregulation, in fact all its effects go in exactly the opposite direction? Is not this bureaucratic centralisation of educational activities totally discredited around the world? Will not the effect of the Minister's proposals be that our universities will inevitably range from the academically very good to the mediocre? Will the inquiry be able to recommend measures to prevent a de facto research quota for mediocre institutions? Will the inquiry be able to recommend that the Minister, who has identified a real problem but has almost exactly the worst solution to that problem, should tear up his White Paper and think again?

—Senator Hamer has asked about 10 questions altogether. I do not accept his term `gross bureaucratic centralisation' of research activity. Towards the end of his question he referred-I think I have the words down correctly-to a `de facto research quota for mediocre institutions'. I thought that was what the existing arrangements effectively did. I thought that there was a research component paid to all institutions without any overall evaluation of the quality of the research being done. Indeed, as I understand it, one of the purposes that the Government had in mind for the policy was to try to get more valid, qualitative comparisons of what the institutions were doing. In one sense that inevitably involves a bit more centralisation, but I do not see how we can get the comparative, qualitative evaluation without, in some sense, having a bit more centralisation. The question proper addressed the review that Mr Dawkins announced. I am asked whether it will have authority to recommend changes to policies previously announced. Frankly, I do not know. I will have to refer that to Mr Dawkins for an answer.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, concerns Christmas Island. Given the Minister's reply to my question of 15 March 1988, in which he expressed hope for announcing promised extensions of the national park on Christmas Island and a plan of management as soon as possible, and the recent meetings held between him and the Minister for the Arts and Territories, I ask: Can the Minister give a commitment that all remaining rainforest will be included in the national park for the purpose of conservation? Is it true that the Department of the Arts and Territories has failed to access the $500,000 allocated by Federal Cabinet for urgent rehabilitation works? If so, why? Is it also true that the Department has refused requests by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to release a $30,000 soil conservation services grant that might have been used by the Service to undertake rehabilitation? When will these moneys be made available to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service? Finally, will the plan of management and the scientific research centre be in operation before further phosphate mining commences, in order to monitor it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last couple of weeks I have had some discussions with my colleague Clyde Holding, the Minister for the Arts and Territories. We have finalised boundaries for the national park on Christmas Island. I do not have a map of those boundaries yet. We are at the moment compiling a detailed description of the boundaries so that we can comply with the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Once these boundaries have been established, 70 per cent of the island will be covered by the new national park. All of the areas identified by the independent consultant as habitats of national or international significance and areas of high landscape value are included in the new national park. A number of areas that were subsequently identified by, I think, officers of the National Parks and Wildlife Service were included as well. Senator Vallentine has my assurance that the vast majority of the remaining rainforest on Christmas Island will be included in the national park.

ANSWER.PARA: The areas that are not included in the national park are the urban area and two other small areas which are non-urban. These are excluded because they are areas on which it is expected future development will occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to put a casino there?

—The area of the casino will not be part of the area of the national park either. The tourist development in these areas, when it does take place-I hope it is a question of when and not if-will be subject to the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Agreement has been reached between my Department and the National Parks and Wildlife Service on the use of funds for rehabilitation works. The establishment of a forestry nursery and subsequent rehabilitation work will begin in earnest in the very near future. The lease under the Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance for the nursery site is currently being finalised, and the first payment from the $500,000 has already been made to the National Parks and Wildlife Service for preliminary site works.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vallentine asked also about the $30,000 for soil conservation. It is not the fault of the Department of the Arts and Territories-in any event it is not a question of blame-but the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has informed us that the purposes for which we were seeking to use the $30,000 was in fact outside the terms of the grant. We are conducting some negotiations with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to try to clear that matter up. Those negotiations are currently in train.

Because of the timing of the recommencement of the mining, which is likely to be very early next year, it is obviously not going to be possible to have in place, as we would like to have done, a management plan prior to that recommencement of mining or, indeed, the establishment of the new scientific research centre. Nonetheless, very strict controls have already been placed on the commencement of mining. As Senator Vallentine would be aware, there is in place on Christmas Island a full time conservator from the National Parks and Wildlife Service. The National Parks and Wildlife Service will make sure that mining is closely monitored, that there is no further clearing of rainforests and that no areas outside the leases will be affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the October current account deficit of $1.685 billion, the effect of which was to increase our foreign debt during that month at the rate of $56m a day. I ask: Can the Minister advise the major cause or causes of Australia's continuing balance of payments crisis? Is the Government reviewing its economic strategy to consider what it might do to rectify this ongoing disaster? What does the Minister believe the Government can or should do to address this problem?

—I do not think that any Minister has claimed that the rectification of the Australian international debt problem or a significant improvement in the current account deficit would be achieved in any brief space of time. Perhaps the best known public articulation of anticipations regarding that was made by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) in a paper released, I think, last year. EPAC said in that paper that, given a number of assumptions, it felt that the international debt position would stabilise by the early 1990s.
—Can you comment on the assumptions?

—I cannot comment on the assumptions, but they were about dollar values, commodity prices and things of that kind. Nonetheless, I think that the assumptions were couched on a range of possibilities. The study is probably still accepted as being pretty accurate. The reasons for the monthly figure just published were the subject of considerable comment at the time. The basic problem, as it has been in the last few months, is that there has been significant and strong growth in imports and a stabilisation at least of export values. The strong growth in imports has arisen very much from high levels of capital investment in Australia, which Senator Walsh has commented on in the course of answering questions directed to him earlier in Question Time today. I guess the most important longer term answer is to improve a diversified base of export activity and import replacement. That involves restructuring and will take time. The Government has never said anything else but that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I take it from the Minister's reply that he does not support the quite ludicrous proposition advanced by the Treasurer in explaining away this shocking trade result; namely, that we are experiencing a manufacturing boom. I take it that the Minister, sensibly, does not endorse the Treasurer's assertion because he, probably unlike the Treasurer, is aware that in the main area which would be affected by any alleged manufacturing boom-that is, machinery imports-there has been hardly any change over recent months.

—As I recall it, when the Treasurer referred to the strong growth of the capital goods element in imports, he made the point that it was basically because the economy was sound that that was happening. That follows from high levels of investment.
—Do you agree with him?

—Certainly, I agree in terms of high levels of investment in manufacturing. If that is what the Treasurer was saying-I do not recall precisely what he was referring to-I agree that the levels of investment in manufacturing are significant. They are particularly significant because the pattern of manufacturing investment has changed over the last few years. Both here and elsewhere much less manufacturing investment is taking place, for example, in greenfield sites, as it used to do, and in enormous plants and so on. A lot of manufacturing investment is directed towards smaller and more sophisticated pieces of equipment which make business and manufacturing plant work smarter, rather than the very large plants which we were used to in years gone by.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question on defence housing at Enoggera Army barracks. It is true that there are some houses of poor standard in Bliss and Taurama streets, Enoggera, about which there was a report in the Brisbane media. Almost all of those houses have some problems. They are of immediate post-war prefabricated construction, are not capable of rehabilitation in any economically viable way, and need to be replaced with new housing. I am pleased to report that the linoleum floor coverings in the houses are being replaced progressively and that the ceilings were not sagging; rather, material covering the joins in plaster sheeting was missing. New timber cover strips are being installed. Pest control measures have been taken where necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that all honourable senators will appreciate that the Defence Housing Authority is not able to replace all the substandard defence housing at once. These are problems that have been accumulating for 30 years. However, the Authority has already commenced replacement programs in many areas. For example, over 300 replacement houses were purchased in a special acquisitions program in the last quarter of 1987-88 and it is planned that a further 1,079 replacement houses will be provided by the Authority this year. There is a portion of the Brisbane media's report to which Senator Bjelke-Petersen did not refer. It quotes a member of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses working party, which inspected the Enoggera houses, as saying that the figure of 98 per cent `did not give a balanced view of the housing situation because only a small number of houses were inspected'. She went on to say that the Authority was working to eradicate poor housing conditions as funds became available and that members of that working party were pleased to have the opportunity to work with the Authority so that jobs could be prioritised. She also said:

The Enoggera houses inspected represented a few poor examples of service homes but the Defence Housing Authority is working to get people out of the bad ones as soon as better houses become available.
That is clear evidence that the Defence Housing Authority is not only getting on with its charter but is doing that in close consultation with its tenants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time today Senator Glen Sheil asked me a two-part question on doctor provider numbers. I am now in a position to answer that question. At present, the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health releases doctors' provider numbers to government departments, statutory authorities and private organisations in order for those organisations to establish the bona fides of medical practitioners so that Medicare benefits can be paid; to identify medical practitioners so that gap benefits can be claimed from registered health benefits organisations for medical services rendered on a day of hospitalisation; and to establish the bona fides of providers of medical services associated with claims for Commonwealth and private workers compensation.

ANSWER.PARA: The release of this information is made in accordance with the secrecy provisions of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act. These provisions place a mandatory obligation on persons to whom information is released to be bound by the same rights, privileges, obligations and liabilities as persons performing duties under the Act. The further release by those persons of that information attracts the penal sanctions contained in subsection 130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act.

The answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question is that, while there is no legislative requirement to do so, the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health obtains a written undertaking from the organisations concerned that they will abide by the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is a very important document because it deals with proposals for reform of the current Commonwealth Government purchasing system. That government purchasing takes place on a truly monumental scale. The report points out that in the 1986-87 Budget explanatory notes it was estimated that annual Commonwealth Budget expenditure on goods and services was about $8 billion. Some 3,500 people are employed in purchasing and related activities. Therefore, as the report points out, purchasing is a significant activity and plays a key role in supporting government programs. It is also of great significance because an enormous amount of taxpayers' money goes into government purchases. Indeed, all government purchases are funded one way or another from taxpayers' money. As we have seen through our pursuit of these issues in Estimates committees and other forums in this Parliament over recent years, the amount of waste in government expenditure is equally monumental.

This is a very important paper. It is also very odd; for example, it has no acknowledged author. There is no explanation of why it has been written, who commissioned it, prepared it or, indeed, where it came from. I would have thought that at the very least the authors of the report should have acknowledged their authorship and the terms of reference that they were given. I presume that it is the review report on tendering and purchasing promised in the Estimates committee for the Department of Administrative Services well over a year ago.

Although I welcome any report which investigates the process of government purchasing, the first question that has to be asked is: why has this taken so long? It is a follow-up, to some extent, of promises initially made by the Hawke Government when it came to office 5 1/2 years ago. The other point I wish to make is that, if the report were going to be tabled today, why was it not prepared in time for the Estimates committee hearings a few weeks ago? That would have given the Parliament the opportunity to question some of the very important points made in the report.

The proposed changes that are outlined to government purchasing policy and practices in the report are significant. They are also very interesting. They include the strategy to improve purchasing performance through a professional approach involving better practice and techniques and well-trained staff; the recognition of value for money as the prime purchasing objective and adoption of a principle of open and effective competition as a guide in determining purchasing methods; the removal of central regulatory control of detailed purchasing processes and procedures, leaving them to be decided by management; and the provision of a centrally provided policy framework and best practice guidelines.

In the limited time I had to examine the report, I found that it involves a less regulatory and more decentralised approach to government purchasing. That is important and a step in the right direction but it raises some very important further issues. For example, if we were to decentralise purchasing how would we be able to maintain the principles of probity, fairness and opportunity to compete for Commonwealth business, which principles are quite fundamental to the whole area of government purchasing and the proper accounting of the use of taxpayers' money? It also raises the whole question of how we are going to train skilled purchasing officers in the various government departments and so on.

The final point I want to make in the time available is that, whilst I welcome the report, I question very much whether it is going far enough fast enough. It has taken a long time to eventuate. At the end of the day it does not tackle the fundamental problem that it really ought to tackle-that is, how is this Government going to get under control the enormous escalation of total government expenditure that has so dominated its period of office and has caused the fundamental problems that have beset the economy, particularly the enormous blow-out in the early years of the Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of things about the report entitled Proposals for Reform of Commonwealth Government Purchasing Arising from Government Review under the Financial Management Improvement Program. I agree with Senator Short that it has some valuable suggestions to make in an area where I am sure there are considerable public savings to be made. The recommendations are not recommendations which have been considered in detail by the Opposition. There has not been an opportunity to do that since the paper was tabled only today.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that some of the recommendations reflect policies already announced by the Opposition. I welcome that fact. The review concludes that the Commonwealth has relied too heavily on the use of detailed technical specifications and endorses the greater use of functional specifications or performance specifications. This is specifically in line with coalition policy and therefore I welcome it.

The review also recommends enhanced requirements regarding public visibility and accountability, an emphasis on flexibility and management for results and generally a more competitive value for money approach. I might say that they are all the right words. I merely draw attention to the fact that translating those words into procedures which will work may be rather more difficult. I have no doubt that the Government will need to direct its attention to meeting the suggestion in the report that, given that there will be greater local discretion, there will be a need for a different sort of control if we are to avoid the risk of abuse of purchasing procedures.

Page 11 of the report says that a code of ethics will be promulgated to give guidance on expected standards of honesty and behaviour. I would agree with the implication from that that any system of purchasing does require a high ethical standard on the part of the persons who are actually doing the purchasing on behalf of the Commonwealth. I remind the Senate that we are talking about $8 billion worth of expenditure here. We are not talking about small change for taxpayers. We are talking about very large contributions, payments which are well in excess of the annual cost of the old age pension. Obviously, there will be an interest on the part of the Opposition to see what code of ethics will be promulgated. We will also be interested to see what these enhanced requirements regarding public visibility and accountability involve. I simply draw to the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, that we would be anxious to see a further statement from the Government and a further opening up to debate of these issues by the publication at the earliest possible time of both the code of ethics and the enhanced requirements regarding public visibility and accountability.

The review was not undertaken from the industry policy viewpoint, although we are advised in the report that industry was consulted and that no disadvantage to local industry is anticipated from implementation of the proposed reform. The fact is that the new simplified procedures which give purchasing officers a much greater degree of discretion could be open to abuse. I acknowledge that the current very rigid procedures can also be manipulated if that is something that a purchasing officer might want to do, for example, through changes to tender specifications.

On the face of this report it appears that the new procedures offer scope for cost savings and benefits to industry through greater flexibility in competition. But I ask the Government to bear in mind the need to ensure that there is this public visibility and accountability and to ensure that the new rules which will be needed actually to put these proposals into operation are made available to us at the earliest possible time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

There is, as always, in the annual report of the Department of Community Services and Health a great deal that one could comment on. However, I will restrict my remarks to chapter 5, which deals with the program of assistance for people with disabilities. Specifically, I want to address my remarks to the attendant care scheme. We are informed in the report that during 1987-88 a total of 64 people with disabilities were assisted under the attendant care scheme. The scheme started in April 1987 with a budget of $11m over three years to assist up to 360 severely physically disabled people to move from nursing homes into community accommodation through the provision of personal care services.

I was recently visited by a group of people from the Attendant Care Coalition in my home State of Victoria who expressed to me considerable concern about the operations of the attendant care program from a number of points of view. Most specifically, these related to the limitations that are part of the scheme at the moment. It is very difficult to qualify for attendant care. One has to have been in nursing home care for a period longer than six months. One of the people who came to see me, Mary Reid, has relatively recently been able to get onto the attendant care program after a long period in a nursing home. Another person there was a school teacher who relatively recently had had an accident. Through the attendant care program he is able to remain in his own home and maintain normal family relationships with his wife and two young children and perhaps, even more importantly, return to his school as vice-principal and to make a major contribution in the community. It does seem very much to me that it would be in all our interests and in the interests of government, which has to pay for these things, to broaden the scope of a scheme such as the attendant care scheme. It needs to be seen as an integral part of our support for people with disabilities, particularly in the area of income security.

I return to Cliff Wise, the school teacher I have referred to. Looking at the actual figures involved, because he is now back in productive work and because his wife has not had to stay at home and look after him full time, as she might have had to do under different circumstances, she is able to make an economic contribution as well. Indeed, figures supplied to me show that the net cost of attendant care in this case would be $16,945. The unemployment benefit that would have had to be paid to him if he were not able to be employed would be $5,500 plus associated benefits. All up, the cost per person would be under $11,000. In this case we have two productive members of the community in work paying taxes far above what the cost to the community and to the Government would be.

There are problems with this scheme. One thing that I think needs to be borne in mind is that it is a three-year trial. The trial period is coming to its last year and yet it really has not had a fair trial in the view of those people who should know best-the disabled in the community-because of the restrictions that have been placed on it. It has been put to me, and I have put it to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) today by way of questions that the criteria should be extended to include people who are currently in rehabilitation or acute care and people who are at risk of being institutionalised in order to get them into attendant care before they become institutionalised. The criteria should also include those who are currently living with family or friends so that they and their family or friends need not be dependent and can be economically viable. People currently living in other institutional settings other than in nursing homes-for instance, people in hostels-would be more easily rehabilitated and more easily able to take up this scheme. The hours need to be extended as well. Too short a period is available under the program. I urge the Government to look seriously at extending the program's range and depth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Department of Community Services and Health annual report. Like other senators in the chamber, I am unable to comment on all aspects of the report in the time available since it covers such a wide area.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to talk about two areas: one is in chapter two, the health advancement program and the other is in chapter four, the residential care for older people program. In chapter two we read about drug abuse reduction. The report states:

More than $3.7 million for drug education programs and over $9.91 million for treatment and rehabilitation activities in States and Territories was provided by the Commonwealth under the cost-shared program with the States.
Twenty pilot tests of innovative approaches to drug abuse prevention were funded.

I do not know whether in those statements the report is referring to $50,000 per annum that has been given by the Commonwealth, which was announced in a press release, to university medical schools to develop drug programs for medical students to teach them about drug abuse and educate them in drug rehabilitation. It was of concern to me when I read about this, since it seemed excessive to give $50,000 to a medical school for this project when, I thought, given my experience in tertiary institutions, maybe those people could also have been asked to develop programs in drug rehabilitation and education for psychologists, nurses, and teachers in Diploma of Education and other areas. It did seem to me that it was a rather narrow view of who should be educated about drug rehabilitation and abuse. I hope the Department will look at that matter and review the spending of that money and maybe have some expectation after the implementation in this first year that in the second and subsequent years that money is also shared across other faculties and departments in order to spread the value of that project around.

I would like to comment about the residential care for older people program and to look specifically at chapter four. I express my concern about the fact that all the developments that have taken place in the review of care for the aged over the last two years I believe have neglected the elderly. One can see as one looks through chapter four that again the summary of what has happened over the past year emphasises this fact. On page 27, under the assessment section, the report states:
The objective of this subprogram is to ensure that aged people who seek residential care gain access to the most appropriate available services.

That might be applicable if a person lives close to the appropriate available services; that is, approved nursing homes. But if a person happens to live in a rural area in Victoria near a Bush Nursing hospital which is not an approved service for the elderly, if there is not private medical care-as we know private health insurance is not able to sustain people in long term care and is withdrawing its support for elderly people in these areas-then, in fact, the objective is not being met. I ask the Department, the people in this area and the Government to reassess and redirect their energies to ensure that some flexibility is brought into the system so that the needs of elderly people who require nursing home type accommodation are met. I do not think they are being met and I think that this matter needs to be addressed.

The other thing that concerns me in the report is the geriatric assessment program. We have had numerous complaints from nursing home proprietors. They are not all vexatious, they are genuine complaints where someone has made an error in assessment and has changed the status of an elderly person because he has had a stroke and has suddenly become more dependent and he cannot be reassessed for a year. This applies to people who also come from other nursing homes. I believe that the Department needs to address some of the problems that are associated with assessment. There are a number of other issues which I would like to address. I may have the opportunity to do so later. They are issues about categories and exempt bed arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to comment on the annual report of the Department of Community Services and Health. This is the first report of the Department in its new revamped form. It was restructured on instructions from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 24 July 1987. The report covers a wide range of activities of community service programs. I, too, like Senator Powell, would like to comment on chapter five, the assistance for people with disabilities program. However, my comments will not be in the attendant care area but will deal more with the question of supported employment, or sheltered workshops as we used to call them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to be the first to admit that the Government, in changing the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 to the Disability Services Act 1986, has attempted to perhaps bring more disabled people into the work force or into the community and give them the support that they need. However, there are some areas, I believe, where this is not occurring in the most efficient way and I do not believe that it is occurring in the best interests of the people involved or in the best interests of the community at large. It is rather unfortunate that, in practice, it does not seem to be working. The transition programs dealing with supported employment, referred to in the report, comment on this. A previous Minister for Community Services who dealt with this matter, Senator Grimes, made the statement that when the transition programs commenced and the new Disability Services Act of 1986 came into being, nobody would be worse off; everybody would be better off. My experience, short as it has been, in dealing with people in sheltered workshops and talking to people who are involved with them indicates that they too would echo the fact that they are worse off, and it is not really a question of the Government being lousy with funds. It has increased funding to a reasonable level. What is happening in the transition program, with the Government's idea of trying to bring more people out into the open community from their sheltered or protected employment schemes, is that for every person or every two or three persons taken out of the sheltered workshop environment one has to provide minders or supporters to accompany them, thereby increasing the cost.

At the same time, in the particular schemes those persons were involved in, they would have been at the highest end of the people able to cope and to show some leadership in those areas. From my experience of talking to them and observing them, they would probably have a supervisory role in a sheltered workshop scheme. By taking them out of the scheme the Government not only disadvantages the scheme but it leaves a gap or two in the workshop, which means that someone from outside has to be employed to take over that position. Then on the other side one has to provide supporters for the disabled or mentally disabled people who are moving out into the community. All these people have to be funded, and unfortunately the funding is coming out of the same pool that the sheltered workshops or supported employment schemes are being funded by. So instead of being better off, they are worse off; so much so that last year very little money was available for new plant and maintenance, and a lot of these schemes are in jeopardy because they do not have the funds to maintain their equipment and to buy new equipment to ensure that these small industries are viable and remain so.
