DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: First Biennial Report by the Australian Institute of Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is a useful report because of the large amount of statistical data which it provides in relation to Australia's health. However, it is a flawed report because of the extent to which-for reasons which are obviously political-it opens with a fairly detailed discussion of the past history of Australia's health policy in what I regard to be a highly contentious, highly political, highly inaccurate and quite improper fashion. The comments go well beyond what any statutory authority such as this should. On page 7 of the report it says:

As a result of opposition from private health insurance funds and the medical profession, a Liberal-Country Party coalition Government elected in 1975 made a number of changes to Medibank over the next six years.

The report then goes on to discuss these and other matters. Madam Acting Deputy President, that is simply a grossly inaccurate, improper, political statement which implies that the changes made in the Medibank arrangements by the Government which was elected in 1975 were made as a result of pressures from private health insurance funds and the medical profession. That is a political statement. It is not a statement which an institution such as the Australian Institute of Health-a statutory body-is entitled to make in a report which is supposed to deal with Australia's health statistics. I object most strongly to the editorialising which has taken place in the opening chapter of this report and I remind the authors of the report that they will certainly not continue to receive bipartisan political support for the work of the Institute if they are going to take upon themselves the making of partisan and party political statements by way of analysis of Australia's health policy.

A great deal could be said about this report, but I draw attention only to a couple of things which I think are objectionable. The first is the description of the AIDS epidemic on page 9, which is described simply as `incurable AIDS'. That may be an accurate reflection of the current prognosis, but what this report ought to say is that AIDS is a disease for which, at the moment, no cure is available. `incurable AIDS' is not a recognised disease. One hopes and prays that there will be a cure for AIDS. I think it is most misleading for the report to make this assertion which implies AIDS will always be incurable.
The report also refers to a number of relationships between health care and other community policies. For instance, on page 103 it says:
Governments could have their greatest impact on health by reducing socioeconomic disadvantage through programs that reduce unemployment and improve social security and community support services.

As we heard today from the speech just concluded by Senator Calvert, one of the things this Government is doing is cutting back on the effectiveness of some of those community support services. In terms of its record as far as poverty is concerned I make the point that while the Hawke Government has been in office the number of children living in poverty has dramatically increased. If this report were to be accurate and even-handed in making its political comments about health policy, it would have drawn attention to that rather than simply seeking to criticise one side of the political debate on health policy.

I find it somewhat confusing to be told in some parts of the report that some of the diseases resulting from unhealthy lifestyles have decreased, without having properly drawn to my attention at the same time the ongoing problem of disease or death resulting from increasing tobacco consumption. I find it somewhat misleading to look at the statistics on the significantly increasing cost of outpatient treatment without any attempt to indicate that this is one of the necessary consequences of the Government's Medicare policies, which are elsewhere in the report praised as having some alleged value in terms of social equity. I do not wish to continue at great length, because I propose to speak at some other time on this report. I simply make the point that the health statistics in this document are valuable and important. The political editorial comment with which the report is shot through is a disgrace and something to which the Opposition objects very strongly.

—Could I say one word and then seek leave to continue my remarks?
—If the senator seeks leave, we will grant it.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Foreman I present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Canberra Leasehold System, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to have the tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

In April this year the Senate referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for inquiry and report Professor Max Neutze's paper entitled The Canberra Leasehold System. The paper had been commissioned in 1987 by the former Joint Committee on the ACT in response to a growing perception that the administrators of the leasehold system were not using the strengths of the system effectively to ensure balanced, harmonious redevelopment of Canberra particularly in Civic.

The House of Representatives also referred to its Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, a reference covering all aspects of the ACT leasehold system including consideration and use of Professor Neutze's paper.

The resolutions referring the matter to the respective Standing Committees also empowered the Committees to sit as a Joint Sub-Committee to consider the ACT leasehold system. This report was prepared by the Joint Sub-Committee.

The report, which includes a minority report, looks at the establishment and functions of the leasehold system, including reasons for leasehold, the concept of leasehold and functions of leasehold tenure, as well as leases and lease ordinances and benefits of the leasehold system.

Issues which the Joint Sub-Committee addressed cover a range of specific aspects of the leasehold system such as length of lease, responsibility for planning and estate management, role of lease administration in redevelopment, effects of plans on planning and development authorities and private sector involvement.

An area in which concern was expressed to the Joint Sub-Committee was in the administration of the leasehold system. There was concern with the way the Administration carried out its ground landlord role. Several areas where administrative reform is needed have been identified in Chapter 4. These include amendments to lease purpose clauses, betterment, breach of purpose clauses, ordinance simplification and consolidation and development rights.

In the final chapter the Joint Sub-Committee addressed the question of public participation. Public participation is the essence of the political process and it is necessary and vital to the effective functioning of Canberra's leasehold system of land tenure. There are three areas where public participation, openness and accountability can be enhanced in the operation of the leasehold system of land tenure. These are public participation in planning decisions, section 11a City Area Leases Ordinance and Section 17 City Area Leases Ordinance and Section 72a Real Property Ordinance.

The Committee has made 18 recommendations. In recommendation 1 the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth retain ownership of land in the ACT. Section 125 of the Constitution states in part, and I quote:

The seat of Government of the Commonwealth shall be determined by the Parliament, and shall be within territory which shall have been granted to or acquired by the Commonwealth, and shall be vested in and belong to the Commonwealth. . . .

The majority of the Committee recognise that Canberra land is both a national heritage to be safeguarded and used for the benefit of the nation and also of vital importance to residents and that the leasehold system provides an effective means of reconciling these qualities.

Leasehold has provided a structure for planned, orderly and predictable development, and has prevented speculation. It has ensured certainty and lessees know they have an enforceable contract in which rights and obligations are clear. It is also clear from the rate of development and redevelopment that the claim by a few large developers that the leasehold system has been a disincentive to investors is nonsense.
In recommendation 2 the Committee affirms the view that the leasehold system of property tenure provides an effective basis for land planning and management in the ACT and that it should be retained.

The majority of the Committee believes that the system of public ownership of land with leasehold tenure has the capability to continue to serve the needs of the ACT at both the national and territorial level. However, there are weaknesses and deficiencies with the administration of the leasehold tenure system which has allowed Canberra land to be treated as the property of lessees. These areas are identified in Chapter 4 and recommendations 9 to 13 address these administrative weaknesses and deficiencies. Not only has the Committee made recommendations which address administrative deficiencies but the Committee has also made recommendations on specific aspects of the leasehold system such as length of lease, responsibility for planning and estate management, role of lease administration and redevelopment, adherence to approved policy and development plans and private sector involvement.

One area which directly touches most residents of Canberra is residential leases. The Committee was aware of the special consideration which residential leases merit. The desire to hand down one's home and property from one generation to the next is a feature of the Australian sentiment and culture. Residential leases in Canberra are granted for 99 years and at present these leases will be renewed at the end of their term without the payment of a further premium. Although renewal of residential leases has been taking place there is no legislation to give effect to this. By amending the City Area Leases Ordinance (CALO) to incorporate a statutory right of renewal of residential leases, residential lessees would have the security of knowing that their leases will be renewed.

Thus the majority of the Committee has recommended that the City Area Leases Ordinance be amended to provide for the automatic renewal of residential leases at the end of 99 years without further charge.

The Committee's recommendation approximates residential leases in perpetuity but the lease purpose clause still controls land use, and development rights are still clearly retained by the Commonwealth.

There has been an ongoing argument that leases should be converted to leases in perpetuity. One of the difficulties with perpetual leasehold is that it is fraught with contractual problems. The proposal for leases in perpetuity has been pressed by those concerned about the attractiveness of Canberra for investment purposes. However it is quite clear that the leasehold system has not been a disincentive to investment as some people have argued. The value of the leasehold system for developers is reflected in a statement made by the founder and then Managing Director of Lend Lease Corporation, Mr Dusseldorp. He said and I quote:

As to the principle when they put it up for auction, not only did every bidder know exactly what he could and could not do with his particular site, but he also knew what everyone else-the other eleven owners in that particular city block-could and could not do. So that one doesn't have to fear as to what is going to happen next door to him, what is going to happen in front of him.

The majority of the Committee has recommended that leases should be for a term of years rather than in perpetuity. Residential leases should be for 99 years. Non-residential leases should be for 99 years or for shorter periods and their renewal should be at the discretion of, and on terms negotiated with, the ground landlord, and will include the payment of a further premium.
Four of the Committee's recommendations address public participation in planning decisions, public notification of changes to lease purpose and public information.

There has been a lack of co-ordination and consultation between the planning and estate administration authorities. The Committee sounds a warning that in the planning and development of Canberra, it must not be forgotten that Canberra is a national heritage to be safeguarded for all Australians. This is one of the major reasons why the majority of the Committee recommend the retention of the leasehold system of land tenure.

I take this opportunity to thank all those who contributed to the inquiry through submissions, to Professor Neutze for his invaluable paper and to the Secretary and staff of the Joint Sub-Committee Secretariat.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly wish to direct attention to my minority report in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) leasehold system, which is contained on pages 75 to 78 of the report. I make the point that property rights provide a strong basis for the protection of liberty. They are therefore important in maintaining a strong democracy, quite apart from being fundamental to the operation of a private enterprise economic system, which even the Australian Labor Party appears to have embraced.
—Ask Geopeko about that. It had property rights in Kakadu National Park and the Government unilaterally took them away, after 12 years, without compensation.

—Well, I guess from time to time the Labor Party wants to create the perception of having embraced a private enterprise economic system. Certainly, with the notable exception of the labour market, which matter the Government has put in the too hard basket, Australia has moved towards a deregulated economic environment. This country is now exposed to the competitive winds of rational investment. Canberra, above all, can ill afford to be isolated by a tenure system that will severely impede its ability to attract and maintain long-term acceptable investment. Yet, the majority report of the Committee on the ACT leasehold system, tabled today, seeks to do precisely that. It flies in the face of economic as well as social reality. There is no reasoned view why residents of the ACT should be refused freehold or perpetual leasehold-a right enjoyed by other Australians. For these reasons, I have presented a minority report.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the existing leasehold system the Government in Canberra acts as both ground landlord and the planning authority, presumably to ensure the efficient and orderly development of the city. Public ownership of the site of Canberra and leasehold tenure for both business and residential use, were adopted some 80 years ago to ensure `orderly development of the city in line with the adopted plan and to avoid scattered development and land speculation'. But what about Government speculation? This is obvious everywhere if one drives through Canberra's inner city. One sees sites reserved for future use-when the value has risen handsomely. A fine cop.

This kind of `orderly development'-as Professor Max Neutze, author of the report commissioned by the then Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, would have us believe-is sitting on resources which would otherwise be fruitfully used. It is, at least in the short term, severely reducing potential government revenue. It also escalates costs associated with other developments in outer areas of Canberra.

Freehold tenure is a key element of our social and economic structure-part of our national ethos. The idea of land tenure based on the principle of freehold has been widely accepted, in particular, for residential property. Indeed, current figures confirm that about 69 per cent of Australians either own or are in the process of buying their own home. This is a broad acceptance that freehold ownership gives greater security of tenure. In fact, the ACT has about 68 per cent home ownership, the second lowest among all the States and Territories.

Even that great advocate of fixed term leasehold, to whom I referred earlier, Professor Max Neutze, upon whose advice the majority report tabled today is largely based, has acknowledged Australians' preference for a freehold system. In a paper delivered in 1986 entitled `Planning and Land Tenure in Canberra after Sixty Years', he said:

Australians have never understood or, to the extent they have understood, have never supported a leasehold system. It seems certain that if they ever did understand it, very few still understood and supported it by 1970. The fact that as early as the late twenties there were successful efforts to get purpose clauses and other terms of leases varied suggests that few people believed in one of the fundamental aspects of leasehold: that it is the role of the ground landlord to determine the purpose for which a lease can be used and that the lessee has to conform to that purpose or renegotiate the lease.

One of the major concerns with the majority report is its recommendation relating to lease length. It claims leases should be for a set term, rather than in perpetuity, that is, residential leases should be for 99 years, with provision for renewal for a further 99 years, while business leases should also normally be for 99 years. If this is to be the case, why not have a freehold system or at least perpetual leasehold? After all, the reasons for limited leasehold tenure being introduced were to prevent speculation in land resulting from the siting of the national capital. It also enabled the Government to defray the costs of establishing and maintaining the capital through revenue derived from land rents and to distribute profits made from the increase in the value of land throughout the community.

The abolition of land rent and the emergence of a more developed city are two major changes which have made this reasoning redundant. Justice Else-Mitchell's inquiry into land tenure reported in 1976:
Residential land in the ACT should be held under perpetual leases . . .

It is claimed that fixed term leases allow the government to encourage redevelopment by precipitating a land-use change at lease expiry. On the contrary, such a system hinders potential redevelopment in the last 20 or 30 years of a lease period by creating uncertainty about future tenure and therefore the value of current sites. Redevelopment is a response to market force, not lease term, and will be most encouraged by the certainty of tenure which freehold or perpetual leasehold provides. If one looks closely at the leasehold system, one sees that the underpinning theme is one of the facilitation of planning. Elsewhere in Australia, planning is supported by a wide variety of statutory planning systems at both the State and local government level. It seems that there are some individuals amongst us who regard the private sector to be the bete noir, to be nothing more than a huge impediment to the administration of land for the public good. The view that limited leasehold facilitates planning and estate management gives absolutely no consideration to how those functions can be as efficiently performed through the familiar statutory planning systems of the rest of Australia.

Land utilisation in Canberra and the ACT should be of national concern, but self-government combined with the role played by the Commonwealth Parliament should be sufficient to ensure that both the local and the national interests are fully considered. The argument that a leasehold should be set to a period of 99 years is completely nonsensical. Why not five, 10, 15 or 20? This reinforces a far more practical view that a statutory planning system coupled with freehold or perpetual leasehold makes good sense. Perpetual leasehold would enable easier administration than the present system, would not weaken the planning function of the lease purpose clause and would permit unearned value increments to be recouped when changes in lease purpose occur. It would also make the leasehold system more acceptable to the business community.

Business leases should in fact not be treated any differently from residential leasehold. The argument that business or commercial leases should reflect the expected life span of most buildings ignores the fact that elsewhere planning permission from local government is always required for redevelopment of commercial property to ensure the redevelopment is consistent with community aspirations. If private enterprise is to play a greater role in the development of Canberra, which it must, given that more private sector employment in Canberra is a major socioeconomic goal, its role in decisions concerning that development must be allowed to broaden. When compared with its role in other Australian cities, the private sector's role in Canberra has always been restricted. Private sector involvement in the ACT has been limited to the implementation of much of the National Capital Development Commission's program in design and contract documentation and by carrying out all works; the provision of local services and facilities by private contractors and investors; and the establishment of commercial enterprises directed at the `export' market.

The following four arguments support a change to freehold or at least perpetual leasehold: First, lease renewal as the primary planning tool provides fragmented redevelopment because leases may expire at different times. Secondly, heritage listings interfere with redevelopment on lease expiry and in effect provide for perpetual leasehold. Thirdly, interstate investors may well be more attracted to privately developed land under a freehold or perpetual leasehold system. Fourthly, the limited leasehold system requires more administration than is necessary because all property has to undergo a process of review for the purposes of lease renewal, regardless of whether there is any redevelopment or change in land use proposal.

The only obstacle preventing adoption of the freehold system may be a constitutional one, for it is a fact that Commonwealth interests in the national capital are well protected by the Constitution. Section 125 of the Constitution provides:

The seat of Government of the Commonwealth shall be determined by the Parliament, and shall be within territory which shall have been granted to or acquired by the Commonwealth, and shall be vested in and belong to the Commonwealth . . .

It is possible that this may be interpreted so as to prevent freeholding of land in Canberra. But it certainly would not prevent the perpetual leasehold option. Eighty years ago there may have been good reason why the Government of the day indulged in public ownership, and why the limited leasehold system of land tenure conferred great planning advantages on a growing city. Today, however, as this nation approaches the twenty-first century, there is no legitimate reason for an ideological commitment to state control of land. Particularly, as a Liberal, it is anathema to me. Since the Australian dream of home ownership has been realised by about 70 per cent of this country's population, it seems an absurd situation that those Australians who happen to live in the ACT, and not in Victoria or New South Wales, or anywhere else, should be denied the aspiration of either full freehold ownership or effective freehold in the form of perpetual lease, if the Constitution prevents full freehold. I therefore commend my minority report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Puplick) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I table the report entitled Is this where I pay the electricity bill?, being the report of the Committee's inquiry into the Efficiency Scrutiny Report into Regionalisation within the Australian Electoral Commission. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard some remarks about the report.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

This is the second Report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The Report is concerned with the organisational structure of the Australian Electoral Commission and in particular, whether the Commission should continue to have 148 Divisional Offices. The Report is of vital interest to all Members of the Federal Parliament and indeed all voters.

The Report details the Committee's findings from its Inquiry into a 1987 Efficiency Scrutiny of the Divisional structure of the Electoral Commission. The Scrutiny was conducted by Dianne Saunders, the Deputy Electoral Officer for Victoria, and recommended that up to seven Divisional Offices be amalgamated to form Regional Offices to reduce costs and allow office computerisation to take place.

The Committee's Report is called `Is this where I pay the electricity bill?'. This title may seem a little strange but I shall explain its origin. During the Inquiry the Efficiency Scrutineer, Dianne Saunders, told the Committee: ``If you go around the divisional offices to talk to staff about something, it is most unusual for somebody to come into the office. They are often there to pay the electricity bill anyway-they have mistaken us for the electricity commission. In fact, we had the official opening of the new office for the division of McEwen when the new division was set up, and we were all there with Lady McEwen and various members to have the official opening ceremony, and a gentleman walked in saying, `Is this where I pay the electricity bill?'!''
This anecdote typifies the difficulty that many Australians have in understanding the role of the Electoral Commission.

Submissions and evidence received by the Committee have shown there to be clear differences of opinion between the Electoral Commission, the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association (the ACOA), Divisional Returning Officers (DROs) and others as to the best organisational structure for the Electoral Commission. While the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes, and other senior staff of the Commission have argued strongly in favour of regionalising the Commission's Divisional Offices, most of the submissions and evidence received by the Committee have argued for a continuation of the status quo.

In its Inquiry the Committee has considered a number of important issues. The issue of computers in the Electoral Commission has been of particular concern and the Committee has found there to be an urgent need for the Electoral Commission to make better use of modern computer systems. The Committee believes it is a serious deficiency in the Commission that its existing computer systems cannot cope with all the demands placed upon them and that some systems such as finance and personnel systems are not computerised.

The Committee has concluded that as a matter of priority the Australian Electoral Commission must pursue the acquisition of modern computer equipment and the Committee has made two recommendations in this area.

First, the Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission seek independent external advice on the computer equipment and systems needed in the Commission's offices which would enable the Commission to best achieve its goals.

Secondly, the Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission adopt a more determined approach in seeking funds from the Government for the purpose of acquiring the modern computer equipment and systems it needs.

However, the Committee's major recommendations relate to the organisation of the Commission's Divisional Offices. In reaching its conclusions and recommendations on regionalisation the Committee has sought to consider broad issues rather than examine electorates on a case by case basis.
The ACOA, DROs and some parliamentarians argued that having an Electoral Commission Office in each Division provided a more convenient service to electors and ensured DROs had better local knowledge.

The Committee believes that in some, but not all cases, DROs have developed extensive local knowledge under the existing Divisional Office structure. However, a Regional Office structure should not preclude staff from gaining local knowledge.

The Committee understands from evidence received during its Inquiry that in most Divisional Offices, no more than 15 electors visit the Office during a typical week and that most enquiries are dealt with by phone or by mail.

The Committee concluded that regionalisation of up to three Divisional Offices in metropolitan areas would not seriously affect roll maintenance, election management or service to electors because of the transport and communications services which are available in these areas. However, the Committee concluded that regionalisation should not proceed in rural areas because of the distances involved and the resulting transport and communications barriers which would affect service to electors and election management.
While the Committee has been presented with different regionalisation schemes it has had no desire to draft specific proposals for the regionalisation of metropolitan offices.

The Committee believes the task of formulating a final regionalisation scheme to be the responsibility of the Australian Electoral Commission and the Government. However, the Committee may wish to comment on the Electoral Commission's proposal for regionalisation.

The Committee has therefore recommended that regionalisation of the Australian Electoral Commission's Divisional Offices only occur in metropolitan areas. The Regional Offices should be formed by the combination of up to three Divisional Offices. The Committee recommends that senior staff within a metropolitan Regional Office at the Administrative Service Officer 4, 5 or 6 level have continuing responsibility for specific Divisions and be designated as Divisional Returning Officers for specific Divisions.

Mr President, in concluding I would like to thank all those who contributed to the Committee's Inquiry and in particular, the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes; the Efficiency Scrutineer, Dianne Saunders; and those DROs who made submissions to the Committee. Similarly, the Committee also thanks Julie Pagonis from the ACOA and Members of this Parliament for their contribution.
The Committee is grateful for the work undertaken by its staff and on behalf of the Committee I thank them: Mrs Helen Misa (``Missa''), Mrs Lexia Noakes and Trevor Rowe, the Committee's Secretary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters I would like to make some very brief remarks about this report. The inquiry essentially concerned the efficiency scrutiny conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission in relation to its operations and the proposals in the efficiency scrutiny report for a system of regionalisation of Australian Electoral Commission divisional offices. The Committee received a considerable number of submissions, and these are referred to in the tabling speech. The Committee recognised that, although only a few persons actually pass through the door of Electoral Commission divisional offices-an average of, say, 15 persons a week-nevertheless quite a substantial volume of work is undertaken by the staff of the Commission. There are some 10 million voters in Australia and each year there are some two million to three million changes to the electoral data in respect of the electoral rolls.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, under section 92 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act officers of the Australian Electoral Commission must undertake a habitation review. The workload of the Commission's divisional officers is lumpy. There is no real way to overcome that problem unless we have more and more elections. That would make the workload less lumpy and more sustained. However, the Committee considered the report and the question of efficiency and, most importantly, whether the efficiency scrutiny took sufficient account of the democratic principle. We have come up with a recommendation for the amalgamation of divisional offices in metropolitan areas to enable three divisional officers to conduct the Commission's business from the same office. This will not apply in non-metropolitan areas.

We received a number of submissions from members of the House of Representatives and the Senate and we also received representations from, for example, the Burnie City Council. That is an interesting example. The Commission's efficiency scrutiny suggested that the divisional office for the electoral division of Braddon should be transferred from Burnie, where it is at the moment, to Launceston. Those who know Tasmania would be aware that such a move would make it extremely difficult for someone living on the west coast of Tasmania to visit the divisional office of Braddon, because it would mean going right down to Launceston. It is not a great distance but, because of the terrain, it would take quite some time. Essentially, we considered the social and economic costs and the important democratic principle in arriving at our conclusions. I might add that our conclusions and our recommendations are unanimous, the Committee's membership comprising representatives from the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are either all wrong or all right.
—We confidently expect that the Government will pick up our recommendations and that the Australian Electoral Commission will do so also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.
On 1 September I moved a motion which was carried by the Senate on the following day. The motion read as follows:

That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 25 November 1988, details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation.

The hope is that this is the first of what might become a regular exercise. In fact, it is something that has exercised the minds of a number of senators for quite some time. The last major step in this area was taken on the initiative of Senator Peter Rae, who is now a Minister in the Tasmanian Government, when he gave a notice of motion which required notification to be given when a Bill that had passed this Parliament was actually proclaimed.

I do not think that many people realise that there are a number of stages in the operation of Bills. The fact that this Parliament has passed a piece of legislation does not necessarily mean that anything will happen with it. There are two further steps: the royal assent, which is a formal exercise, and then the actual proclamation date. I note that Senator Puplick is flicking through this paper. He has raised this question from time to time in the various Estimates committees. It is interesting that, after a brief look at this paper, I have found details of 57 Bills. I think people should take note of that. It is all very well to know which Bills are proclaimed. That already occurs, the information being tabled by the Clerk from time to time. However, what we do not know is which Bills are not proclaimed. Unless one has a massive indexing exercise and manages to keep on top of it, most senators would not know, but some fascinating things happen. What we have in fact done, by the mechanism under which Bills are drafted, is hand over effective legislative powers to the bureaucrats. When one goes through this list and sees some of the reasons why Acts passed by this Parliament have not been proclaimed, one is astonished. For example, on the very first page there appears this statement in relation to sections of the Goods, Works and Services Act 1981:

These sections relate to preferential buying of Australian goods by Commonwealth authorities and provoked considerable and continued Ministerial and bureaucratic opposition on enactment. They were therefore not proclaimed.

This Parliament passes an Act; it runs foul of the bureaucrats who do not like it, and it is therefore not proclaimed. One can go on and look at some of the other reasons given why Bills, passed by chambers of this Parliament, have not been proclaimed and one is astounded. By the way, my motion managed to flush out something rather interesting. Somebody suddenly discovered that the International Finance Corporation Act had been passed on 22 November 1963 and the bureaucrats thought that they ought to put it into practice. The Commonwealth Teaching Service Act which was introduced in 1972 was to provide scholarships. Proclamations were delayed `pending drafting of regulations'. Those regulations have not been drafted 16 years on. Somebody has not got round to that exercise. A number of senators will remember the Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Amendment Act 1985 being pushed through here at the end of the session.

My worry is that the device of leaving legislation unproclaimed is used in a number of ways. There are examples of Bills in this paper that the Government said were urgent when they were passed. Indeed, the Government said that one Bill, which is in this paper, was so urgent that it could not accept an amendment. The reason given as to why it was not proclaimed was the very reason that was given in the amendment to fix up the Bill. It is an extraordinary exercise and one that all honourable senators ought to take some note of. If we are willing simply to hand over the legislative power of these chambers to bureaucrats, then it is on our heads. I hope that all political parties in this place will look at what is occurring with the drafting of legislation and whether we might look at inserting a date that it could be proclaimed on rather than simply a date being proclaimed. The Government might not rush Bills in here which are poorly drafted and poorly thought through.

When one goes through the reasons in this tabled paper one finds, time and again, items that one would have thought would have come up in the drafting of those pieces of legislation. One would have thought that reasons given as to why the Bill cannot be implemented would have been thought of before it was brought in. I am not objecting to the fact that there may be unforeseen occurrences from time to time, but surely we should not have 57 unproclaimed Acts passed by this Parliament sitting on the books. Indeed, that is about half the Acts that we manage to get passed in the year. We could have saved ourselves a lot of time and the country a lot of expense. If we have a legislative backlog, as we do at the moment, it is fair to ask: how many of those Bills currently on the red sheet-we have 38 items listed at the moment-will not be proclaimed? If they are not to be proclaimed, let us take them off the red and save ourselves some time. If they will be proclaimed, it is all right to spend our time looking through them, trying to amend them, passing them or rejecting them.

I am rather upset at being gazumped quite so often by the bureaucrats in this exercise. They are deciding who should have the final say in respect of the legislation passed by the representatives of the people in these chambers, presumably in a democracy, who should have the final say. The people who really get the final say at the end of this exercise are the bureaucrats. They say whether they like the legislation. If they do not happen to like it-as was the case with the Act I mentioned on the first page of the tabled statement-they simply make a fuss and do not proclaim it. I do not think it is right; it is not proper. It may very well be that our party room should consider the way in which legislation is drafted. If we are not willing to do that, I hope that honourable senators will support a continuation of my motion. As a result of this material, I now seek to institute a permanent motion so that at least once a session we find out how many pieces of legislation passed are still sitting around in some bottom drawer somewhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to make some comments on this report. I indicate to Senator Macklin that I am sure there will be a great deal of interest from the Opposition parties to ensure that it becomes a standard practice, by way of a permanent order of this chamber, to have regular reports on legislation which has been passed by the Parliament but which has not been proclaimed. I want to draw attention to a couple of matters. This is another step in the reassertion to some degree of a better balance between the legislative and executive branches of government in terms of, if not making the Executive more accountable, at least making the activities of the Executive more open to the scrutiny of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall speaking on this matter some time ago when dealing with a report presented in 1986 by Estimates Committee D which referred to our concerns about lengthy delays between the passage of legislation and its proclamation. I think at that stage I drew attention to an article which had been printed in the Economist in December 1981 which had raised the scandalous record established in the House of Commons of a piece of legislation which had been passed by the Parliament but which 12 years later had not been proclaimed. When I look at this list which comes before us I find two absolutely extraordinary items. The Naval Properties Transfer Act passed in 1925 still has not been proclaimed. Sections 3 and 4 of the Taxation of Loans Act passed in 1923 have not yet been proclaimed. The record established by the House of Commons of a mere 12 years between the enactment of legislation and its proclamation which led to such outrage pales into insignificance in relation to these matters.

I do however draw attention to a couple of points in terms of specific examples. There are lengthy sections, for instance, of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1985, the Bankruptcy Amendment Act 1987, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act 1987 and certain customs legislation dealing with security and searches relevant to the detection of drug smuggling, which have not been proclaimed. For instance, those amendments to the Customs Act were made in 1979. Undoubtedly, we were told at the time that the power to detain and search persons who were reasonably suspected of having prohibitive imports internally concealed in their bodies was a matter of urgency. In fact, those sections of the Act dealing with the attempt to crack down on the drug trade have still not been proclaimed.

For example, I look at the Prime Minister and Cabinet area. The Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Act 1980 has large sections of some importance which have not been proclaimed. I go back to the example that Senator Macklin raised. When this resolution was adopted we asked for a statement of why it was that Acts had not been brought into effect. Under the Procurement of Goods, Works and Services Act 1981, this explanation occurs:
These sections-
that is, the unproclaimed sections-

relate to preferential buying of Australian goods by Commonwealth authorities and provoked considerable and continued Ministerial and bureaucratic opposition on enactment. They were therefore not proclaimed.

That is the most extraordinary statement for any parliament to be confronted with. The Parliament passed legislation in terms of preferential buying of Australian goods. Ministers and bureaucrats decided that they did not like the Act of Parliament, and so simply did not proclaim it. What is the purpose of passing legislation through Parliament if Ministers and bureaucrats then decide, `We don't like what the Parliament has done. Therefore, we will simply not proclaim the Act. We will not advise the Governor-General, through the Executive Council, to bring the Act into force'? Nothing could be more subversive of the proper role of Parliament than to say that Parliament can pass legislation which will come into effect if the bureaucracy thinks it ought to come into effect. The opportunity to expose this sort of nonsense is one of which we should be very conscious.

The distinguished now Deputy Clerk of the Senate, Miss Anne Lynch, published in the House Magazine on 13 May 1987 an article entitled `Proclamation of Acts-When . . . How . . . If?'. That article sets out in detail the history of the Senate's concern about this matter, going back to the days when our former colleague Senator Peter Rae was involved in raising these matters in the Senate. I seek leave to have the Deputy Clerk's article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PROCLAMATION OF ACTS-
WHEN . . . HOW . . . IF?
by
Anne Lynch
Clerk-Assistant (Committees)

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which was established in 1981, already has an honourable record of considering provisions of Bills which might otherwise escape attention, under civil liberties criteria. Among the five criteria is a provision by which the Committee evaluates proposed legislation to ensure that it does not inappropriately delegate legislative authority. In recent times increased recourse to that provision has been made by the Committee to draw attention to provisions such as clauses which enable Parliamentary enactments to be repealed by executive authority only, without further reference to the Parliament.

It seems timely, therefore, to draw attention to an increasing trend in the legislative process which also has the effect of delegating to the executive powers formerly exercised by the Parliament. These powers, of a general nature, are laid down in the Acts Interpretation Act, section 5 of which provides that Acts passed by the Parliament will, unless otherwise specified, come into operation 28 days after receiving the Royal Assent. Increasingly, over the last decade or so, the Parliament has ``otherwise provided'' by what seems to be a harmless-looking clause 2 in most Bills, which is headed ``commencement''. In passing, it is no wonder that, in order to get to the heart of policy espoused in a Bill, legislators have ignored the gobbledegook in which this clause is often couched, for example:
Commencement
2. (1) Subject to sub-section (2), this Act shall come into operation on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.
(2) Sections 33, 34, 35, 36 and 37 shall come into operation on a day to be fixed by Proclamation, being a day later than the day fixed under sub-section (1).
It is worthy of comment that this example is one of the less complex on offer!

Stripping the clause of its complexity, the heart lies in the words ``this Act shall come into operation on a day to be fixed by Proclamation''. The effect of the seemingly innocuous words can be quite overwhelming. What in fact a Parliament which passes that clause of a bill is doing is saying to the executive, ``we have done our part in giving you all sorts of powers; you can get round to implementing the policies contained at your convenience, with no further input from us as legislators''.
On the face of it, this may seem perfectly reasonable. However, its consequences are many:
(a) it places in the hands of the bureaucracy an enormous power to gainsay or even override the wishes of the people as expressed by their parliamentary representatives;

(b) if legislation is passed without a time limit set on its implementation, it provides encouragement-because there is no pressure to have structures and administrative details in place by a defined date-to the bureaucracy to be tardy in implementing worthwhile goals;

(c) it can be a method of window dressing, so that the executive can declare an Act of Parliament has been passed in order to help a disadvantaged group within a community-without ever having to mention that there is no intention to implement the proposals contained therein because of, for example, a lack of money;

(d) it can also be used as an instrument of blackmail-for example, ``we will pass this legislation, but will not bring it into effect unless you, the citizen, behave in a particular way which we do not like''; and

(e) finally, and in my view most significantly, the failure to proclaim a law-whether in whole or, as now more frequently and insidiously occurs, in part-leaves those with a need to be concerned about what the law is in a state of constant indecision and doubt. It is, one might have thought, reasonable to expect that the law is known to operate as a result of its passage through all three constituent parts of the Parliament, that is, by passage of a bill through the House of Representatives and the Senate and Assent by the Governor-General. This-together with a known date of operation-alone gives certainty to the law.

The rationale for the use of the proclamation as an alternative to 28 days after Royal Assent, a specified date declared in the legislation, or, in the case of taxation laws in particular, Royal Assent itself was in its early usage perfectly reasonable. It was regarded as a departure from the norm and was used only when, for example, complex regulations could not be finally prepared until the authorising legislation was agreed to by the Parliament.

Recently, however, it is rare for the normal provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act to apply. To illustrate, of the first 12 Acts passed by the Parliament in 1987, 8 contained a provision declaring that the Act or parts thereof should come into operation on a day to be fixed by proclamation. Even more disturbingly, the legislative process has reached such a pass that the ``normal'' operations of the Acts Interpretation Act are even specified in legislation. The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 contains the following astonishing provision:
Commencement
2. (1) Section 8 and Part V shall be deemed to have come into operation on 24 June 1986.
(2) The remaining provisions of this Act shall come into operation on the twenty-eighth day after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.

The somewhat disturbing trend towards the increased use of proclamations was first noted, both in Australia and Britain, in the early 1980's. For example, The Economist of 12 December 1981 contained a trenchant article drawing attention to the abuse of proclamations at Westminster while, within the Australian Parliament, negotiations were undertaken with the then Government formally to inform the Parliament of executive proclamations. Early in 1982, the following somewhat picturesque Notice of Motion was given by then Senator Peter Rae:
``Mr President,
I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move-That an Address be presented by the Senate to His Excellency the Governor-General, as follows:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY-
We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to present the following address:
The Senate-
(a) noting the Constitutional responsibilities of the Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives in relation to the passage of all proposed laws of the Commonwealth;
(b) noting that each constituent part of the Parliament of the Commonwealth advises the others of agreement, amendment, and assent, as the case may be, to all such proposed laws; and

(c) noting that substantial numbers of laws which pass both Houses of the Parliament and receive the Royal Assent provide that such laws or provisions thereof shall come into operation on a day to be fixed by Proclamation,

requests your Excellency to notify each House of the Parliament of each Proclamation which is made to specify a day on which an Act of the Parliament or any provision thereof shall come into operation''.

The purpose of the Notice was to make the point, in what the Senator regarded as a constitutionally proper way, that the Governor-General-as, in effect, the legislature's ``delegate''-might deem it appropriate to advise the Parliament of the completion of the legislative process. Although the Notice of Motion was never formally moved, it unquestionably provided both the focus of and the impetus for this important issue, and subsequently arrangements were made for all proclamations of this nature to be tabled in each House of the Parliament. This practice is now well established.

However, the question now arises as to whether the Government, with the responsibility for implementing and administering laws passed by Parliament, should give an account of its stewardship in relation to Acts of the Parliament, or sections thereof, which have not been proclaimed. This question arose in stark form during the consideration of estimates of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment during the Budget Sittings of 1986. The Committee reported as follows:
``Proclamation of Acts

The Committee was concerned to learn of the lengthy delays that have occurred in proclaiming the Public Lending Rights Act 1985 and the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986, neither of which has yet been proclaimed.

The Committee appreciates that there can sometimes be a number of legitimate reasons for not proclaiming or delaying the proclamation of legislation. The Department explained to the Committee that the delays in these cases result from the Department having to prepare a gazette notice for the Minister to spell out the operation of the Public Lending Rights scheme and to develop a national cultural heritage control list. The Committee does not regard these explanations as satisfactory for the following reasons:

(i) There has been a considerable period of time since the Bills were introduced into Parliament. The Committee expects that if Regulations or any other actions need to be prepared consequent upon the passage of the Bills, such preparation would have commenced following their introduction or indeed in conjunction with the original drafting. The legislative history of each Bill was as follows:
Public Lending Rights Act 1985
House of Representatives: Introduced-17 April 1985, Passed-9 May 1985
Senate: Introduced-9 May 1985, Passed-6 December 1985
Royal Assent: 16 December 1985
Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986
House of Representatives: Introduced-27 November 1985, Passed-18 February 1986
Senate: Introduced-11 March 1985, Passed-1 May 1986
Royal Assent: 13 May 1986

In respect of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act, the Department indicated that it hoped the legislation will be proclaimed towards the end of 1987-two years after its introduction in Parliament!

(ii) The effectiveness of the Senate's capacity to review the Public Lending Rights Bill was reduced due to the Bill being pushed through the Senate's Committee of the Whole stage on the last sitting day in 1985, with the Government claiming its passage was urgently required.

The Committee is aware that there are a considerable number of Acts and sections of Acts awaiting proclamation. The Committee regards this situation as complete derogation of responsibility by departments and Ministers in allowing such a volume of legislation to remain inoperative. The Committee will be closely monitoring legislation with similar commencement provisions which are the responsibility of departments within the Committee's purview''.

When the Appropriation Bills were being considered in the Senate on 17 November 1986, Senator Puplick expanded upon the points made in Report. In illustrating his point, he gave quite horrifying examples of outstanding proclamations-some dating back as far as six years-and, reflecting the comments of Estimates Committee D, made the particularly pertinent point that, in relation to one of the Acts on which the Committee had commented-the Public Lending Rights Act 1985-``we were told when the Bill was debated in this chamber that the amendments the Opposition sought to make to the legislation could not be made, that the Bill was an urgent Bill which could not be amended by the Senate in December 1985 because the House of Representatives had adjourned for the year and the Government was not prepared to recall it to deal with amendments which the Senate might have been persuaded to make''.
When Senator Puplick made his remarks he commented that the Bill had still not been proclaimed; that remains the situation to this day.

It is fair to say that people are affected as much, if not more, by unconscious acts as by deliberate attempts to take away rights and liberties. For this reason, the question of executive, rather than parliamentary, control of legislative enactment should not be treated as one of those esoteric topics which are a parliamentary officer's equivalent to counting angels dancing on the head of a pin-a source of intellectual merriment and pedantry. One can but hope that the inroads already made by the Senate into executive usurpation of democratic decision-making will continue, so that in future such matters will indeed by merely of intellectual interest, rather than being examined for their perhaps sinister implications.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Some of the pieces of legislation involved are of very considerable significance. Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 will undoubtedly be familiar to colleagues such as Senator Messner and Senator Michael Baume, who are present for this debate. They will know how significant that piece of legislation could be, if it were proclaimed and acted upon. Senator Crichton-Browne has already drawn Senator Macklin's attention to the provisions of the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981. Consistent with his view on this matter, Senator Macklin undoubtedly will be most anxious that section 3 of that Act should be proclaimed. He will accept that the Parliament passed the legislation, and that therefore there is no good and proper reason why, seven or eight years after the event, we should not proceed to the proclamation of section 3 and allow the mining which will be able to take place as a result in fact to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not simply a problem that arises on one side of the Parliament; it has been current before the Senate for some time. My Liberal colleague, former Senator Peter Rae, moved motions on this matter dating back to 1983. Senate Estimates Committee D, of which I was a member, in its report of October 1986, drew attention to a number of Acts within the purview of that Estimates Committee which had not been given effect to by proclamation. This is a very important exercise. It is part of the ongoing role that the Senate should play in the supervision of the activities of the Executive Government. I am pleased that the Senate now has this report. I hope that it will be the first report of many which will help to keep any government on its toes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without canvassing what has been said by Senator Macklin and Senator Puplick, I wish to make the point that they have detailed to the Senate the facts of the issue. I have in the Senate on many occasions expressed my views about the functions of members of parliament: they have a legislative function, an audit control function, representative functions, and so on. By dint of refusing to proclaim legislation simply because it does not agree with other legislation, Ministers and bureaucrats undermine the legislative functions of members of parliament. That indeed is a very serious issue and I am pleased that it has resulted in the tabling of a paper from the Deputy Clerk. I am sure that the Presiding Officers, particularly the President of the Senate, are most interested in this aspect because, as was said by Senator Puplick and Senator Macklin, this is a matter particularly for the Senate to consider.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with what has been said in this debate. I shall not let this matter die. It is not only a question of considering what legislation is now before us which is not urgent. Senator Macklin gave a good example of a piece of legislation which the Government said was so urgent that it could not bear an amendment to it. That piece of legislation has not been proclaimed. We need to examine not only how many pieces of legislation that come before us are urgent, but how many pieces of legislation that come before us are necessary in the first place. If they are not to be proclaimed, obviously they were not necessary. That issue must also be considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the views which have been put by others in this debate, and I wish to place particular emphasis on the matter that was touched upon by Senator Puplick in respect to the provisions relating to Koongarra. That project is capable of providing, as Senator Collins will know better than anybody else, $256m in revenue for the Aboriginal community involved-enormous wealth for the Australian people. Furthermore, it will make a significant contribution to our balance of payments at a time when it is at crisis point. Yet the matter has been deferred.

SPEECH.PARA: As a matter of general principle I support the arguments which have been put. To do otherwise is to ignore the fundamentals of the functioning of Parliament and the administration of the laws of Australia. Whenever we have before us cases such as were articulated by Senator Macklin and Senator Puplick, they touch on the trust in government and in the procedures involved in the passage of legislation in our parliamentary system.

A further extension of that, which exacerbates the problem, is the present practice by this Government-although I have to admit that the last coalition Government was not without sin-of introducing notice of legislation in a general sense and in an inarticulate sense by fiat. To all intents and purposes, legislation takes effect from the day that it is announced, as we find this Treasurer (Mr Keating) doing. Frankly, that makes the passage of the legislation inconsequential and the proclamation totally irrelevant. The Treasurer now takes the cradle of democracy into his arms and acts as though there is no Parliament. As was the case recently with legislation that was almost four years old, when the Treasurer finally puts the legislation through Parliament its date of operation is made retrospective to the date that the Treasurer released his press statement-press statements which, by definition, can only be vague, imprecise, and on many occasions inaccurate, and certainly uninformative. So, at the end of the day, the poor little citizen who elects senators and members for the purposes of forming a government is kept totally in the dark as to the effect of the legislation, and in many respects the functioning of Parliament becomes totally irrelevant.

We saw this recently with the legislation in respect of taxation, concerning taxation on benefits accruing by way of trips, and rewards of that nature. The High Court of Australia held that if such benefits were not paid in cash they were not taxable. As I said at the time, I assume that the people involved had been taking the benefit assuming it to be tax free and accommodating their standard of living accordingly, only to find four years later that new and different levels of taxation applied. This occurs simply because the fundamental premise, the fundamental process of government in this Parliament, is first of all ignored and then deliberately bypassed by the Treasurer, with the approval of Cabinet and the support of the Government members in this chamber and in the other place.

While we debate here the matter of the date of proclamation, we ought to remind ourselves that the date of introduction of legislation into Parliament in the first place is relevant. That is the first opportunity that a citizen has to examine what his rights and responsibilities are and, ultimately, what his obligations are. Up to that point a citizen simply has a one-page press statement telling him that his whole tax obligation has changed. That is extended further, as we are not told, by the failure of the administration by governments, through bureaucrats, to proclaim legislation when it is ultimately passed by both Houses of Parliament.

In my view, that is showing an absolute contempt for the process of decision making and for those who support the legislation in whatever its ultimate form. I hope that, this matter having been raised, the Government will reconsider its position in terms of expediting this matter. However, I despair that the Government will ever take notice of the detrimental effects that government by fiat has upon the people of Australia. However, I suspect that this is a matter upon which it will be judged ultimately at the next election. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Deputy Clerk-A return to order relating to an answer to a question is tabled pursuant to standing order 358.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

Yesterday I asked Senator Richardson about what is now a provision adopted by the Senate whereby Ministers must give a reply to questions on notice within 30 days. If this is not complied with, senators may now ask Ministers for an explanation as to why answers have not been provided. I did mention this matter to Senator Richardson yesterday, but unavoidably he was unable to be in the chamber at the time I raised it. I therefore moved a motion which provided for the relevant material to be tabled by next Monday. Senator Richardson provided that very promptly today, and I thank him for that. The explanation given was that the answer to my question was delayed by the need to obtain and clarify the information required. The information required was not on hand until late yesterday. That is convenient timing, I fear. It is probably a coincidence--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a coincidence.

—Just a coincidence, the Government Whip suggests! I have since spoken to Senator Richardson, who has expressed the view that he is unhappy with the speed at which his Department is able to provide answers, as I imagine quite a number of Ministers are. I recommend to senators who have had questions on notice for more than 30 days that they seek to take advantage of this provision. I wish to read into the record a response I have had from the President of the Senate which clarifies the standing of some of those questions:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Macklin.
I refer to your letter of 9 November 1988 relating to the resolution of the Senate of 28 September 1988, on your motion, concerning questions on notice.

The resolution could not be regarded as having any retrospective effect in the absence of any express provision for retrospectivity, so it did not take effect at once in respect of questions on the notice paper on that day. It does apply, however, to all questions which are on the notice paper 30 days or more after 28 September, regardless of whether notice of them was given before or after that date. I think that this is the correct interpretation of the resolution. The notice paper now shows which questions have remained unanswered for 30 days or more since 28 September 1988.

I urge honourable senators to take advantage of the resolution of the Senate to get answers to their questions. I believe that if they do so we will make questions on notice a useful questioning function of the Executive rather than simply a paper exercise that bulges over the year with hundreds of unanswered questions. This is an opportunity for senators to question the Executive and have the answers promptly delivered to them. I believe that in very large measure the non-answering of questions on notice to date, probably due to delays within the departments concerned has amounted almost to a contempt of this chamber. I hope that, by more strenuous use of the resolution which is now on the books, we will be able to get prompt and ready answers to reasonable questions.

I am not expecting the Executive to want to answer, or to be able to answer, every question put to it. Indeed, I believe that on occasions many questions have been put on the Notice Paper which, if answered, would have caused massive expenditure of public moneys in order to get the information together-to little or no effect. I believe that those questions which are responsible questions, particularly those questions about matters on which one would expect current information to be held, ought to be answered-and answered promptly. I urge all honourable senators to use the facility that we have voted for ourselves so that we can get some better accountability from the Executive.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to paper No. 7, the Australian Wool Corporation annual report for 1987-88. I have spoken to this report previously, but would like to add a few remarks. I believe that, as 1988 is the bicentennial year and in view of the historic significance of wool to Australia, it is appropriate for the wool industry to play a major role in celebrating 200 years of Australia's nationhood. I think we can all remember very well indeed the bicentennial wool collection staged in the Sydney Opera House on 31 January. It brought together woolgrowers and leaders of the world's textile, retail and fashion industries. It certainly demonstrated how highly the wool industry is regarded both within Australia and internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the woolgrowers themselves have wanted to ensure the future of the industry. They have decided to increase the funds available for international wool promotion. I was very interested to read in the People magazine an article about Bill Peach and a new image for wool that he was promoting. I think that we all know of Bill Peach through his tourism activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you don't look at the pictures.

—Actually, I think the article was about people and was in the New Idea magazine. I would not like Senator Collins to think that perhaps I had gone in for reading other magazines. However, this was a very interesting article about Bill Peach. We are used to seeing Bill Peach and his documentaries about Australia. They have all been very interesting. This time, the documentary has been partly sponsored by the Australian Wool Corporation and will take 3 1/2 weeks to make. It is entitled Golden Fleece. Its purpose is to inform and entertain Australians about the uses of wool overseas. I think that that documentary will certainly be worth looking at. Apparently, Bill Peach is going to Russia. He said in the article that in Russia wool was creating a minor fashion revolution and that he would be very interested to see how the Russian woman in the street was using wool to make Russian fashion even better. I was very pleased to read about that documentary. It is to be filmed in Tokyo, Shanghai, Milan, Leningrad, Moscow, rural England and London, and will be a documentary worth seeing.

SPEECH.PARA: Last time I spoke about the Australian Wool Corporation report I mentioned the `Mr Cool in Wool' campaign. I read just recently that the Australian Wool Corporation, in its recent awards for inventors, gave top marks to the scientific achievements of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The Sir Ian McLennon award was given to Dr Dieter Plate, Assistant Chief of the Division of Wool Technology and the man responsible for Sirospun, the revolutionary Australian process that gave the world `cool wool'. I think we all know that cool wool is an extra lightweight fabric that is light enough to be worn in summer and warm enough to wear through autumn chills. Actually, Dr Plate himself believes that Sirospun could enable Australia to process more of its wool clip at home and to provide more value added dollars to our $6 billion annual wool sales. He maintained that luck had been important in developing Sirospun, but I think that Dr Plate should be commended indeed on the work he has done, because I think it is all of great assistance to the woolgrowers and to the development of the wool industry in general.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report comes from the Australian Archives Advisory Council, of which I am a member. I want to refer particularly to the fact that, under section 56 (2) of the Archives Act, as yet no arrangements have been put in place for special requests. I remind the Senate that prior to 1984, when the Archives Act passed through the Parliament, the decision to grant access was an administrative one taken by the Minister responsible for the Archives and the relevant Minister responsible for the agency whose records were being sought. However, that arrangement was superseded by the legislation introduced in 1984.

During the four years that have passed attempts apparently have been made to sort out a set of arrangements between the Office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Attorney-General and the security and intelligence agencies, but as yet they have not been successful. The Archives Advisory Council has commented on this on a number of occasions, and does so again in the summary of its activities in the 1987-88 report. We have had a succession of Ministers with jurisdiction over the Archives. The Advisory Council sent a delegation to Senator Robert Ray when he was in charge of the Archives. When he left the portfolio, we saw the new Minister, Mr West. I believe it important that some scheme be set up granting special access to the Archives to ensure that there is some scrutiny and monitoring of the Government in its willingness or otherwise to make available the documents and records held by its agencies. It is almost as though the Act is being used to stifle access to information, rather than the reverse. We would be better off with the arrangement we had previously-an arrangement between the Minister responsible for the Archives and the agency in question.

Another matter I wanted to refer to was the production of a book by the Australian Archives this year to mark the Bicentenary. The book is entitled Relations in Records: A guide to family history sources in the Australian Archives, and was very well received. It was launched by Senator Robert Ray on behalf of the Australian Archives. For anybody commencing genealogy as a hobby, it is a very valuable document and, I think, something very worth while for the Archives to have produced during the bicentennial year. I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is present and, I know, listening to my remarks, to take this up with the Government to deal with the matter of requests under section 56, part II, to which the Council draws attention, not for the first time since the legislation was passed in 1984.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
