SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It seems to me rather extraordinary that one should have to discuss a so-called blueprint for Australian higher education in this way. Indeed, the Government did not see fit, either in this chamber or in the other place, to allocate a time in which this particularly important debate might be held.

We are dealing with the central problem of government and education and what role government has to play in education as distinct from the funding exercise. The major problem has been fairly clear. What we are looking at is probably a relatively heavy-handed exercise in terms of this paper.

The policy which the Government has set down in the paper and is implementing represents a very narrow utilitarian view of what higher education institutions might be able to contribute by way of economic restructuring. Despite the genuflection-and that is about all it is-to the institutions' cultural role, the Commonwealth, having done that obligatory bit of rhetoric, spends the rest of the paper discussing essentially the economic contributions that higher education might make to Australia. In particular, it looks at items such as the size of institutions. In the Australian Capital Territory and the States we have seen the proposition that the size of an institution can be somehow equated to its worth. Obviously, that is absurd. There are no linkages between size and quality. For example, the proposed amalgamations in my State will try to swallow up the Conservatorium of Music which has 350 students. That college has a worldwide and an Australian reputation second to none, having got four out of the five winners in the most recent awards. The Julliard School of Music in New York has 400 students and the Royal Academy of Music in London has 350. The number of students in the major music schools around the world hovers around that figure, yet in Australia we propose that they have to be part of an institution of 6,000 or 7,000 students. There are no linkages. The Government simply assumes them.

The unresolved tension that is evident in the White Paper has probably resulted from a lot of talk of reducing centralised control, creating conditions in which institutions can be more innovative and independent, and so on. There is a whole set of statements about institutions having to have priorities in areas defined by government as national priorities and having to undertake management changes and amalgamations according to national priorities. I think that this tension will be resolved. There will be only one resolution; that is, institutions will be able to be flexible in those areas dictated by the Government. It is a simple resolution of the tension, but it is a resolution which will be to the disadvantage of the country and to learning in this country.

If one takes the only economic criterion which points ahead as being an area in which one might invest, knowing that investment in that area is linked directly with outcomes, one looks at dollars invested in higher education or, more particularly, dollars invested as part of the gross domestic product contribution to education across the board. That is the only reliable predictor of where we might be going. I believe that this entire policy is misguided and misdirected and that ultimately it will be to the disadvantage of not only the students who are undertaking education but also the country in general.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL BOARD OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We are considering the guidelines issued to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) in relation to the performance of its functions in accordance with section 8 of the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988. That legislation was passed by the Senate half way through this year. The last part of the guidelines at page 8 states:

NBEET's advice to me should be framed in recognition of the budgetary priorities outlined above, and on the explicit assumption that there will be no further growth in expenditure in the Employment, Education and Training portfolio to cover new policy proposals in future financial years.

In other words, the Government put down in writing over the signature of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on 30 September that there will be no future growth in expenditure in this area. I have been saying that for a long time, but seemingly the press did not want to believe it. It is now in writing over the Minister's signature. It means that we face a continuing run-down, because no further expenditure means a wind-back of support for education in this country and a move to financing education by the private sector. It also means, and gives tacit support to, the notion of a myriad of developments in private higher education. It also means that the current level of $800 for each student, as suggested in the Higher Education Funding Bill, which passed the House of Representatives on Tuesday night, will soon be exceeded and could rise to as high as $8,000 within two or three years. That will be the only way-if that is correct-in terms of the guidelines provided to the Board that it can take on board the direction that there will be no further increases in expenditure.

We believe that the advice to the Government from the Board should be done on the basis of what is optimal, not necessarily what is achievable. If it is done on the basis of what is optimal, the Government will make the hard political decisions as to what is achievable within that optimal range. Why bother getting together a group of people who are expert in education, who have the ability to look at that whole range of institutions and advise as to what best might be done and place those constraints upon them? That is essentially an absurd exercise. What we are trying to get out of the Board is advice about where to go. The Government can then pick from that advice those things which are possible within its own financial and budgetary arrangements. But to apply those constraints up-front means that no optimal procedures will be raised, no way ahead will be flagged and no broader vision will be mapped out by which we might be able to have an education debate in this country that is worth having. I do not think that it is much use having a board which simply does the type of job that is currently being done by a department. We had this argument regarding the Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. It looks as though we are about to have the same argument again. It is a senseless and useless proposition and, in the end, a waste of public funds to so constrain such an organisation.

I believe that this body and the people appointed to it give us a great deal of hope that they can come up with a quite far-sighted and interesting projection of where Australia should be going in the 1990s-if they are allowed to do so. On the basis of saying, `This is the optimum; this is where we could go; these are the types of things we need', we are then able to judge this Government's or any future government's performance in this area. We do not have that benchmark. We are to be deprived specifically of that benchmark by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Hence, I think that the national debate will be that much the poorer, because without that projection I do not see how we are able to estimate whether the Government has done a good or bad job or whether its own priorities for expenditure in this area compared with other areas are something that we would like. I think that is a pity. It destroys the effective work that was done by this chamber in amending that Bill to make a strong, vibrant organisation. Essentially that organisation has now been neutered by the guidelines provided under the legislation by the Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We are presented with the final report, volumes 1 and 2, of the Constitutional Commission, which has in excess of 1,100 pages. They are 1,100 pages of pure failed propaganda. It was never the intention of this Government that there be a proper, healthy, open and fruitful debate on constitutional reform from the outset without reflecting on any individual in a personal way. The Government sought to find people to put on the Constitutional Commission who it judged, whatever their political persuasion, would be moved to agree to the essential core proposition which the Government had. Of course, this proposition was for four-year terms for the Senate tied to the House of Representatives and the inevitable and inexorable consequence that the Senate would lose its fundamental powers in respect of its legislative capacity.

As events unfolded and it became obvious to the Government and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that their agenda was in tatters, that the public was awake to their intentions, they immediately jettisoned the findings of the Constitutional Commission and introduced and raised their own agenda and gave us four questions of their own. Those four questions, which at the end of the day cost the Australian taxpayers $37m at a time when they had holes in the seat of their pants because of the levels of taxation they were paying, were never going to succeed.

Out of 1,100 pages of report we got proposals for a mini Bill of Rights; a facade, a pretension, of recognition of local government in the Constitution; freedom from religion, and freedom of religion, which we have already got; trial by jury, which we have already got; and reasonable and fair compensation, which we have already got. I suspect that the referendum on these questions was unique. I do not recall another occasion when a question has been put up and has not been carried in one single State. Never before has there been a uniform vote of the type we saw on this occasion. In excess of 70 per cent of the population said no to the Government. Yet it cost us tens of millions of dollars to go through the charade and the exercise. At the end of the day we saw the desperation of people such as Sir Maurice Byers, who got himself involved in the politics of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's hardly a bolshie.

—I do not know whether he is a bolshie or not. He may be described as many other things but it would be unfair of me to use the privilege of this chamber to say what. Certainly at the end of the day he put his snout in the political trough and found the lid slamming on it. The tragedy of this farce is that for at least the foreseeable future the Government has undone any prospect we had of constitutional reform. We have a Constitution which the High Court of Australia, in its own selective and subjective way, seeks to interpret and make a live and living document. That does not necessarily reflect community view. While we could have had an open and free bipartisan debate as to where it needs to be changed and amended to accommodate contemporary society, that probably for the next decade has been lost because of the conduct and misbehaviour of the Government, which used and abused the Parliament and the taxpayers' money to put up dodgy and fraudulent questions, which of course failed. It is an indictment upon this Government that it buried any prospect of future rational debate and amendments and variations to the Constitution which are no doubt necessary.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Crichton-Browne in expressing my concern at not only the nature of the Constitutional Commission Report but also the Government's failure to act with integrity on its recommendations. I wish to deal in particular with one element of it: the suggestion of a four-year term for the Parliament, which I believe this Government successfully demolished by purporting to propose an improvement but surrounding it with impossible qualifications. This worthwhile objective was totally rejected by the Australian people and, in that form, properly so. This has set back many years the prospect of getting an improvement in the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am strongly in favour of a four-year term for the House of Representatives and a much longer term for the Senate. The elections should not be coincidental. However, I note with distress that when the Government produced its recent referendum proposals it did nothing to ensure a longer term for this Parliament. It wanted to remove, by reducing the rights of the Senate, the one inhibition on a Prime Minister shortening the term of a parliament. I only hope that the next government, which will come from members on this side of the House, will be prepared to bite the bullet at an early time and have an honest referendum on a four-year term for the House of Representatives which does not effectively mean a diminishing of the present short term. As the Senate knows, the average length of a term for the House of Representatives in recent years has been something like two years. There appears to be a need-this was discussed by the Constitutional Commission but totally ignored by the Government-to put some limit on the freedom and the power of an executive to determine when it should take the Parliament to the people.
A lawyer, Mr George V. Turner, has written to senators such as me on this question of constitutional reform, saying:

The Personal Particulars revealed in the 1986 Parliamentary Handbook indicate the possibility that you should review your eligibility status, in terms of the Australian Constitution, for being chosen or of sitting as a member of the Federal Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a rude and offensive letter.

—As Senator Puplick has said, it was rude and offensive. I will not be stood over; I will not be blackmailed by a person of this character in this way. There is nothing in the Parliamentary Handbook which gives any indication of any possibility that I would not be eligible for this Parliament. If this person has some case to make, I will be interested to hear it. The reality is that he has no case to make whatsoever that there is any risk to the members of this Parliament under this requirement of the Constitution. Firstly section 44 commences by stating that any person who:

SPEECH.PARA: Is under any acknowledgment of allegiance, obedience, or adherence-to a foreign power--
no-one in this chamber has acknowledged such allegiance, obedience or adherence to a foreign power-
or is a subject or a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power:

The reality is that any migrant to Australia becoming an Australian citizen renounces all other allegiances, and it is the act of renunciation of all other allegiances which prevents an unwanted nationality from overseas being thrust upon that person while in Australia. It is the law applying in Australia that is of relevance, not the fanciful nonsense of this gentleman Mr Turner. I presume that there are many lawyers who have muddled views of many matters, but Mr Turner is certainly not only top of the muddle stakes but very high on the offensive stakes. I reject his suggestion that I am in any way at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us today the two final reports of the Constitutional Commission, volumes 1 and 2. The Commission was set up at a cost of $6m. The Commission's own propaganda, entitled Australia's Constitution: Time to Update, said that the Commission would report to the Federal Government and that the Government would then decide what recommendations to put at the referendum. In typical style the Government set up this Commission but did not wait for its report before it brought forward its own four ludicrous questions to put to the people. An interim report was put down and the Government chose to ignore its recommendations. It did not pick up one of its suggestions. In the propaganda booklet Australia's Constitution: Time to Update there is a foreword by Professor Colin Howard, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Few countries can be so dominated by a printed document as is Australia by its constitution. Few peoples can be so plagued with constitutional problems in their daily lives as are Australians.
As I went around the traps campaigning and read that rubbish to the Australian people, they roared with laughter. The foreword goes on:
Few peoples can be so plagued with constitutional problems in their daily lives as are Australians.
The foreword continues:

A dull, remote and incomprehensible document like a printed constitution seems to have no connection with life as it is actually lived. This appearance is misleading. The constitution has everything to do with life as it is actually lived.

You bet it has. The Australian people are well aware that the Constitution, as it is written, as it has served them since Federation, has given them a country that is amongst the top 18 countries out of 165 in the world, in terms of political and general freedoms. That Constitution, upheld by the governments that have run this country, has given the people this freedom that is so valuable to us. I repeat that only 18 countries out of 165 have the freedoms that we have in Australia. This whole referendum debacle cost the Australian taxpayer in excess of $37m, yet this Government tells everyone, `Pull your belts in because it is time, unfortunately, for us to save'. The Government has put us so far in debt with our overseas balance of payments that everyone has got to pull in his belt-everyone, that is, except the Government, which could squander not a paltry amount, but $37m of taxpayers' money on a referendum that it wanted to get through cloaked in questions so misleading that the people of Australia said, `There must be something wrong with this', and threw out the four of them.

The Government has been accused of not being in touch with the people of Australia on many occasions. I say that this is the ultimate proof. If ever there was proof of this it was when, more significantly that at any other time in Australia's history, every State threw out every question that the Government attempted to bring in. In defence the Government said, `The Australian people are stupid; they don't understand', but the people of Australia certainly understood.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In making a few remarks on the annual report of the Prices Surveillance Authority, I note that of late the Government has been doing quite a lot navel gazing. It has been trying to find out why it has not been exactly the flavour of the month-one other term that was used was `not travelling well'-and why it has been suffering so badly in Federal by-elections around the country this year. A very good place for it to look would be in the area of price restraint or, rather, the lack of it.

The Prices Surveillance Authority, which replaced the Prices Justification Tribunal in 1983, was set up with one aim: to maintain the accord known as the prices and incomes accord. It should perhaps more accurately be named the `profits and incomes accord' because there appears to be very little political will on the part of the Government to address seriously the problem of dramatic price increases and their effect on ordinary Australians. There are several examples of current price control mechanisms failing us badly. One of the most current is the pricing of beer. In the Budget the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced dramatic changes to the sales tax and excise on beer, particularly low alcohol beer. His motives had more to do with fulfilling his consumer price index prediction than they did with helping consumers; but, notwithstanding that, we should have been assured that consumers would see a dramatic drop in beer prices commensurate with the changes that were made in that Budget.

On 27 September I sought an assurance from Senator Walsh that this was occurring. He said in reply that the Prices Surveillance Authority had taken appropriate action. However, retail prices have not dropped universally to the extent that the Budget changes would suggest. So we had a windfall for the liquor industry at the cost of taxpayers, and the price control mechanism in that case has been found to be ineffective. Similarly, almost all major banks-including the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, regrettably-have introduced a range of bank charges despite their phenomenal profit increases in a climate where the Government has claimed deregulation of the banking industry was necessary to introduce competition which would be of benefit to all Australian consumers. All we see are increased charges, which impact most on small account holders and therefore low income people and people on benefits who commonly use their bank accounts and who are, if not forced, certainly massively encouraged by the Government to use their bank accounts as the mechanisms through which their benefits are paid if they are Commonwealth beneficiaries. Throughout this whole exercise of increased charges, which has drawn a considerable outcry from the public, the Government has sat on its hands and as far as I am aware-and I am not any further enlightened by this report-the Prices Surveillance Authority has not taken action.

The other area in which consumers have considerable cause for complaint is petrol prices. The report notes-as, of course, we are aware-that the Authority does not exercise surveillance over retail prices of petrol and there are other areas of action that are necessary there, some of which the Australian Democrats have over time attempted to take. The tremendous fluctuation of petrol prices has a great impact on consumers, particularly in rural areas where there can be no certainty in people's actions in the purchasing of petrol, again an area where the Prices Surveillance Authority is certainly failing ordinary consumers in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is in five volumes and of 2,200 pages. It contains the Inter-State Commission's preliminary findings and proposed strategy for removing waterfront-related impediments to Australia's trade. This is crucial to the country's economic prosperity. There is one overwhelming finding in this very lengthy report, that is, there is an urgent need for fundamental changes to the waterfront industry as it operates at present. That would be the least surprising finding of the year. The Commission found, not surprisingly, that the policy of incremental adjustments to industry arrangements in the past has not succeeded. We do not solve the problems of monopolies by nibbling at the edges. The only way to bring monopolies under control is either by legislation-and then there is the question of who has the power to make the legislation-or by introducing competition. We will never do it by encouragement and inducement, because monopolies are in a strong position. They will not yield to such blandishments. They may bend a little, but we will soon find that they have gone back to where they were.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government keeps on calling for reports, such as this one, but it is very slow to take action. I think the time is up. Since 1986 we have had eight official reports on, or inquiries into, the waterfront industry. The time for reports is past. The time for action is now. This report identifies four major causes of our waterfront inefficiencies. The first is overmanning. There are so many examples one could give of grotesque overmanning that I shall not bore the Senate by listing them. The second is restrictive work practices. Again, we all know the sorts of restrictive work practices that operate on the waterfront. The third is hours lost through industrial disputes. At the moment the waterfront industry is the second worst of Australian industries, after the troubled coal industry. The second highest number of days lost was on the waterfront. And they are not all over industrial matters. Last year 84 disputes on the waterfront were in protest at the internal policies of South Africa, leading to substantial ship and cargo delays. The final problem we have is high unit costs; that is, the employment of unnecessary or unfit workers, restrictive work practices and low productivity.

What we must all understand is that we all pay for these inefficiencies. Inefficiencies with regard to coastal shipping are compounded by the inefficiency of our ports. Our exports are less competitive because of the inefficiencies of our ports. Our imports cost more because of the inefficiency of our ports. This is really a test case of this Government's economic handling. A few years ago Australia had a downturn in the value of its exports. The terms of trade turned against us. If you looked at what we had to do, obviously we had to improve the productivity of our work force. We had to get more investment in capital equipment. We had to reduce or keep down the amount we borrowed overseas during the transition phase. Of course, if you borrow overseas-as this Government has-$100,000m in five and a bit years, you have to pay interest on that, and that makes recovery more difficult.

On all those matters-the productivity of the work force, investment in plant and equipment, holding down our overseas borrowings in the transition phase-this Government has not tackled any of the problems successfully. If we want to succeed as an economic country, if we want the standard of living of all Australians to rise, these are the problems we must tackle, and these are the problems the Government is failing to tackle.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

This paper in fact is a bundle of 22 treaties and I have them in my hand. It is the current practice of the Government that about twice a year a similar bundle of treaties is lobbed into the Senate, with little opportunity for effective scrutiny. In 1986 there were 30 new treaties, in 1987 there were 42, and so far this year there have been 44. I have 3 1/2 minutes to get through 22 treaties. It is very interesting that some of these treaties are conventions, which could oblige Australia to undertake certain tasks. In so doing the Government could utilise the external affairs power and ride roughshod over the rights of the various States.

I notice among the treaties that are before us today there is a Protocol of 1984 to amend the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, for example. The instrument of accession was deposited by Australia on 22 June 1988. The Protocol is not yet in force. There is a United Nations Convention on Contracts for International Sale of Goods, an instrument of accession deposited by Australia on 17 March 1988. Entry into force for Australia is 1 April 1989.

If a true opportunity were given by the Senate to discuss these matters, then that would not be so bad, but I doubt that there is anyone in the Government who could state with any degree of accuracy the actual number of international treaties to which Australia is a signatory and which are still current. My research reveals that since Federation Australia has signed 2,035 international treaties. Obviously some of these have expired, but most of these documents await discovery by a clever lawyer or an unscrupulous government to be employed as vehicles to underpin new Federal laws and actions which are designed to override the powers of the States. I do not want to anticipate debate on a notice of motion that I have before the chamber. Suffice to say that these considerations should be borne in mind when honourable senators from both sides of the chamber consider the letters that I have written to them about my notice of motion, which in effect would establish a Senate standing committee to study the implications for the legislative powers of the States of treaties proposed to be entered into-and those that have already been entered into-by the Commonwealth of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 November, on motion by Senator Puplick:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick spoke to the Australian National Gallery annual report 1987-88 on a previous occasion and I do not wish to go over the matters that he raised, except to endorse his comments about the interference by the then Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, in purchasing arrangements. The report indicates quite clearly that the Gallery has been very successful indeed with the exhibitions it has held. The significance of that, other than artistically, is what it has done for Canberra in attracting tourists. I was present at the Australian Capital Territory tourism awards night at which the Gallery had conspicuous success. In fact, it won the most popular tourist attraction award, the special event award for the `Old Masters: New Visions' exhibition, the award for tourism marketing of the ACT; and James Mollison received an award for the most outstanding contribution to tourism in the ACT. I think the Senate should note not only that the Gallery has been successful in winning these awards, but also that the people of Canberra appreciate what has been done.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also refers, on page 14, to late night openings and the fact that they have been resoundingly popular. I believe that some of Canberra's tourist facilities should be open later than is the case at present, because the hours between 9 a.m. and 5.30 p.m. are not particularly helpful to the industry. I hope that, in time, the Gallery can be opened on perhaps four nights a week and that it becomes very much a part of the evening program for the ACT. At least it does open one night a week at present and on other special occasions. I offer my congratulations to James Mollison and the Gallery on their contribution to tourism in Canberra, and I express the hope that it continues.
