That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not yet in any position to express a view formally on behalf of the Opposition about this particular matter, but simply draw attention to the fact that there are a large number of significant and as yet unanswered questions about the operation of the proposed Antarctic mineral resources regime. I understand that the Government has now put this matter forward for public comment and that it is not going to make a final decision on the matter until it has had the benefit of studying public comments on the treaty and on the related proposed minerals regime. We have already seen from within the Government some public expression of a degree of concern about this matter. A report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 November indicated the view, attributed to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who had written to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on this matter, that signature of the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities could involve some concession of our economic claims over the Antarctic, for virtually no reward to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a particular interest in the regime in the Antarctic because in 1980 I was a member of the Australian delegation which participated in the negotiation of the regime which led to the signing of the convention for the conservation of marine living natural resources. In fact, together with Mr Jacobi, the then member for Hawker, I was one of the two members of the Australian Parliament who actually signed that treaty, together with Ambassador Brennan. As a result, I have followed very closely the development of the minerals convention over many years under the chairmanship of Mr Beeby from New Zealand and have paid a great deal of attention to the working papers that have come out of the various international conferences, culminating in the final conference of treaty parties in Wellington in May.

I might also draw attention to the fact that my colleague the member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith, has recently published a lengthy document dealing with the Antarctic minerals regime and has put forward within the Opposition parties a detailed paper on this regime in which he expressed his own views about the convention. I have no doubt that Mr Smith's paper will provide the Opposition with a great deal of material to discuss as it formulates its view about whether Australia should enter into full participation under this treaty.

In the very brief time that is available, I do not have the opportunity to canvass what I think are the many deficiencies in the text of the Final Report and the Final Act of the Fourth Special Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting on Antarctic Mineral Resources or those in the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities. Nor will I have time to comment on the press statement on this matter issued by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on 22 November. I simply say that it should not be assumed at this stage that the Opposition is entirely satisfied with the text and indeed with the assurances which have been given.

I am grateful for the fact that the Government has made it clear that, in tabling this convention, its aim is to promote community discussion. I hope that that will be genuine community discussion and that the views of people who might have some concern about this matter will be capable of being taken into consideration before the Government makes a final decision on it. It is of enormous significance, although I think very few people in Australia would appreciate that. It proposes a quantum change in the nature of activities to take place on the Antarctic continent which, if not properly controlled and properly regulated, may have the most devastating consequences for all of us. There is a threshold question of whether any such activity should be permitted and, if it is permitted, under what terms and conditions. I look forward to participating in the public and community discussion which should take place on this very important subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to speak to the Final Report and the Final Act of the Fourth Special Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting on Antarctic Mineral Resources. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) said, these documents are the result of six years of negotiations by the Antarctic treaty consultative parties, which were done to develop a regime to govern any commercial mineral activity which might be proposed in Antarctica in the future. Since 1977 a policy of voluntary restraint has applied in respect of commercial exploration for and exploitation of minerals in the Antarctic.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1981 the Antarctic treaty consultative parties began negotiating a convention for the regulation of mineral activity, and the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities is the result. Conservation groups, of course, were not party to the negotiations. The document sets out a legal framework for the conduct of prospecting and exploration for and exploitation of minerals in the Antarctic. It will, if accepted, replace the moratorium on mining and, if ratified, will facilitate the exploitation of mineral deposits in the Antarctic.

Although the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has stated that the aim of the convention was to establish a structure for dealing with future mineral discoveries and not to encourage present mineral activities, there is considerable room for doubt, given the strength of those treaty nations which are strongly pro-mining. In fact, I believe that this convention could be the thin end of the wedge for the destruction of the Antarctic.

The preamble to the convention makes reference to the concern of the Antarctic treaty states to protect the Antarctic environment, its scientific value and its wilderness qualities. Again, there is cause for concern in this respect; exploration activity will certainly cause damage to the environment. The continent's fragile and unique wilderness will suffer irreversible damage if wide-scale mining takes place. The convention does not, in its present form, contain specific and detailed provisions relating to the protection of the environment. Furthermore, the liability provisions are imprecise.

Let me remind honourable senators that the Antarctic is much more than an el dorado of mineral deposits; it is the world's last great continental wilderness, the coldest and driest place on earth, covering 10 per cent of the world's surface. Ninety-eight per cent of the continent is covered by an icecap two kilometres thick. The Antarctic and the surrounding Southern Ocean comprise a unique and fragile environment supporting marine and bird life as well as Antarctic vegetation about which very little is still known.
Recommendations and conventions negotiated since the Antarctic Treaty came into force in June 1961 have strengthened--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: CENSUS AND STATISTICS AMENDMENT (VOLUNTARY PROVISION OF SURVEY INFORMATION) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Sheil:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue my remarks, albeit very briefly, on the private member's Bill that Senator Sheil has introduced into the Senate-the Census and Statistics Amendment (Voluntary Provision of Survey Information) Bill 1988. It provides that survey information be provided voluntarily rather than compulsorily. Senator Sheil was concerned enough to introduce this Bill because of the shonky, intrusive and absolutely outrageous Australian Bureau of Statistics survey that was foisted upon the people of Australia this year. I just hope that if this Bill is passed here and, by some quirk of fate, passed in the other place, it is, unlike many of the other Bills mentioned earlier today by Senators Macklin and Puplick, proclaimed. As I said before, this intrusive survey was foisted upon the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a most burdensome and highly intrusive survey. They are not my words; they are the words of the Assistant Statistician in a minute paper he sent to the Deputy Statistician. I repeat that he said this is a most burdensome and highly intrusive survey that has caused all sorts of concerns particularly to old people around the country. Before the matter was adjourned, I was speaking about the numbers of people who had contacted my office and had gone to the offices of honourable senators complaining about the complicated and highly intrusive nature of this survey. It is clear that the due processes of Parliament are being ignored by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. There are those who argue that the material which the survey provides is vital to the nation. I cannot, for the life of me, see why families should be required, without any choice, to reveal details of their house mortgages, Bankcard loans, or how much they spend at a supermarket, to any individual or bureaucracy. It is virtually impossible to guarantee that the information provided remains private.

I know that the Australian Democrats have shared this concern in respect of the identification card. The people of Australia showed the Government what they thought of the ID card because they did not trust the Government to guarantee confidentiality. We had the same concern with the pharmaceutical benefits changes. A major concern on that related to information given by pharmacists and doctors to bureaucrats. I am not at all against procuring statistics for proper purposes. As a farmer I know the value of stock and crop returns. I have filled them out all my life in business. I know that every farmer around Australia fills these out in good faith. It is compulsory to do so. I suppose the reason that it is compulsory in this case is that farmers are known to be a bit lazy on paperwork and such matters. But the questions asked of farmers are not intrusive; they are purely fact finding questions that I do not believe they object to. The data taken from these is used effectively.

The people of Australia have had this particular compulsory household survey thrust upon them. It requires them to give details that they do not want to give. How do we know that the people who are required to do this against their will will give the correct answers? I know that I would not give details that I did not want to give. The Bureau of Statistics is likely to receive information that it does not require. Therefore, the survey falls over. It is far better to conduct a survey with the cooperation of the people. Senator Sheil is to be congratulated on bringing in a Bill that will make details provided in surveys voluntary rather than compulsory.

I am sure that many people in our community would provide this information on a voluntary basis if they thought it was in the interests of bettering our system. I am sure there are many public-minded people who would give this information voluntarily rather than being bludgeoned into doing so by a very intrusive survey. It is imperative that any future surveys conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics be voluntary regardless of the possible effect that may have on the survey. The people have the right to choose whether they wish to reveal their personal details.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a most unfortunate and foolish proposal contained in this Census and Statistics Amendment (Voluntary Provision of Survey Information) Bill. It is particularly unfortunate and foolish in that it will strike down and destroy the powers, such as they are, and penalties given to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) that were set in place by John Howard in 1981. I will quote from the second reading speech made by the then Treasurer in the House of Representatives in 1981. The particular paragraph that--
—You have gone right overboard on what was designed in 1981 and you know it.

—I do not understand the relevance of that interjection. The particular quote from John Howard's second reading speech on the necessary balance to be struck between the essential collection of accurate data for all government of whatever political persuasion and personal privacy is as relevant today as it was in 1981. The relevance of his statement is that a major overhaul was conducted of the entire Bureau of Statistics leading up to that legislation in 1981-it was not a minor Bill. When that Bill was introduced in 1981 by John Howard, who was then responsible for the operations of the ABS, he provided the powers and penalties which this Bill now seeks to strike down. I think that it is a foolish proposal. It is also based on utter and complete nonsense. I refer to a press release issued by Senator Sheil on 30 May 1988 wherein he laid down the reason and justification for this legislation. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sheil drew up the Bill following suggestions that 14,000 Australian families were to be selected for a random health survey that would inquire into their sex lives, even to the extent of asking if and when they used condoms.

That statement, like so many issued by Senator Sheil, is utter and complete nonsense-it was then and it is now. What is irresponsible and contemptible about the statement by Senator Sheil is that the Australian Bureau of Statistics had categorically refuted this nonsense prior to Senator Sheil issuing this press release and subsequent press releases, and that factual information was completely ignored by Senator Sheil. The basis on which he launched this was about as good as the basis on which he condemned the Department of Administrative Services for failing to pay his staff.

It is relevant to consider how the Australian Bureau of Statistics works because of the profound ignorance Senator Sheil has shown in this matter as a result of some of the other statements he has made. The same press release went on to say:

`The situation is right out of hand', said Senator Sheil. `We have groups of outside bodies riding their own hobby-horses and using the power of the ABS to require compulsory answers to their questions.
That is absolute nonsense, as I will demonstrate in a moment. Senator Sheil went on in a further press release dated 2 June 1988 to say:
The Australian Bureau of Statistics is being `used' by unions and self-interest groups . . .

Again, that is nonsense. It might be of benefit to members of the Senate to understand how the ABS operates. It does not have the untrammelled powers suggested by Senator Sheil. It is not the subject of outside interest groups and hobbyhorses. It acts in a very precise way which is regulated by this Parliament. In respect of the operations of the ABS, the statistical collection of data is carried out under specific legislative authority. It is not the open-ended and free rein exercise of untrammelled power that Senator Sheil suggests. The Census and Statistics Act 1905 provides in part that the Statistician:
may from time to time collect such statistical information in relation to the matters prescribed for the purposes of this Section as he or she considers appropriate.

Prescribed matters are listed in statistics regulations that are subject to the disallowance of this House. Amongst other matters, they include population and the social, economic and demographic characteristics of the population; health, health services and quarantine; social and welfare services; housing; and income, expenditure and savings in relation to a person, household or family. In addition, subsection 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 provides that each new proposal for the collection of information has to be laid before both Houses of Parliament before its implementation-which is also subject to disallowance.

There is a further control that is exercised on the way in which the ABS conducts its business. Obviously this has completely escaped the attention of Senator Sheil in all the years he has served in the Senate. The ABS does not rely on people riding hobbyhorses or on private interest groups. It relies on the Australian Statistics Advisory Council. That Council, which consists of representatives of all States and the Northern Territory, community organisations and businesses, advises the ABS on exactly what information it shall collect. The advice it offers to the ABS is tabled in this Parliament every year. I understand that those reports have been tabled in this Parliament every year since 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —They weren't tabled this year.

—They might not have been tabled this year, but the Bureau is required to table an annual report. The Australian Statistics Advisory Council has advised successive Treasurers, including John Howard, as to how the ABS conducts its business. I go on to deal with a piece of absolute nonsense contained in a press release issued by Senator Sheil, and from which I shall quote.
—You had better get back in your seat or I will call a point of order on you.
—I would have hoped that Senator Patterson would treat the debate a little more seriously. I quote Senator Sheil:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the current laws there is no limit on the subjects, detail, and frequency of ABS surveys. People can be required to supply an unlimited amount of personal information to collectors who have such sweeping powers that they can even force their way into private premises and seize documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right; they can.

—I am delighted that Senator Sheil has interjected. I think that it is appalling that a senator can introduce legislation into a parliament based on such profound ignorance. The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not have, nor has it ever had, any power to enable it to force its way into private premises.
—It has.
—It has no power whatsoever to do that. Senator Sheil is compounding his ignorance. The ABS has no power to seize documents, nor has it ever had any such power.
—You are the repository of all information, are you?

—I will respond to that interjection. People do not have to be particularly intelligent or the possessor of all knowledge to understand that, because the powers of the ABS are extremely limited indeed, as are the penalties. All that the ABS has the power to do is to require persons to answer its questions. If they do not do so, those persons are subject to a fine. It is outrageous nonsense to suggest that it has the power to force its way into premises.
—Where did you do your research?

—Senator, I challenge you, as you will have the opportunity to do, to rise in this debate, instead of continually interjecting, and cite to me the section of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act which gives the powers to the ABS which the senator who introduced this legislation said it has. I say again categorically, despite the continued ignorance displayed by Senator Knowles and Senator Sheil, that the ABS has no power to forcibly enter premises or to seize documents, and has never had those powers. It does Senator Sheil no credit to continue to interject with absolute nonsense when he is the person who has the carriage of introducing this unfortunate Bill into the Senate. The fact is that the powers possessed by the ABS and the penalties for non-compliance were introduced into the Parliament by John Howard, the then Minister responsible for the ABS in 1981. The same press release went on to compound the nonsense by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sheil's stand against the controversial Census Act is certain to gain wide public support, especially in view of this week's claim that Australians could soon be forced to take compulsory blood tests and divulge details of their sex lives.

That statement is nonsense. To indicate just how much nonsense it is, it may be of some interest to Senator Sheil to know the genesis of that claim. Claims were made some time ago, I think originally by the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties, that the ABS was proposing to take these steps. A number of national newspapers published those claims without bothering to check with the ABS whether the claims were correct. The ABS went to the Press Council of Australia and complained. I can assure honourable senators, from personal experience, that it is not an easy matter to persuade the Press Council, which has as a fundamental tenet freedom of the press, to recommend that a newspaper print a retraction. On this occasion the Australian Bureau of Statistics succeeded and all of the eight major national newspapers that had published this nonsense were subsequently required by the Press Council to publish retractions.

The reality is that a number of interest groups-and this occurs constantly-have suggested that such intrusive questions be asked. People are always suggesting to the ABS that various questions be asked. However, at no time has the ABS ever made a decision that such questions would be asked. I have described precisely the very strict legislative requirements that are placed on the ABS in relation to the asking of questions. It has a national advisory council which considers all such requests. That council's reports are tabled annually in this Parliament. Further, the ABS has prescribed legislative guidelines for what goes in the surveys, which guidelines have to be tabled in this House and are then subject to disallowance. In the face of that regime, Senator Sheil says that the ABS is, in fact, ridden by private groups with hobbyhorses and that it has untrammelled power to ask people the most intrusive of questions. I think I have adequately demonstrated that the statement that Senator Sheil has just made is utter nonsense.

The ABS has never proposed to take blood samples from 14,000 Australians. It never proposed to ask people about their sex lives. It never proposed to ask people whether or not they used condoms. That was never a proposal of the ABS. It is on that false foundation that Senator Sheil has, on his own account, brought this foolish legislation into the Parliament. I must say that I am profoundly disappointed that, with very little thought at all, I would think, the Opposition has elected to support Senator Sheil's legislation, with its fundamental problems for any ensuing Australian government-which I will describe in a minute-and by so doing to strike down the very foundations on which the ABS operates, which were introduced into the House of Representatives by John Howard, as Treasurer, in 1981.

I shall quote from the second reading speech of the then Treasurer in 1981, when he introduced this legislation that Senator Sheil wants to destroy, a statement that is as fundamentally correct now as it was then. This is what John Howard said during the second reading debate on the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981:

This area brings very much into focus one of the problems that any government faces, that is, balancing principles and conflicting priorities. I dare say that if we carried out a survey of a cross-section of the Australian community and we said to those people: ``Do you believe that governments should be well informed and should have available to them a wide range of information about the habits, the wants, the desires, the assets and the capabilities of the Australian community on which to base, in a sound way, government decisions?'' the overwhelming majority of the people surveyed would simply say ``yes'' to that proposal as being self evidently valid. I suggest that if we asked an equally representative group of Australians this question: ``Do you believe that governments should ask a lot of questions about your life, should ask intrusive questions, should pry into what you do, should want to know more and more about what you do?'' the answer to that question would be an equally resounding ``no''. That in a sense is the problem that any government has in this area.

What we have tried to do is to balance those two aspirations as much as we possibly can. Of course we need information. Of course governments have to ask questions, whatever political persuasion they are. Of course we need sound statistical data on which to base our decisions in whatever area those decisions are. But equally there is a growing and legitimate community resentment towards over-intrusive government . . .

In response to interjections from honourable senators opposite about the non-relevance of the statements that John Howard made in 1981, I point out that the statement I have just read is as relevant today as it was then. As I have said before, the basis on which Senator Sheil has introduced this legislation is factual nonsense. He has continued to assert that factual nonsense during this debate. There will be a health survey conducted in 1989. It will be conducted under prescriptive guidelines that will have to be tabled in this Parliament and will be subject to the disallowance of this Parliament. There will be no blood tests--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't they put this one in?

—I will discuss that in due course. There will be no blood tests, no questions will be asked about people's sex lives, and there will be no questions asked about condoms-and nor were there ever going to be.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of this supposed wave of complaints and resentment from the community, again the facts might be useful in this debate rather than the fiction that Senator Sheil is peddling. Less than one one- hundredth of one per cent of all the people questioned in any of the surveys that the ABS has ever conducted have had to be directed to respond to the questions. For all the population censuses that have been conducted, that is, involving 16 million Australians, a total of 39 people have been prosecuted for not providing information. In relation to labour force statistics, 35,000 households are surveyed every month by the ABS for those essential figures. Out of those 35,000 households, eight people have been prosecuted in five years. As to the household expenditure survey that has come up for so much attention just recently, the number of people prosecuted has been nil. These figures relate to the total number of surveys undertaken. They do not relate just to last year or the year before; these are total, historical surveys. In relation to the national health surveys the number of people prosecuted has been nil, as was the case in relation to all other national household surveys.

I turn now to the problems that will be caused by this legislation not just for this Government but for any government that is properly trying to deliver services and public resources where they are needed most. If the compulsion is removed completely from providing information it will particularly affect the corporate sector, the private sector, the individual sector. This applies equally to the corporate sector. Senator Sheil might be interested to know that it is a fact that in Australia about 1,000 companies in total provide about 60 per cent of the entire gross domestic product of this country. Some 1,000 companies provide that information. Many of them would choose not to provide it if it was not compulsory, not because they were trying to hide anything but because, it is acknowledged-and no-one tries to pretend that it is not-it is inconvenient for those companies and it costs them some time and trouble to provide that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —And money.

—I said time and trouble, and I concede quite freely that it costs them money. A direct and substantial community benefit is derived-an essential benefit. I might add that among the figures that would be rendered useless if those companies were not compelled to provide the information-and this legislation would remove that compulsion-would be the consumer price index figures. The average weekly earnings figures, which are essential for proper social planning in this country and the provision of social resources to people who need them most, and the retail sales figures which are so vital, would be destroyed. The reason is obvious, and I would have thought that it would be obvious even to Senator Sheil: if the information is not compulsory and is provided, as Senator Calvert suggests, only by people who want to provide it, that will result in a gross bias in the reliability of the figures. It is obvious that a group that chooses not to provide information will be distinctly different from a group that does provide it. That would render the surveys statistically useless. In fact, it would render them useless to the point of it not being worth collecting the information.

SPEECH.PARA: With the greatest respect, I suggest to Senator Sheil that, as John Howard said, quite correctly, in 1981 when he introduced the legislation that Senator Sheil is now trying to strike down, it is essential for governments to be possessed of accurate statistical data. It is essential that the ABS be possessed of the very limited powers that it has-and it has never had any other-that is, the requirement for people to answer the questions and fining people if they do not. It is essential for the ABS to be provided with those powers. If not, and people simply choose not to provide the information, statistically, as any polling company will say-Senator Sheil should go to his own research people for advice on this-the information that would result would literally not be worth collecting. We would have no reliable figures on the CPI or on average weekly earnings, on which so many government decisions are based, and we would have absolutely no reliable information on retail sales. The reality is that all of the series of economic surveys done by the ABS and all of the series of social research and data collection done by the ABS would be fundamentally destroyed by this proposal.

I will give honourable senators opposite the benefit of the doubt, but there has been a knee-jerk reaction to this Bill of Senator Sheil's: people have been prepared to accept at face value the assertion that he has continued to make in this debate that the ABS is empowered with ASIS-like powers to knock down doors, to forcibly enter premises-to quote Senator Sheil again-and to compulsorily acquire documents. It has no such powers. I am sure that honourable senators opposite have simply accepted the very foundation on which Senator Sheil has based this legislation-that the ABS was proposing to ask people about their sex lives and about their use of condoms-when in fact it was proposing to do absolutely nothing of the sort. The very premise on which this legislation is based is fundamentally flawed.

I would ask the Opposition and certainly the Australian Democrats to consider at this late stage not supporting this legislation. It will totally destroy the fundamental avenue that all governments of any persuasion need in directing scarce resources to that area of the Australian community where they are required most. I think it is unfortunate that Senator Sheil has brought into this House a piece of legislation which dramatically and radically alters the fundamentally sound basis on which the ABS was set up by John Howard, as its responsible Minister, in 1981, which will substantially-I think totally would be more accurate-destroy its ability to collect statistically useful and reliable information, and which thereby will greatly disadvantage the community of Australia, through governments of whatever persuasion, in providing scarce public resources to the areas of our community that need them most.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Census and Statistics Amendment (Voluntary Provision of Survey Information) Bill, introduced by Senator Sheil, which seeks to provide for the voluntary provision of information under the Census and Statistics Act. Clearly, we are not discussing the total introduction of voluntary exercise with regard to all of the activities of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Indeed, Senator Sheil accepts that there should be available to the Bureau the ability to compel people to answer questions with regard to the census. Of course, the difficulty statistically is that the census is not defined under the Act, and in that sense Senator Sheil's Bill would probably end up failing on that technicality alone; and the Government, using the notion of the census, could reintroduce the material as a census exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: That apart, I think we have to see clearly, that, if Senator Sheil is happy for compulsion to be used in the census part of surveys, but not in other parts, the distinction is not with regard to whether citizens should be compelled to answer questions but with regard to what questions they should be compelled to answer. That is a slightly different philosophical basis from the one I thought Senator Sheil was arguing in his second reading speech.

I think everybody acknowledges-indeed, Senator Collins, in reading out Mr Howard's second reading speech on the introduction of census legislation in 1981, made it clear-that any responsible government must have information upon which it is able to base its policy determinations. I would like to spend a little time on that fundamental proposition, because I think some of the things that have been said in this debate cast some doubt on it. One thread that runs through the Estimates committee reports on this year's Budget, the questions asked at Question Time and the questions placed on notice is the demanding from government of information.

The reason we believe we can demand information from government is that we believe that the Government ought to have that information before it makes a decision. Indeed, if it went ahead and made a decision in the absence of information, it would be condemned not only by people outside but, I am sure, by everybody in the Opposition. To suggest that governments ought to legislate or ought to engage in policy decision making in the absence of information is to promote an irrationality that I am quite sure nobody in here would want to adhere to. So we want two things-and I believe Senator Sheil agrees with both: first, that governments ought to be able to compel people to answer questions-Senator Sheil has accepted that, as seen by the mention of the census in the legislation-and, secondly, that the Government needs information and ought to gather it so that it can properly base its policy and decision making processes.

What Senator Sheil is objecting to is a particular exercise-the household expenditure survey. I think we ought to go to the analysis of that because, if what we have said so far is correct, there is a dispute not about whether the Government ought to have the ability to compel people to answer questions, but about which questions people ought to be compelled to answer. It is interesting to look back in this exercise to 1905, as I had the misfortune to do. I am not sure why I had to do this unfortunate exercise; I think I was not in the party room at the time and I ended up with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I drew the short straw, too.

—Senator Collins drew the short straw as well. This legislation started in 1905. Even at that early stage compulsion was built in. The requirement to get information was obviously felt to be important even at that early stage in our Federal history. This is not something that has arisen recently; it has been going on for quite some time.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1905 the Bureau was basically looking at the census part. This is included in Senator Sheil's second reading speech and, by implication, in his amending Bill, because he does not seek to take away the compulsion in that area. In addition to the census which it said shall be taken, the statistical information also had to be collected and at that stage the legislation said, `The Statistician shall, if the Minister so directs by notice in writing, collect such statistical information in relation to the matters so prescribed as is specified in the notice'. In other words, it was a fairly open-ended exercise in 1905. A Minister, when needing some information, could merely direct the Statistician to nip out and talk to the three or four cows wandering around, ask them what they thought and then provide the information to the Minister. One would imagine that in 1905 the amount of information that would successfully have been able to be acquired, processed and used in policy determination would have been quite small. But as the years went on we had a series of amending Bills. One of those Bills occurred in 1975 and in it was mentioned a very interesting body which does not seem to have been mentioned in the debate so far-the Australian Statistics Advisory Council. The functions of the Council are:
To advise the Minister and the Statistician in relation to-
(a) the improvement, extension and co-ordination of statistical services provided for public purposes in Australia;
(b) annual and longer term priorities and programs of work that should be adopted in relation to major aspects of the provision of those statistical services; and
(c) any other matter relating generally to those statistical services.
That seems to me to have been an excellent suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I talked about it for 10 minutes.

—I am sorry, Senator, but I was otherwise engaged. Indeed, it is a suggestion that might be able to be taken up with regard to these particular propositions and concerns. In following up these concerns that Statistics Advisory Council would seem an appropriate body to be involved. In addition, amendments were made which required the tabling of various documents. I think that all honourable senators in this place, if they manage to keep all the stuff, probably have bulging files somewhere of all the material generated by Don Cameron before he left for other climes-material which is obviously still being generated by his office in his absence because it is still being pumped out.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned with the legality or otherwise of the current exercise. While I know that some members and senators were quite happy to go on radio and tell people that they should not fill the questionnaires in, when I was asked that particular question, being a slightly more cautious person, I said, `I am not about to suggest that people should break the law of the land'. Quite frankly, whether it is legal or not is not a matter for this chamber to determine unless we wish, in fact, to pass amending legislation. It is a matter for the courts to determine. There are processes for bringing that particular aspect before the courts. I understand that if the matter is not before the courts, the process has been put in train, and several lawyers are now earning their incomes from it. That is the way the matter should proceed. That is where finally the legality of the exercise will have to be tested. I have read several opinions from several sources. Obviously, those opinions will be used and be grist to the mill for the final resolution through the courts.

I would have thought that in terms of a procedure that should have been followed, the proposal should have been tabled. I really do not think that there is any need to go round splitting hairs quite so finely as has been done. Why not inform the Parliament of the types of things that go on? We are kept informed of a lot of other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was tabled in 1984.

—But this particular proposal was not tabled. I do not wish to rehash the whole aspect of whether it was legal or not-I do not want to buy into that argument-but really there did not seem to be a great deal of reason as to why the Bureau did not table it. I think it could quite well have done so, even if it had been done in a way, as it were, over and above what it felt its technical requirements demanded. I think that it would obviously have made things a lot easier. I think that we might have an excess of feeling in regard to that in future.
—What you are going to get is an excess of paper.

—I think that the Bureau will be doing a lot more tabling than it has done in the past. Hopefully, if senators in this place are doing their job, they can pursue those matters. However, I have the distinct feeling that if the Bureau tables the proposal no-one will actually read it. That will actually negate one of the arguments for tabling. That tabling probably would have helped the Bureau and probably now it regrets having acted in the way it did. Knowing the number of pieces of paper that are in my room, I know that I would not have been dashing to the chamber to grab hold of the tabled proposal myself.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings us to the current survey for which there have been a series of arrangements made over time for the collection of information. I must admit that I find myself in some difficulties here because I am not trained as a statistician. I have sought advice with regard to the statistical base of information collected on a voluntary basis. I would incline to the proposition, if we want to put it in these terms, that there should be voluntary compliance in regard to the collection of a lot of the information, under particular conditions. The difficulty was that when I suggested that to some statisticians I was roundly taken to task for suggesting such a thing. My suggestion was that where there was voluntary compliance and people did not comply then the sample should be redrawn in such a way as to enable one to comply with the original sample. I was told that that was utter nonsense.

As I say, I am not a statistician so I was not able to say whether that proposition was nonsense or not. However, I know that there has in fact been a much higher response to the current survey than to the 1984 survey. Presumably this is as a result of Senator Sheil's activities. Therefore, he may in fact have assisted the compliance rather than prevented the compliance. I do not know what other difference there is between now and then, other than people making a lot of noise about this survey. Presumably, that is why the response to the survey has gone up. Indeed, the response has gone up so far that 97 per cent of households have actually complied. I know that that is a fairly high compliance rate because I used to engage in surveys from time to time. I know that if I had got anything like a response of 97 per cent I would have said, `I will go home now, I have got enough'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not doing the survey for the Government.

—No, I was not. However, the statisticians who were working with me on surveys were quite happy if they managed to drag in 50 per cent. I would have thought that the Government and the statisticians would be quite happy with the type of return they are getting at the moment. If one looks at the number of times the Bureau has actually bothered to prosecute anyone under the Census Act one will realise that it would not bother to prosecute people who do not respond to this survey either simply because the costs involved in prosecution are not commensurate with the types of returns the Bureau would get. In fact, the Bureau would not significantly boost its returns nor boost the reliability of the information it gets by prosecuting people. I am trying to say in a practical sense that I cannot see the Bureau involving itself in any exercise which would lead to a prosecution of citizens in this area if the compliance rate of 97 per cent continues.

SPEECH.PARA: The total number of people to be surveyed is equivalent to one household in every thousand households. I have looked at the survey material. The material concerned is quite voluminous in terms of the number of pieces of paper that one gets. However, when one actually starts to go through and answer the questions one can actually skip quite a number of pages here and there for quite a variety of reasons. Nevertheless, I think that answering the survey would take quite some considerable time. I must admit that one would need a very good system of bookkeeping at home in order to be able to comply with the survey in a meaningful way. I suppose that is the guts of my worry. I am concerned that while we may be getting 97 per cent compliance, what is it that we are getting in that 97 per cent? Originally the premise of my surveys was that I wanted information. However, my worry at the moment is what type of information we might be getting out of this survey because the material is so voluminous. I wonder whether there may be other methods, for example, surveying a variety of households with only part of the material. I know the difficulty there lies in the cross-tabulations which are also necessary for information purposes. In other words, we want to know for information purposes, for example, how many families rely on social security.

I will give an example. Many years ago I conducted a number of surveys on education in my own State. I found out some alarming things about education and its provision. I did not even look at the schools; I looked at the homes. I found in my own city of Brisbane that the so-called high-class or costly suburbs had on average a little less that two children per household. Suburbs such as Senator Sheil's St Lucia, Kenmore and so on had fewer than two children per household. However, those households had three to four bedrooms. However, if one then went across to Inala, essentially a post-war Housing Commission development, one found that on average there were households of one to two bedrooms but with the number of children going up to over six. What that says about education provision is that no matter what we do in the schools the children at home do not have anywhere to study. One can see immediately from those statistics that, regardless of anything else, what is required is a significant boost in Inala to enable those children to have parity of educational opportunity. What I am saying is that even from that minimal data one can devise policy directions that could have significant impacts on people. Without the data, one would be floating to be able to pinpoint the type of policy direction heeded.

I make it very clear that the Australian Democrats support very strongly the work of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the notion that it ought to be able to collect data. We believe that the Bureau ought to have the power to compel people to respond. I know that at the end of the day one is very concerned about this. There is a great deal of concern about two matters. The first is the inordinate length of time for which the Bureau keeps its material before it is destroyed. The Act says quite explicitly that that material has to be entered and then destroyed. However, when one looks at how long it takes before the actual paper containing people's names is destroyed, one sees that it sometimes stretches into years. Why is that material kept when the data was entered long ago? No good reason has been given. There were some mutterings about computer failure and so on, but obviously once one has got the backups one is all right. I find that a great worry.

My second worry concerns the Government's move to use various instrumentalities either to fundraise or to pay for part of their operations by selling material. We now find the Bureau is involved in this activity. Do not get me wrong; I am not averse to the Bureau collecting data and selling it. I think that if we have the data we should use it. It is absurd even to collect it if we do not intend to use it. However, the problem is that an invitation is offered to the Bureau to use its powers of compulsion to collect information which it then sells as a commercial product to the private sector, because the private sector does not have the powers of compulsion to collect that type of information. I think that that could and should be catered for-it is not catered for in the Act-by a specific requirement that the collection of data must always be for the purpose of policy development by governments; in other words, if the Bureau is not able to justify the collection of that data for its primary role, it cannot collect it. That would rule out questions such as the brand of toothpaste, lawnmower or whatever people use. A lot of that is profitable information. After all, a lot of bodies in the community, without compulsory powers, collect such material. The Bureau could get into that area, using its compulsory powers-there is nothing in the Act which prevents that; that is where the Act could and should be strengthened-rather than our going down the avenue that Senator Sheil suggests.

What we should do is look at the problems in 1988 with information gathering and collection. One way of dealing with it is Senator Sheil's method of moving away from compulsion to a voluntary exercise. I am not convinced by the arguments put so far-I think that there will be other speakers on the Opposition side-as to how we will still be able to provide the database that I know I and my colleagues want. I know that I want that data because I want government to make a decision based on facts. I find it very difficult to say, on behalf of my party, that we are quite happy to go to a voluntary exercise. I acknowledge Senator Sheil's concerns. I have expressed the same concerns publicly and have suggested that possibly one way of handling the matter is by voluntary exercise, as Senator Sheil suggests. However, in reviewing the information, I must admit that the first position I took I have now had to change. At the moment I cannot see that if we move down this line I can still get the type of data that I believe government should have.

The Opposition says that it will be in government by the end of next year. It will be looking for this type of data in terms of its ongoing policy decision making. Every government must do that if it is not going to simply fly blind. I have not yet heard how we will protect the database-I am quite sure that the Opposition wants it as much as does the Government-under the voluntary exercise that is suggested in the Bill. I wonder whether subsequent Opposition speakers might address that. I would certainly be very interested in listening to their arguments for the protection of the database.

Honourable senators know, from our stance on the privacy legislation, that my Party does not want to be involved in an exercise which intrudes on privacy. Indeed, that is why we opposed the tax file number system, although it was accepted by the Opposition. The Opposition says that it wants the information to be given voluntarily. We have not seen whether that will be the case with higher education. The Bill which the Opposition said it will accept makes it compulsory, so I will be looking with interest at the support that it may have for our amendment, designed to make it a voluntary exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have the money up-front you will not have a need to give the information.

—The honourable senator might be able to do that but, as she well knows, other people in the community do not have such funds. Many women supporting children and trying to educate themselves do not have such funds. They have to be able to do so, as it were, on the never never. Senator Patterson knows that as well as I do. Since 1972, when the fees were abolished, women have used higher education progressively to move themselves within the community. That is particularly so in single parent families where women have other responsibilities and seek to move from an area of dependency into an area of work. Rather than putting disadvantages and hurdles in their way, we should be encouraging them to do that. They will not be able to pay up-front, so they will be compelled to give their tax file number. All along we have supported the privacy principle. I accept the privacy argument: I think that it is a powerful one. That is why I suggested that my concern about privacy is the non-destruction of material by the Bureau for such a long period. The longer the material stays around, the more it must leave open the possibility of abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless the Opposition is able to come up with some more cogent reasons as to how we can protect the data base that is required by government for decision making, I cannot see how we can go to a voluntary exercise. The other problem I have with a voluntary exercise-as I say, it may be that there are statisticians in the Opposition who have yet to speak-is that it has been clearly conveyed to me through information provided to me that the type of voluntary procedure that I have suggested in the past is a non-goer in statistical terms. All I am able to do is simply take that advice-that one would not be able to conduct a statistically valid survey under those conditions. In relation to those two points I will be listening carefully to subsequent speakers. At the moment I cannot see how we can support the proposition that the exercise be voluntary, although I believe that other amendments should be made by government to follow through the types of things that Senator Sheil has raised.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two minutes of my time left. I thought I had completed my speech before tea but I noticed in my notes that there was one item that I had failed to raise. I would like Senator Sheil to have the opportunity to respond to that point when he sums up at the end of the second reading debate. It concerns the information from corporations which is used by the Government in a whole series of Acts, particularly those governed by things such as average weekly earnings and the consumer price index (Quorum formed).
—Senator Macklin, your time has expired. Do you wish to seek leave to complete your remarks?

—I would like to raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, with regard to my time being consumed by a quorum call. I do not see how my time can be consumed if the House is not in session.
—It is a sad fact of life that the clock continues regardless of quorum calls. I suggest that you seek leave to complete your remarks.
—I seek leave to speak for two minutes. However, I do not believe that there are any standing orders requiring that the clock do that. I believe that we should stop it during the forming of a quorum.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a difficulty I have so that Senator Sheil can respond to it. If corporations were to be in a situation where providing information to the Government was voluntary, presumably because of very large costs involved they would no longer do so. Under those circumstances many of the Acts which are written in such a way as to provide automatic increases based on average weekly earnings, movements in the consumer price index and so forth would not be able to operate. For example, the automatic rises provided to pensioners could no longer occur. I hope that Senator Sheil will be able to respond to this, the last of the three items I have difficulty with. If we cannot make all of those Acts work, particularly those which provide benefits to the citizens of this country, then we have to look at another method by which to bring into effect the types of things Senator Sheil is suggesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-People invented government to protect their privacy, not to invade it. The operations of the Australian Bureau of Statistics have expanded to such an extent now that they amount to an invasion of people's privacy. I thank honourable senators who have contributed to this debate. I also thank those who did not contribute to the debate in order that we could bring it to a vote. During Senator Macklin's analysis of the situation with regard to the Australian Bureau of Statistics he said that 98 per cent of the people involved in the household expenditure survey replied willingly to the questions. If that is the case why is the Bureau frightened of allowing the answers to be voluntary? If 98 per cent of the people are going to accept the survey, why not protect the other 2 per cent?
—Companies are not.
—I will deal with companies in a minute. Senator Collins should hang on. He stretched the truth so far in his contribution that I found it rather disgusting.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am not going to have my truthfulness alluded to in a deprecatory way. I found Senator Sheil's remark offensive and I ask him to withdraw it.
—On the point of order: I intend to prove that Senator Collins was stretching the truth. I have the quotes from the Act that he mentioned in his speech.
—Senator Sheil, it does strike me as being bordering on the offensive and being unparliamentary. I ask you to withdraw.

—I withdraw. I must say that Senator Macklin carried out a nice analysis of the situation. He reminded me of Senator McLean in his maiden speech, when he gave a very accurate analysis of the political situation in Australia and then came to the wrong conclusions. I think Senator Macklin has done the same thing with regard to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. As an example, I think of the way the Australian Democrats strove and fought to ensure privacy with regard to the tax file number, yet here we have the Australian Bureau of Statistics able to ask people to produce their income tax returns. There is a conflict there that should be addressed by people who are trying to analyse the Census and Statistics Amendment (Voluntary Provision of Survey Information) Bill 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to Senator Collins's remarks. He accused me of pushing emotional issues such as sexual habits, blood tests for people and other personal information. I would like to remind him that these items were under active consideration by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and its working party at the time the press releases he referred to were made. I am sure that it was only because of those press releases that the Bureau of Statistics withdrew from any inquiries into those personal areas. There have been only 38 prosecutions for failure to provide information to the Bureau, which is an indication to me that the Bureau has proceeded with only those prosecutions it felt it could win. It is an indication that it has withdrawn from many more prosecutions. Because of the activities of its officers, who were perhaps a little bit insensitive in questioning people, it decided not to go on with the cases. Nevertheless, the interviews by Bureau officers were an harassment and a threat to the households which were being subjected to survey.
I turn now to the powers of entry of the Australian Statistician. Senator Collins said that the Statistician has never had any powers to enter premises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forcible entry, I said.
—Yes, forcible entry. Section 18 (1) of the Census and Statistics Act 1905 states in respect of powers of entry:

SPEECH.PARA: The Statistician or an authorized officer may, at all reasonable times, enter any premises included in a prescribed class of premises for the purpose of-
(a) supplying persons with forms;
(b) collecting forms that have been supplied to persons; and
(c) making inquiries for the purpose of this Act.

The only place he cannot go into is a person's home or a place where he sleeps. So Senator Collins is completely wrong. He is creating emotional issues about the intent of the Bill. There is no intent in this Bill to deny the Bureau of Statistics access to figures which it requires to establish the indices upon which the information it provides to the Government is based.

The legislation is not intended to destroy the Bureau of Statistics, as claimed by Senator Collins. The Bureau can go ahead and ask all the questions it wants. All the Bill seeks to do is make survey questions voluntary for everything but the census itself, which I would have thought was perfectly reasonable. Under the Census and Statistics Act the Bureau can ask all the questions it wants of the corporate sector-a point that Senator Collins was worried about. When it comes to the consumer price index (CPI), average weekly earnings and pension increases, a far better solution would be for the Government to stop spending more than it earns and to stop causing an increase in the CPI. It should cut its expenditure and taxes and fix the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a census once every five years. Sometimes it even skips that to save money.

—Let us not confuse the census with what Senator Collins was talking about. The honourable senator was talking about the supply of statistics by the corporate sector. I am answering a question that Senator Macklin asked. All those statistics will be completely available to the Government, in accordance with the Census and Statistics Act. I was merely pointing out that if the Government behaved more responsibly, it would be better able to determine effectively the CPI, average weekly earnings and pension increases without invading the privacy of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin conceded that a powerful argument could be put forward in respect of privacy. I think it just depends on where one sits in this Parliament as to how powerful one thinks that argument is. For me, privacy is the most powerful consideration. As I said at the outset, government was invented to protect privacy, right up to and including the defence of the realm. But there has been a naked exercise of power by a public servant in that he attempted to carry out a compulsory survey without tabling in Parliament what he proposed to do. Not only that, he defended the situation and there has been no end of argument one way or the other about what has happened. It is fundamental that if he wants to make the answers to his questions compulsory, he has to table his intentions in the Parliament. By the way, there is no provision under which we can reject what he proposes. So why did he not propose it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, there is. It is subject to disallowance.
—I doubt if it is. I will check that out.
—It is.
—Oh, well, Senator Collins has talked so much rubbish in this chamber tonight that I cannot take his word for that either.
—Is that the best you can do?

—What I am putting forward is perfectly reasonable. I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I am sorry that Senator Macklin is not supporting the Bill, but perhaps not all the Australian Democrats feel the same way as he does. I see the issue as far more important than dividing it up into private and corporate sectors. I see it as an issue of privacy for people, which I consider important. The Democrats argued strongly for the protection of privacy in the Australia Card Bill and in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill. Yet, they do not display the same attitude when it comes to a perfectly reasonable request that will not deny the Australian Bureau of Statistics any information at all. In fact, the Bill will probably make it easier for the Bureau to operate. The Statistician himself says that when his officers are interviewing people in the field they act with delicacy and sensitivity. All they would have to do is act with a little bit more delicacy and sensitivity. If they conduct a slightly wider survey than they do at the moment all the figures that they want will be available to them. They just have to behave in the same way when obtaining information from the corporate sector. As a hospital proprietor, I supplied statistics to the Bureau of Statistics for years and I did not mind at all. I put them all in, as do many businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard Senator Calvert say tonight that most members of the agricultural community would be perfectly happy as part of their civic responsibility and duty to supply the Government with the figures it required. They do it voluntarily. But, no, the Government wants to make it compulsory. There must be a reason for that. I know what the reason is: the Government wants to indulge in social engineering. I am sure that the Hawke Government has been using the Bureau for this purpose. This is why it wants to persist with requiring compulsory answers to its questions. I just do not happen to believe in that sort of social engineering. I suppose it depends on one's political philosophy on just which side of the line one falls. My appeal is not an emotional one and it is not based on a whole lot of hysteria, as was claimed tonight in the Senate by Government speakers. I think I have explained the facts sufficiently well. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
