TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary memorandum for each Bill, flagging the amendments to be moved by the Government.

—by leave-Madam Temporary Chairman, I have just committed a most shameful act for a member or parliament, missing a division. I am overcome with shame-not shame to my side of the House but to the House as a whole. We politicians are very responsible people. What happened on this occasion was that the lift would not work. I have some evidence from a witness, Senator Devlin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not know whether I was waiting for the same lift as Senator Cooney, but I also was prevented by a lift from being present. The result of the division was probably unaffected. In effect we were paired.

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (SELF-GOVERNMENT) BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, and we have just dealt with amendment No. 26 moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Page 11, subclause 32 (5), leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(5) The Assembly, may, by resolution, request that Schedule 3 be amended by omitting a law from that Schedule.

``(5a) Any such resolution shall be laid before each House of the Parliament and the request therein shall be deemed to have been agreed to by the Parliament unless within fifteen sitting days either House pass a resolution declining so to agree.''

I have moved this amendment because it is appropriate that there is a convenient mechanism which is capable of being initiated by the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Assembly for the transfer of additional ordinances and inherited laws to that Assembly. It is also appropriate that the right to decline to transfer such a law should rest with this Parliament. In other words, the ACT Assembly should have a prima facie right to take over ordinances which it says belong to it. sub-clause (5a) is a protection for the Federal Parliament to stop this happening if that is the wish of Federal Parliament. So the initial decision would be with the ACT Assembly, but the right to veto would remain with this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Jenkins did not proceed with this amendment earlier but she is proceeding with it now. I believe that we dealt with this issue in relation to another amendment and I really do not think that I have anything to add to my earlier comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Page 12, clause 33, lines 1 to 22, leave out the clause.

This issue has already been canvassed at great length, but I believe that this is a matter of the greatest importance. I believe that the principle enshrined in the Government's Bill is wrong, and I believe that it should have been addressed in a separate self-contained Bill similar to that which has now been removed from the agenda. I believe that clauses 5 to 9 of my Bill would have taken care of this aspect and should have been transferred to this legislation. I do not expect to succeed because of what has happened previously but, because of its importance, I plan to call for a division if my amendment does not receive the support of either the Government or the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, I think we canvassed this issue before. The right of disallowance that is maintained here is the same right-no more and no less-as that retained in the Northern Territory. Yet here in the Australian Capital Territory there is obviously a greater imperative to keep it because, as I said earlier in the debate, it is here that we have the ultimate constitutional responsibility. It is worth noting that this power has never been used in the Northern Territory and here, where we have an even stronger right, I would imagine that we would almost always be able to deal with these matters by consultation and negotiation. I think it is a reasonable power to retain given our constitutional responsibility.

—Once again, as I have said to the Australian Democrats previously to this debate, our view is also that a cautious approach to self-government is sensible and, for the time being anyway, this security should remain in the Bill. As I said in my second reading stage speech, we do not necessarily lock ourselves into that position forever. We think that, perhaps after a certain period when the Bill and self-government have had a chance to apply in practice and they have both been found to be sound, some of these extra safeguards can be removed by amendment. At the moment, as I indicated, in adopting that cautious approach we would prefer to see the safeguard remain and therefore we are not prepared to support the amendment.

—After the recent referendum debates and the vote returned by the Australian people I guess I can understand the Government's point of view, but I find it hard to understand the Opposition's point of view. The Opposition campaigned very heavily on the side of States rights as opposed to rights being maintained by the Federal Parliament. Here the Australian Democrats are supporting territorial rights so that the Governor-General may not disallow an enactment after six months if he sees fit so to do. As I said before, if we do not gain the support of either the Government or the Opposition for this amendment I shall call for a division.

—Can someone explain to me precisely what clauses 33 and 34 mean? As I understand it, the Governor-General may within six months disallow an amendment. I assume that the fact of that disallowance would need to be placed before the Parliament. If that is the case, the Commonwealth Parliament would have the opportunity to overturn the Governor-General's disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not go before Parliament. The other point to make is that it is a pretty long bow to draw for Senator Jenkins to equate this in some way with States rights. Clearly the constitutional responsibility which the Commonwealth possesses with respect to the ACT is a lot different to what it lacks in respect of the States. It is just not the same argument. This is not a State rights argument at all.

—I understand the argument put forward by the Minister and by Senator Hill that really we should give this a trial and that there should be some backstop, as it were, because of the possible inexperience of some persons who may be elected to the Assembly. In fairness to them and to the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), I acknowledge that there is a need at least for the time being for clauses 33 and 34. However, I would prefer that decisions by the Executive Government-that is, the Governor-General-be referred and tabled in both Houses of the national Parliament. At the present time ordinances in the ACT are tabled here. We have the right to disallow those ordinances. It seems to me that, in this new Australian Capital Territory self-government legislation scheme this Parliament loses any right that it previously had and the Government assumes that right solely. Had I thought of this before I would have moved a further amendment which would have left clauses 33 and 34 intact but which would have required the Government to table its disallowance in both houses of Parliament. That instrument would then be the subject of disallowance by the Parliament itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem that is facing us here is the transition problem between where we are and where we want to go. The difficulty I have with the current situation as expressed by the Government is, as suggested by Senator Harradine, that the Parliament has been reduced in power. I could put it this way: currently an ordinance is drawn up at the behest of the Executive by those people involved in the administration of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). It could then be disallowed by this Parliament. Under the new arrangement we could have one item being raised by the ACT Assembly but disallowed by the Executive Government. Yet this item may have the full support of this Parliament. The Government has managed to remove this Parliament from effective control and substituted itself in its place. I know that Senator Reid, who is in the chamber at the moment, has moved many of these ordinances herself in regard to ACT matters.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that an ordinance is overwhelmingly supported by the Assembly. It may even be overwhelmingly supported by honourable senators in this chamber or in the other place, yet it may be disallowed by the Executive Government. I think that it is moving the Executive Government into a situation that it may be very uncomfortable with. It may sound like a good idea but, at the end of the day, the Executive Government may find itself bearing the weight of many decisions that it might not want to take. It might be in the interests not only of this Parliament but also of the Minister who will suddenly become responsible because the Minister, not this Parliament or the Assembly, will have sole power. I would not have thought that that was such a good move. Ultimately, the avenue is there for the Northern Territory as well. I recognise that. It has rarely been used although threatened on occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think it has ever been used.

—It may never have been used but I can remember it being effectively threatened in the last couple of years relating to matters in the legal area. It must have been a number of years ago because Senator Gareth Evans was the Attorney-General at the time; so it was in 1983 or 1984. It was to do with the exercise in the Northern Territory that I was being extensively lobbied on. I remember that Senator Evans made some very strong statements in this chamber in regard to that particular matter. Ultimately, it did not come to pass and the Northern Territory Government did not proceed down that avenue. Although I cannot be held to it, it may have had to do with trial in certain areas. The heart of the matter went to the preservation of the right to trial. The Government has moved into a very odd context. I am not disputing the fact that it needs a fall-back because no Governor is proposed in this context. That fall back is acceptable. Of course, the difficulty is that the Governor-General effectively means the Executive Government. I would have thought that it would have been possible to organise it in such a way as to allow the Executive Government to be removed from that type of pressure yet still provide the back stop that the Government felt was necessary under the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make one comment: the reality is that this is the same provision, the same power, that the Commonwealth reserved for itself in the Northern Territory. It has never been used in the Northern Territory. What is more, the Northern Territory, which is run by a government with philosophies not exactly akin to my philosophies, is not deluging us with requests for change. This is a non-issue; this current debate is a non-issue. If we are to have divisions on matters such as this we will be here for a very long time indeed this evening. I really would have thought that we had more important and substantive matters to discuss during the course of the evening.

—The Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) are not exactly in the same situation as far as their relationship with the Federal Parliament is concerned. I would like to remind the Senate of the debate that has just been pursued on the Australian Capital Territory (Protection of the National Interest) Bill 1988. It is a pity that Senator Harradine is not in the chamber because this would have allayed a few of his anxieties. It is stated in that Bill that Acts of Parliament and not ordinances should be the method of dealing with any matters that pertain to the ACT. However, the Governor-General would be allowed to make certain ordinances but they would then be laid before each House of Parliament within five sitting days. They would exist for only three months during which time the matter could be sorted out. This is the sort of compromise which would protect the National Parliament's interest but, at the same time, give the people of the ACT genuine self-government-not a Clayton's self-government where Acts could simply be dismissed by the Executive of the Federal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be voting to retain these clauses but if these clauses are retained I now foreshadow an amendment which will add some words to clause 33 (2) which would indicate that the Governor-General may, by instrument in writing, disallow an enactment within six months after it is made. The amendment will also state that that instrument would be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament. I foreshadow that so that honourable senators can think about it. I had not seen that particular provision and given it consideration but it seems to me that there is an argument for it which I will advance at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Jenkins's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 12, subclause 33 (2), line 4, after ``the Governor-General may'', insert ``by written instrument,''.
(2) Page 12, after subclause 33 (2), insert the following new subclause:
``(2a) A written instrument referred to in subsection (2) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.''.

These amendments would enable either House of Parliament in effect to reverse the decision of the Executive Government, which then would enable the enactment of the Australian Capital Territory legislature to remain intact. At present, as honourable senators know, the Federal Parliament has the power to disallow ordinances made by the Executive Government in respect of the ACT. Under the provisions of the Bill the Parliament is taken out of the legislation altogether, it has no role in respect of the laws governing the Australian Capital Territory other than those listed in schedule 4 of the Bill. It is interesting that the Parliament would still retain some power of veto in respect of the matters that are contained in schedule 4. I understand that the amendment has the support of all honourable senators, so I will conclude my remarks at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's amendment is a safeguard for a safeguard. Although some people might think it is taking the matter to extraordinary extremes, it is better to be more cautious than disappointed, and so we will support the amendment.
—I indicate that the Government will also support the amendment for the same reasons and with the same reservations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support Senator Harradine's amendment, on the basis that half a loaf is certainly better than no loaf at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27) Page 13, clause 39, leave out ``Chief Minister'' (wherever occurring), insert ``chief minister''.
This matter was also discussed earlier today.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (28) Page 13, subclauses 40 (1) and 40 (2), lines 25 to 29, leave out the subclauses, insert the following subclauses:
``(1) Until the Assembly otherwise provides:
(a) the chief minister shall appoint ministers for the Territory from among the members of the Assembly; and
(b) the number of ministers so appointed shall be three.''.

The Australian Democrats believe that it is inappropriate to remove from the Australian Capital Territory legislature the right to determine the number of Ministers appropriate for the Territory or the appropriate form of the executive. We believe that it is inappropriate for the view of the ACT legislature to require endorsement from an executive arm of government. In fact, this relates to the same principle that applied to the amendment on which I called the previous division.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment. I think one of the principal concerns of people in the Australian Capital Territory is that the costs of self-government should be contained. This is one of the measures that will give them that assurance. Accordingly, we consider that the clause as it stands is appropriate, and we will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Similarly, the Opposition stands by the position that we adopted earlier today. We believe that subclause (2) is a satisfactory mechanism for increasing the size of the Ministry, and therefore we believe that the Australian Democrats' amendment is unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (29) Page 15, clause 47, lines 6 to 28, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``47. The Assembly may decide to go to election by the direct process of a specific resolution to this effect.''.

The Australian Democrats believe that if it is appropriate that a decision to go to an early election should be made, that should be done in a straight forward way by a direct resolution of the Assembly. We do not believe that all of these mechanisms are required or that complicated games need to be played for that to happen. In other words, if the Assembly wants an election it should be allowed simply to vote to that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's view is that this amendment is incompatible with the fixed term approach that is being adopted with regard to the Assembly. I think the fixed term proposal has been accepted and supported. Accordingly, in the interests of brevity, all I will say is that, on the basis of that principle, the Government will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to Senator Jenkins earlier that we will not support the Australian Democrats' amendment in this instance. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, it took us a little time to come to grips with the fixed term proposal. But having decided that a fixed term is warranted, we believe that it should be workable. This provision is designed with that objective in mind and we therefore support it as it stands.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Page 15, subclause 48 (2), leave out the subclause.
Subclause (2) reads:
The Chief Minister may appoint such associate heads of administration as he or she considers necessary.
Again, all the arguments have been put and we are applying the same principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —We consider that the amendment moved by the Government adequately covers this matter. The role of the Public Service and its relationship with the Minister has been adequately spelt out. The Government does not believe that the amendment is necessary or helpful, and therefore we will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's amendment, which we supported earlier today, includes the Opposition's provisions in relation to the structure of the head of administration and the associate heads of administration. We think that the Government's amendment, in the compromised form in which it was moved and passed by the Committee earlier today, adequately provides heads of administration in a way that is appropriate to the new self-governing body. Therefore, we believe that the provision in the Bill should stand.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be proceeding with the Australian Democrats' amendments Nos. 31 to 35 because, as I understand it, the issues covered by these amendments have already been dealt with in Government amendments which have been moved and passed. I must say that I believe that the Democrats' amendments would have been preferable, but we regard as quite acceptable the Government's amendments that have already been passed. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: (36) Page 18, after clause 58, insert the following new clause:
Commonwealth Grants

``58a. (1) It is the intention of the Parliament that the Commonwealth should make grants, by way of financial assistance, to the Territory, in respect of each financial year, of amounts related to the amount determined by the Commonwealth Grants Commission to be a fair and equitable contribution by the Commonwealth towards the general costs of the government of the Territory in respect of that financial year.

``(2) The Minister administering the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 shall, at such times as are agreed on by the Commonwealth and the Territory but not less frequently than once every 3 years, refer to the Commonwealth Grants Commission for inquiry and report the amount that it would be fair and equitable for the Commonwealth to grant to the Territory by way of general financial assistance in respect of a specified financial year, or 2 or more specified financial years, towards the general costs of the government of the Territory.
``(3) In making a report under subsection (2), the Commonwealth Grants Commission shall have regard, in particular, to:
(a) the several sums payable by the Commonwealth to the States, the Northern Territory and local government;
(b) the likely effect on the Territory of inflation and of increases or decreases in the population of the Territory;
(c) differences between the demand for educational and other services in the Territory and the demand for like services in the States;
(d) the extent to which particular expenditure of a State or municipal nature is required in the Territory because of the status of Canberra as the national capital;
(e) the extent to which expenditure of a State or municipal nature in the Territory;
(i) services the region surrounding the Territory as well as the Territory itself; or
(ii) is otherwise incurred in the interests, or for the protection, of the region surrounding the Territory; and
(f) the extent to which the expenditure of the Territory continues to be affected by decisions taken by the Commonwealth before the commencement of this section.
``(4) References in subsection (3) to the expenditure of a State or municipal nature shall be read as references to expenditure of a capital or recurrent nature.

``(5) For the purpose of this section, expenditure of a State or municipal nature on works or services shall be taken to be required in the Territory because of the status of Canberra as the national capital:

(a) to the extent to which the works are for the purposes of, or for use by, or the services are provided to, the Parliament, Departments of the Commonwealth, authorities of the Commonwealth or diplomatic missions, embassies or residences; and

(b) to the extent to which, although paragraph (a) does not apply to the works or services, the works or services are provided at a higher level than the like works or services are provided in the States in order to enhance the status of Canberra as the national capital or to provide a model for the States.

``(6) There is payable to the Territory by the Commonwealth, in respect of each financial year, by way of general financial assistance, an amount determined by the Parliament, being an amount not less than the amount determined by the Grants Commission as the amount that it would be fair and equitable for the Commonwealth to grant to the Territory by way of general financial assistance in respect of that year.
``(7) Payments under subsection (6):
(a) shall be made out of moneys appropriated by the Parliament for the purpose; and
(b) shall be made at such times and in such amounts as the Treasurer determines.

``(8) The Treasurer may, out of moneys lawfully available for the purpose, make advances to the Territory in respect of grants that will become payable to the Territory in respect of a financial year under subsection (6).
``(9) Nothing in this section shall be taken to prevent the Commonwealth from making grants to the Territory, by way of financial assistance, for special purposes.''.

New clause 58a is an extensive addition. We believe that it is appropriate to include extra detail because a whole range of matters must, as a minimum, be taken into account by the Grants Commission. For instance, if decisions made by the Federal Government before self-government is achieved are to have ongoing consequences, we believe that they must be taken into account by the Grants Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think, on any ordinary reading, the amendment probably does not mean anything at all or have any effect. However, any effect that it might have would probably be detrimental. If the intention is to bind the Commonwealth to implement the findings of the Grants Commission, I think this is an entirely inappropriate way of handling government finances. This seems to be entirely unnecessary. Examinations that I have made indicate that there are no precedents for the Commonwealth's paying to smaller States or Territories a lesser amount than that assessed by the Grants Commission as being appropriate. Notwithstanding the views of my colleague next to me, Senator Walsh, there may even be a circumstance in which, in the transitional period, the ACT Government may require greater funding than that assessed by the Grants Commission, which, if this clause means anything at all, would probably be impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: The arrangement that the Government is proposing is consistent with the normal arrangements for smaller States and the Northern Territory. The proposed amendment does not apply to the States or the Northern Territory. If we are adhering to the principle that the ACT, after self-government, should be treated as far as possible in the same way as the States and Territories, this amendment defeats that purpose. For that reason we will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the financial relations between the Commonwealth and the new self-governing Territory was, I guess, along with the questions of the electoral system and the appropriate functions to be transferred, one of the three major questions of debate in the Territory over the last months, if not years. We have considered the drafting of clause 58 as it now stands:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth shall conduct its financial relations with the Territory so as to ensure that the Territory is treated on the same basis as the States and the Northern Territory, while having regard to the special circumstances arising from the existence of the national capital and the seat of government of the Commonwealth in the Territory.

We believe that that adequately expresses the proper financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the Territory. However, we are concerned by the Democrats' amendment, as I have discussed with Senator Jenkins, particularly its inflexibility. Sometimes that leads to unexpected consequences. As I said, we would prefer to retain some flexibility but within the structure that is set out in the Bill, which we think will adequately protect the interests of the Territory as well as the interests of the Commonwealth.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (37) Page 18, subclause 60 (1), lines 25 and 26, leave out ``, with the approval of the Treasurer,''.
(38) Page 18, after subclause 60 (1), insert the following new subclause:
``(1a) Such borrowing shall require such approvals by the Treasurer, or other constraints applied by or under Commonwealth law, as apply to borrowings by the States.
(39) Page 18, subclause 60 (3), line 27, leave out the subclause.

These amendments clarify that the Australian Capital Territory should be treated in the same way as the States as far as borrowing is concerned. The Australian Democrats believe that it should be the clearly expressed intention of this Parliament that, as the ACT moves towards self-government, it should in as many ways as possible be treated in exactly the same way as the States are.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an interesting contrast between the principles underlying this amendment and the previous one. Clause 60 in the Bill is entirely consistent with the relevant provisions in the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act and will operate in exactly the same way. Borrowings by the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) will be treated in a consistent way with Commonwealth approval of State borrowings on the same basis as for the Northern Territory at the moment. Because of the status of the ACT and the Northern Territory as Territories rather than States, different arrangements are required from those which apply between the Commonwealth and the States, which are embodied in the Loan Council arrangements. The arrangements specified here have worked for the Northern Territory. They have operated without any disadvantage to it, and there is no reason to believe they will not operate equally adequately for the ACT. We will, therefore, not be supporting the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have also noted the similarity between these provisions and those that exist for the Northern Territory. As has been stated by the `Minister for the moment', they do seem to have worked satisfactorily for the Northern Territory. I said in my speech during the second reading stage that what we were dealing with here was something that was somewhere between local government and State government, and therefore the provisions that might apply to a State were not necessarily totally appropriate to this particular body. Certainly for the time being we believe that clause 60, as it now stands, is appropriate to the circumstances of the self-governing Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (40) Page 19, subclause 64 (1), leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:

``(1) A law of the Territory legislature, vote, resolution or question (any of which is in this section referred to as a ``proposal''), or an amendment of a proposal, the object or effect of which is to dispose of or charge any public moneys of the Territory:
(a) may be proposed in the Territory legislature by any member; and
(b) shall not be passed by the Territory legislature unless there has been laid on the table of the Territory legislature a certificate:
(i) signed by the presiding officer or chief minister;
(ii) approved by a resolution of a committee established by the Territory legislature to consider the proposal, the amendment of the proposal or both; or
(iii) approved by a resolution of a standing committee of the Territory legislature established to consider and report to the Territory legislature on the financial management of the Territory; and

certifying that public moneys of the Territory can be provided for the purpose of the proposal, the amendment of the proposal or both, as the case may be, or can be made available in a manner specified in the certificate.''.

Amendment (40) relates to clause 64 (1), which we seek to delete and to be replaced by the new subclause. Again, it is the view and indeed the policy of the Australian Democrats that the executive arm of government should not be given powers which rightfully belong to the elected Assembly in a democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats' proposal is quite contrary to the operation of the Westminster system as it has developed in Australia, with the Executive's responsibility for initiating money Bills and the role of the legislature in effective scrutiny. It is different from any provision that operates in this Parliament, in any State Parliament or in the Parliament of the Northern Territory in relation to money Bills, in all of which instances the initiation of money Bills is restricted to the Executive. As a matter of effective and sensible Budget management for any government, this is a matter that needs to be retained in the hands of the Executive. As a supporter of democracy, I support enhanced powers for the legislature, but they cannot include, in my view, this sort of proposal to initiate expenditure. That would otherwise negate the Executive's responsibility for preparing and proposing the Budget, which is a fundamental requirement of the concept of responsible government not only in Australia but certainly in terms of Australian precedents everywhere-the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. It is not appropriate that we should start changing this in the way that is proposed. I think it is neither sensible in practice nor appropriate in principle. We will be opposing the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess we also adopt the traditional approach-what I might call the conservative approach-in this area. We recognise that it is not only practice but also law elsewhere. We believe it is appropriate in the circumstances of the new self-governing Assembly that money Bills be introduced by a Minister and not simply by a member of the Assembly. We therefore oppose the Democrats' amendment, as I expressed to Senator Jenkins earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not at this stage seek to move amendment (41), but in lieu of that I would ask for an assurance from the Government that a participant in a government superannuation scheme, while a member of the Assembly, will not be regarded as the receiver of an allowance.

—It appears that there are circumstances in which a problem could occur in regard to superannuation for a person who is on leave without pay. I cannot give Senator Jenkins the unqualified assurance that she seeks at this stage. The advice I have is that there is a possibility that complications could arise. That seems to me to be a fairly unlikely cause of major concern to any potential member of the Assembly, although I understand the point that Senator Jenkins is making in this regard. There is a potential, if very minor, problem. Probably it would not operate to exclude any person from membership of the Assembly. Therefore, as far as I can see there is probably not a problem for a person on leave without pay. It will not render him or her ineligible, although I do not have sufficient detailed advice to give Senator Jenkins the unqualified assurance she is seeking.
—I also seek an assurance that there are no impediments to a public servant's being able to be a member of the Assembly without having to resign.
—My advice is that public servants would not have to resign to nominate for the Assembly, but they would have to resign from the Public Service to take up their seat.

—I am a little concerned about the previous matter. When I read clause 69 I must say that I satisfied myself that somebody who was a superannuant would not be excluded. I am not too sure whether the Government is now trying to say that that could fall within the meaning of the word `allowance', or exactly what the explanation is. However, as Senator McMullan has indicated that there are circumstances which mean that he cannot give an unqualified assurance, and as this is an important provision, I think that we should ask what those circumstances are that cause him not to be able to give an unqualified assurance.

—On the same point, surely in the ACT there is likely to be a significant deal of interest in the Assembly from people who, more likely than people anywhere else in Australia, are likely to fall within these parameters. If it is not possible to get an assurance at this time maybe we could actually adjourn this matter to a later stage in order for it to be clarified.

—Now that advisers have stopped trying to give me complicated advice and started giving me simple advice I can say that the normal circumstance in which superannuation does not count as an allowance would also apply in the circumstances being discussed. It would not operate to render somebody ineligible. If the honourable senators' concern is the status of superannuation, there is no problem.
—Does the same principle apply to defence services allowances as well?
—Yes, the principle is exactly the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been expressed previously by both the Government and the Opposition that we should not seek to put forward legislation in this place which is different from legislation applying to the Northern Territory. I would like to suggest that, as the ACT is different in the respect that so many of its inhabitants are public servants, the Senate should in fact consider whether it is brave enough to start moving in another direction with this legislation. I believe that we should start moving to allow a person who is a public servant to take up a seat in the Assembly without having to resign.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to cite a case that happened in Western Australia at the last Federal election. A person who had a high position in the State police force stood as a Liberal Party candidate in that election. That person had to resign under the provision which is normally called a technical resignation. However, when that person did not gain a seat in the Federal Parliament and tried to be reinstated in the police force, this was refused. I think that, if we can in any way move in a direction in this chamber which would prevent that sort of thing occurring, we certainly should do that. We should not feel ourselves bound by what has happened in the past simply because it was then a good idea. I think we have to look realistically at the present. I would like to hear the comments of the Minister, Senator Richardson, or the comments of the junior Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —The aspirant Minister-and it is no secret.
—the aspirant Minister, Senator McMullan, on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This provision is the same as the Northern Territory provision. It is no different. I know that a great percentage of people in the ACT are public servants. However, quite clearly a high proportion of people in the Northern Territory are public servants as well. The Northern Territory has a much higher ratio of public servants than do the States. I do not really believe that it is inappropriate to put the ACT in the same position.

—As I understand the present situation in regard to the Commonwealth, if a public servant wants to stand for office he resigns at the time he nominates. He is entitled to go back to his position if he is not elected. This clause says that a person `is not qualified to take a seat'. I would interpret that as meaning that public servants, therefore, would not have to resign when they nominate but have to resign from the Public Service when they are elected. That is a very different situation from that which exists presently in relation to the Federal Parliament.
—It is an improvement.
—It is an improvement on what exists in relation to the Federal Parliament. That is my interpretation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid is correct in her interpretation. The reason we have gone further is in order to improve the position in an area in which there will be a great many public servants affected.

—I appreciate that answer but I wonder whether the Minister can give the reasons why we cannot go to the next step. I believe that in the ACT which has a very large number of public servants it would be perfectly permissible to try to draw on the expertise across the board such that it would not disturb their tenure or their ability to return to the Public Service after one or two terms in the Assembly. I imagine that the matter was discussed. Can the Minister give us a reason as to why in fact that would have been rejected. I acknowledge that it is different but I wonder why it has been rejected. I believe that it would have been a move forward. The public servants concerned would have been under no obligations. There is no leverage available to them. It seems to me to fit in much more with the circumstances in the ACT than it would anywhere else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the officer concerned was still working with Bill Harris in the ACT Administration there would be a pretty fair conflict of interest. I think that is a case of taking one step and not needing to go any further.
—Senator Jenkins, you have not moved amendment 41, have you? You have just been making inquiries about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —That amendment has not been moved. I needed reassurance from the Minister in regard to superannuation which was actually what this clause 66 referred to. I am satisified by the Minister's statement. The other matters were simply observations which I wished to raise and to have discussed at this time because I thought they were matters that needed to be addressed at some stage. So I do not move that amendment. I now seek leave to move amendments (42) and (43) together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (42) Page 20, subparagraph 66 (4) (a) (ii), lines 10 to 13, leave out the subparagraph.
(43) Page 20, after subclause 66 (4), insert the following new subclause:

``(4a) A person vacates office as a member if the person becomes entitled to any remuneration or allowance in respect of any office or appointment, being any office or appointment under a law of the Commonwealth (including this Act) or a law of a State or Territory (including an enactment).''.

The existing subclause 4 covers eligibility to take a seat in circumstances under which a seat already held must be surrendered, but we feel that these aspects should be recognised as distinct. We have moved these amendments to clarify the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much to say about these amendments. Proposed new subclause 4a which Senator Jenkins seeks to insert is already dealt with in the Bill. Therefore, there is no need for her amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated to Senator Jenkins, that was also our interpretation. Unless there is something that I have failed to appreciate, again, as I indicated to her earlier, I would not be prepared to accept the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not proceed with amendments (44) and (46). However, I move amendment (45):

SPEECH.PARA: (45) Page 22, paragraph 72 (4) (b), line 7, after ``the person is re-elected'', insert ``or is a candidate''.

We believe that it is appropriate that a person who is contesting re-election should not have to commence job hunting until the outcome of the election is known. If one stops to think about it, it is quite unrealistic that a person should be regarded as losing his term of office at an election when sometimes, with a prolonged and a very close count, he would still be carrying on electoral activities from his electoral office which still functions. I remind the Committee that very often in a half Senate election senators are elected some months before they take up their seat. Similarly, senators who know that they will not be re-elected actually sit in this chamber for some time after that. People in this situation have time to make arrangements for themselves. I ask the Government and the Opposition to consider very seriously this, my final amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is possible for the Commonwealth to bestow upon the members of a new ACT Assembly conditions which go further than we have here.
—It could.

—We could, I suppose, but I do not think that it is appropriate to do so. In the Senate and the House of Representatives we operate under a system whereby we are paid until polling day. If we are re-elected we get back payment for the interim period, which, if one is a New South Wales senator, is sometimes a very long time. As I recall it, it was about six weeks last time. Nonetheless, I do not see how we could justify going further than that. Clause 10 of the Bill takes us that far.

—I indicated to Senator Jenkins earlier that we would not be supporting this amendment. We think that polling day is the day on which it all happens, unfortunately for those who miss out. As the Minister said, the same provision applies in the House of Representatives. It seems to us that it is appropriate for this Legislative Assembly. As I have said, we do not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that this amendment will not be passed. Therefore, I place on record the suggestion that this matter be considered across the board at a later date. If a person is regarded as taking up his seat from the date of the declaration of a poll, it is not illogical as far as a new member is concerned because although his salary is backdated to the date of the poll I do not believe that he does any electoral work during those days or weeks, whatever the case may be. I ask that this be considered at a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 10, after clause 27, insert the following new clause:
``Avoidance of application of enactments to Parliament
``27a. (1) In this section:
`enactment' includes a part of an enactment;
`Parliamentary precincts' means the precincts defined by subsection 3 (1) of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988.
``(2) If either House of the Parliament passes a resolution declaring that an enactment made after the commencing day does not apply:
(a) to that House;
(b) to the members of that House; or
(c) in the Parliamentary precincts,
the resolution has effect according to its tenor and the enactment does not apply accordingly.
``(3) A resolution under subsection (2):
(a) does not have effect in respect of the application of an enactment on a day before the day on which the resolution is passed; and
(b) has effect, to the extent that the enactment ceases to apply, as if the enactment were repealed by another enactment.''.
The purpose of this amendment is to insert new clause 27a, basically to ensure avoidance of the application to this Parliament of enactments of the new Legislative Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Hill can clear up the confusion in my mind. I thought that the amendment sought to insert new clause 32a, not 27a.

—The Minister might remember that earlier in the day the Australian Democrats said that they would prefer it to be numbered 27a. As they have been prepared to concede some of the language in the clause, we thought we should give them the number. That is the spirit in which tonight's debate should be completed. The subject matter is well known. There has been a concern within the Territory, within this Parliament and on the part of some officers of the Parliament that the Territory Assembly could inadvertently make law that could detrimentally affect the functioning of this Parliament. We are talking about domestic matters that might include the hours for which the shop can remain open here, questions of parking, and so on.
—They are of great moment!
—They may not be of great moment but, as I said earlier, we have a particular responsibility for the proper functioning of this place.
—What about the bar?

—I will not mention the bar because that would be flippant. This is a serious amendment. It has been the subject of considerable negotiation. Honourable senators would be amazed if they knew how much time had gone into these amendments. There have been arguments back and forth with the Attorney-General's Department as to appropriate language, and there has been some assistance from the Australian Democrats. But I believe that we finally have before the Committee a compromise form that will adequately achieve the objectives that we were seeking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit to which Senator Hill referred, the Government will accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wording of the amendment is fully in keeping with what the Australian Democrats wanted. I am delighted to see that it is now being moved as an insertion as proposed new clause 27a. I believe that it belongs in that place. We are very happy about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our amendments (2), (3), (6) and (7) dealt with the question of the transfer of courts and the transfer of law appropriate to those courts. Considerable negotiation has been taking place on this subject during the day. As honourable senators will recall, earlier in the day, the Government, when it was moving its amendments to clause 22 to deal with the courts, asked that they be deferred until a later hour in order for it to take instructions. As a result of all that I understand that the Government is going to move a series of amendments. If they are in the form in which I understand they are going to be moved we will be pleased to support them. On that basis it is not my intention to move amendments (2), (3), (6) and (7) as I had earlier foreshadowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the amendments that we have been negotiating for all these hours are typed up they will be in the form that Senator Hill wishes. I do not think he needs to proceed with his amendments.

—For the record, and so that we do not get any other changes in the course of the evening, the amendments that we are anticipating say that magistrates courts will pass by mid-1990, the Supreme Court will pass by mid-1992 and from 1990 Supreme Court judges may be appointed on the recommendation of the Australian Capital Territory Government. As I understand it, the appropriate laws which are currently in the Bill to be transferred will now be transferred according to that timetable.
—So you are not proceeding with those amendments?
—The Government will be moving them and I will be looking forward to supporting them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that final consideration be deferred until I have been provided with the amendments that are currently being typed.
—How long are we going to wait?
—I cannot put a time on it but I think they should be here very shortly. If he could give us another quarter of an hour until 10 o'clock I am pretty sure they will be here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 20, paragraph 66 (4) (a), line 16, leave out ``or'' (second occurring).
(5) Page 20, after paragraph 66 (4) (a), insert the following new paragraphs:
``(ab) the person is:
(i) an undischarged bankrupt;
(ii) taking, or has applied to take, the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors;
(iii) in the course of compounding with creditors; or
(iv) making an assignment of remuneration for the benefit of creditors;
``(ac) the person is of unsound mind; or''.

For some reason of which we are uncertain, the usual provisions that one finds in legislation of this type as to circumstances in which a person becomes disqualified to stand or serve in a legislature were not included. They have principally related to circumstances where a person is an undischarged bankrupt or is subject to some current scheme of arrangement or, alternatively, is of unsound mind. I could spend time going through the various provisions of all the States, those of the Commonwealth and those of the Northern Territory, which were imposed by this Parliament. Provisions of a similar nature to that which we propose now be included are to be found within such legislation. We presume that the omission here was not deliberate. We believe that it is important that a person who stands for this important office, or a person who serves in this important office, not be in the position of being an undischarged bankrupt. Obviously, he should be of sound mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to accept that part of Senator Hill's amendment which refers to unsound mind. At times I have doubted the soundness of mind of some people in some parliaments. On behalf of the Government, I wish to say that I cannot accept that part of Senator Hill's amendment which refers to bankruptcy. As recommended by the Senate committee which examined this matter some years ago, we ought not to be putting a stigma on those who are declared bankrupt. Many Australians who are put in that unfortunate position go on to lead lives that benefit the rest of the community. I cannot see-and frankly never could-why bankruptcy should in some way disqualify them from being in parliament, whether in the Australian Capital Territory Assembly or any other legislature. I know that that Senate committee recommended the deletion of two parts of the Constitution which refer to this. I really do not believe that we ought to be putting any stigma on bankrupts.

—We would be setting an undesirable precedent and I think it would be inappropriate for the Australian Capital Territory self-governing legislature not to be safeguarded in the same way as other legislatures in this country are from service by undischarged bankrupts. `Undischarged' is the important word. We have no concern about somebody who has unfortunately been through bankruptcy but has put his or her affairs in order and been discharged from that. Our amendment is referring to somebody who is currently bankrupt or, alternatively, has had to enter into some arrangement with respect to his or her debts or property. If we are talking about compounding debts, for instance, creditors being prepared to take lesser amounts, those arrangements can arguably put a person in a position where unsatisfactory influence can be brought to bear on them. We think that that is undesirable. We recognise that the Senate committee which was dealing with the Commonwealth Constitution in 1981 was of a different view. We notice, however, that the Government has not since sought to take that up in relation to the Commonwealth.
—We have had enough referendums for a while.
—They would be of unsound mind if they did.

—I am presuming that the Government made the decision on the merits of the matter. It has certainly been prepared to take other matters to the people. That was one matter that it chose not to. We do not believe that whilst a person is bankrupt he should be able to serve in the ACT self-governing legislature. We do not believe it is the correct precedent to set. We therefore intend to press our amendment in full.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —From my point of view, there is certainly a difficulty with the amendment in respect of bankruptcy. This difficulty was raised in a Senate committee inquiry. It was also raised in the first report of the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform. The fact is that members of the Federal Parliament also face this difficulty. We really cannot change this provision. While Senator Hill said that these matters have been dealt with on their merits, we all know that it is impossible to change the Constitution in these areas. Members of the Parliament suffer because of the possibility of their being sued, taken through every court in the land and losing their seat, not because they might not be guilty of anything but because they do not actually have the resources to be able to sustain that type of battle. They may not be guilty of anything, but they might be made bankrupt for that very reason. I probably speak with a little bit of emotion on this matter having been sued myself by a multi-national company which was going to try that exercise on me.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether Senator Richardson remembers the passionate plea I made as a Committee member in respect of the unsound mind question. I have a very great and genuine concern that we have in our society a changing view with regard to mental illness. Senator Hill has taken the sweeping phrase `unsound mind' from the Constitution; in fact, I think it is probably in every State Act. I believe that this is one occasion when it is time to take a step forward. Hundreds of thousands of people in our society suffer from schizophrenia. That is not a debilitating disease. This problem, which can be managed with medical attention, in no way prevents people holding down very senior positions within our society. I do not believe that it should prevent a person from serving within an elected assembly. There are many other mental disorders of the same kind. The sweeping phrase `of unsound mind' effectively covers all those people. We are now tending to distinguish more and more between people who fit into the various categories. Undoubtedly some conditions are so disabling that service in an assembly such as this is impossible. I think they are taken out by the ordinary course of events.

Many other types of mental illnesses which are nowhere near as disabling could technically, I am afraid, still be caught by that very sweeping phrase `of unsound mind'. I think we are moving forward. This is 1988. We are not back in 1901 when that blanket type of phrase was used. I hope that we will not continue to encompass people suffering from some type of mental disability within a phrase which I think is degrading and has been rejected by everybody who deals with people who suffer from some type of mental disability. It would be far better actually to take a step forward and say to the Government that any amendment should specify the disabilities that are of such a serious nature as to disqualify people from being members of the assembly. I really cannot support this exercise of continuing the attitude to mental disabilities that unfortunately was written into our Constitution in 1901. It is still there and is still used, but it creates a stigma in respect of the hundreds of thousands of Australians who hold down jobs of enormous responsibility although they suffer from some type of disability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point that has been made by Senator Hill about bankruptcy and the pressure that might be able to be applied by other persons against an undischarged bankrupt. At the rate things are going in this country, half the people of Australia will be disenfranchised in terms of standing for public office. The economic and taxation policies of this Government are pushing more and more people into debt. I am quite serious about that. I have just had figures taken out on middle income earners. A middle income earner on $28,600 a year with a dependent spouse and five dependent children has suffered a loss of 12 per cent in his disposable income since July 1984. That is not taking into account the enormous hike in interest rates for mortgages. So half the people will be disqualified under this particular proposal. I am opposed to it.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as `unsound mind' is concerned, I thought that that probably was a prerequisite for standing for parliament. But I think the electors can choose whether or not people are of unsound mind. If they want to vote such people into power, let them be voted into power. Who will determine `unsound mind'? Will the medical profession make such a determination? I know that these matters have been canvassed by a Senate select committee. I believe that Senator Macklin has made a valid point about the question of unsound mind.

I repeat that more and more people are being pushed into bankruptcy by the taxation policies of this Government. I am glad that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is in the chamber. The Government of which he is a member will be defeated at the next polls if it does not do something about recognising families. It allows farmers to write off, for taxation purposes, food for 200 cows. But it does not recognise children who are part of the most important business in this country-that is, raising a family. I wanted to make that point while the Minister is in the chamber because, if he does not take it on board, he will be on the Opposition bench after the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to answer Senator Macklin because whether or not one personally likes the expression `unsound mind', the value of it is that it is a term well known to the law. If one reads the law dictionaries, one finds a very precise definition of it. It has been interpreted by the courts many times over. On the definitions, as I read them, clearly a schizophrenic would not fall within that category. So I do not think that that concern is well founded. But that is the reason we used an expression that might seem to be dated, rather than attempting to invent a 1988 expression. If we did that, we would have uncertainty of interpretation. It is better to rely on the precedents that have been established over a long period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall, although I had almost forgotten, what Senator Macklin had to say as a member of the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform. That was so long ago that my unsound mind had faded on that question. Indeed, I also recall the passion with which he put it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not like the term `unsound mind' either. It is a most unfortunate term. Like Senator Hill, I do not know what other term could be used. It is the accepted legal term. I do not pretend to have the knowledge of a High Court judge or a Queen's Counsel, but I did not believe before this debate began that a person suffering from schizophrenia-which was the example Senator Macklin used-would come within the definition. That being the case, as I said, I am still of the view that the Government should accept the proposal in respect of unsound mind that Senator Hill has put up.

As far as Senator Harradine's comments on that aspect are concerned, while he says people will know and will vote accordingly, the reality is, if we in the Senate are being honest, that people do not always know. Not all of us are exactly household names. Not all of us are voted for because we are superb individuals, brilliant and erudite. Rather, we are voted for because we get a good number on a party ticket. I might say that it has been very helpful to me in the past, so I am not knocking it. I am just making what I think is a fairly obvious point. I do not believe people will always know, and for that reason I am minded to accept at least that part of Senator Hill's amendment which refers to unsound mind, again regretting the use of the term.

I do not think now is the time-and I am sure, Madam Chair, that you would prevent me from doing it anyway-to debate the Government's economic policies. I would have thought that what the Government did with family allowances during the last year was a great leap forward. Unfortunately, the take up rate on that has not been all that it ought to have been and we need to do more to make families aware of it. Certainly the Government's task has to be to look first at those at the bottom and move on up.

As far as bankruptcy is concerned, certainly there are examples in Australia where bankruptcy rates have risen dramatically-not so much because of this Government's policies, because the highest increases have been in Queensland. I would ascribe that increase to reasons other than the Government's policies. Some of my best friends are bankrupts, to use the well-known phrase. I know a lot of people who have gone bankrupt. That does not mean that they are in some way inferior citizens. I do not want to see that stigma placed on them to prevent them from entering parliament. I think we are past that in this day and age. We are not going to have a referendum on this question. I know it is not my place to announce Government policy, but I think I am pretty safe on that one. I doubt very much that the Government would be minded to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have put some pretty silly ones in the past.

—I am not even going to comment on that; I am not game. But we suspended one person from Caucus this week. I do believe that in this day and age the community perception of people who have suffered bankruptcy is very different from what it was 87 years ago, and I am not minded to accept that part of Senator Hill's amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out proposed new paragraph (ab).

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very serious in what I said about bankrupts. The rate of bankruptcy in this country is rising enormously. I was making a valid point. If we are talking about the qualifications of persons to stand for public office, it is a valid point to make. I am sorry that Senator Richardson has not understood what I said. His response indicates that he is ignorant of the vast number of people out there who are hurting, who are being pushed further and further into debt. He is ignorant of the fact that, because of the sum of money I mentioned-$28,600-the type of family I mentioned is not eligible for family allowance supplement (FAS).
—I made that point. I said we would start at the bottom. You did not listen.

—I listened all right. Those who have got FAS are behind what they would have got had family allowances been indexed. The Government has really done nothing for them. Those are the people that are going to react strongly at the next election. That particular family has suffered a reduction, in the last four years only, of 12 per cent in disposable income. That is why those people are being pushed into bankruptcy by the tax policy of this Federal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I am certainly not going to respond to all that Senator Harradine just said. He did not listen to what I said earlier when I remarked about the Government's policy of going to the bottom first. That is what we have done. If Senator Harradine waits just a few more months until the new year and sees what the Government does with tax policy for a start, some of his concerns may be addressed. I would hope that at a later point and an appropriate point I will have an opportunity to debate the matter properly with Senator Harradine, but now is not the time, so I am not going to.

Amendment (Senator Hill's), as amended, agreed to.

AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ELECTORAL BILL) 1988
Clause 1 (Short title).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to flag to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that there are two basic difficulties with the Bill. One is the political aspect, which we accept there will still be a disagreement about-that is, the imposition of the d'Hondt system. The other problem, about which I want to go into some detail as we go through the Bill, is the way in which the d'Hondt system has been drafted. I disagree with both of those matters, but I want to make it clear to the Minister at the outset that the first one we see as a political objection that we will lose on-not necessarily gracefully-because the numbers are against us. I appeal to the Minister to look carefully at the propositions with regard to the way this is drafted. I would take the Minister back to the long debate that we had on the Commonwealth electoral laws in 1983 when he and I sat on the same committee. The usefulness of that exercise was to make sure that we had a rigorous, tight, predictable electoral system. While there may be disagreements about what the system should be, I do not think there should be any disagreements about those particular principles. I believe that, if in the committee stage we could proceed on that basis rather than on the basis of trying to disrupt the system, we would have a better committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this is an excessively flawed Bill for a whole range of reasons that I will go into as we go through it. I do not believe that we should ever enact legislation as poorly drafted as this and so poorly put together. In fact, it has the potential for the most extraordinary problems to arise. In that regard I refer the Minister to Hansard of 2 December 1983 when I moved, amongst a whole host of other amendments, an amendment to insert a clause that I think at the end of the day should be inserted somewhere in this Bill to save it. That clause had to be inserted following an exhaustive committee inquiry, a long debate in the House of Representatives-which is somewhat unusual for that place-in which quite a number of amendments were moved and then a number of amendments were moved in this chamber. In fact, it was my twenty-ninth amendment, and at that stage all of them had been successful. The amendment read as follows:

Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, where, on the completion of a transfer of votes under this section, the number of continuing candidates is equal to the number of remaining unfilled vacancies, those candidates shall be elected.

The amendment was to remove a technical error that was in the Bill at that time-and acknowledged by the Government as such in the Hansard-which could have resulted in the election of more senators than were permitted to stand for each State. If that had occurred, the election would have been aborted and we would have been in a constitutional crisis because there would have been no government to change the legislation to rectify the error.

I am not talking here in these technicalities about things that may necessarily happen in this election, the next election, or the election after that; I am talking about the technicalities of the Bill. I believe that, if we are going to enact this legislation, it should be predictable; it should bring up a result that is predictable on every occasion, that is, it should elect 17 members-that is not the case here; on a whole host of possibilities it will not elect 17 members-and it should allow us to have a system in place that will not forever be going off to the courts. I ask that we proceed on that basis whereby issues can arise that are not of a political nature but are of a technical nature. I hope that we can have that technical debate in a reasonable manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, how do you propose to deal with the four options that you have put forward?

—None of my amendments has been moved as yet, so there is nothing before the Chair. It depends on the way that a range of other items are dealt with as to which of the options might be applied. There is no indication as yet from the Government or the Opposition as to their response to our proposal that might assist greatly, and I refer to the proposal for a subsequent referendum with regard to a range of options. If that option were carried, it would certainly allay our fears because we would be looking at an electoral system for one election only. TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, after clause 4, insert the following new clause:
Available preferences

``4a. For the purposes of sections 18 and 19a, where the next available preference indicated on a ballot-paper cannot be determined because the same number appears on more than one square on the ballot-paper:
(a) where only one of those squares is opposite the name of a party or an independent candidate, the next available preference shall be taken to be for that party or candidate;
(b) where 2 or more of those squares are opposite the names of parties or independent candidates, the ballot-paper shall not be taken to indicate a next available preference;
(c) where all those squares are opposite the names of candidates of a particular party, the next available preference shall be taken to be for that party; and

(d) where all those squares are opposite the names of candidates of parties and 2 or more of them are opposite the names of candidates of different parties, the ballot-paper shall not be taken to indicate a next available preference.''.

This proposed new clause deals with a circumstance where the next available preference cannot be determined because the numbers are duplicated on the ballot paper. A provision in similar terms occurs in clause 18 of the Bill and applies a number of general principles. I will not repeat them all now because that would delay the committee. However, as there is now also provision to transfer, under clause 19 (a), the preferences of provisionally unsuccessful candidates to the next preferred unexcluded party or Independent candidate, the possibility of duplicated numbers frustrating the transfer needs to be catered for. The Government believes that proposed new clause 4a succeeds in catering for that possibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the insertion of this new clause. I signal, as the Minister suggests, that it is probably not appropriate to discuss this issue now but, under clause 18, we have a particular difficulty in as much as the Government has not sought to insert a definition of `next available preference'. That becomes incredibly important because the next available preference under this system is quite different from the system under the principal Act which the Government attempts to rely on here, and that is the Senate system. The Government cannot use the same definition, but that is probably better dealt with under clause 18, where I might be able to give some pertinent examples.

But the Electoral Commissioner was not involved in giving policy advice on the Bill. As far as I am aware, that is what the Electoral Commissioner wanted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

The effect of this amendment is to provide that public funding will not apply for the first election. The Opposition has consistently maintained that position. But in this first instance where the Commonwealth is paying the money, we have to make decisions which we believe are responsible to our electors. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
