TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 6, paragraph 17 (d), lines 18 to 27, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(d) at a general election, an elector shall vote only by:
(i) expressing a first preference for one independent candidate;
(ii) expressing a first preference for one registered party; or
(iii) expressing a first preference for one candidate of one registered party;
and, if the elector wishes to do so, expressing subsequent preferences for candidates or parties for which the elector has not expressed a first preference.''.

This amendment makes it easier to understand how electors may vote. It specifies that electors can vote by expressing a first preference for one independent candidate, one registered party or one candidate of one registered party and express subsequent preferences for as many remaining candidates as the elector wishes. It is a system which is pretty well known to us. I do not propose to make a great speech about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be noted that the Government's amendment and, indeed, the original clause have an optional preferential system built into them. With all the rhetoric that has gone on in the past in this chamber with the particular method, I want it to be noted that the Liberal Party and the National Party propose to support an optional preferential method.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, want to rub that in a bit. I thought that this box system that we have for the Senate was brought about in order to minimise the number of informal votes. The Government and indeed the Australian Democrats did not go to the optional preferential system. There was a problem because New South Wales had more than 50 candidates in one Senate election. Obviously, this was rather difficult for the electors. It was half a day's job to fill out one's ballot paper. Instead of going for the optional preferential system of voting, the Government, along with the Democrats, decided on this most undemocratic way of voting-the box system on the top of each list of candidates on the ballot paper.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I raised this issue with the Australian Electoral Commission. I asked whether the first test of a fair system of voting is that it truly reflects the intention of the voter. Of course, the answer was yes. The next question was: did the box system truly reflect the intention of the voter? The answers are now out. As far as I know, they have not been published anywhere but they came out in the discussions the other day in the public hearings of the Electoral Matters Committee. Over two-thirds of the people who voted under the box system did not know to whom their second and subsequent preferences were going. The Government gave the excuse that this was the best way of going about it.

I think it is very noteworthy that the Government in this Bill has turned to the optional preferential system. If it can do it there, it can do it in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It would certainly be a much fairer way and more accurately reflect the intention of the voter than the party box system, which gives advantage to the parties and does not truly reflect the intention of the voter.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Pages 6, 7 and 8, clauses 18 and 19, line 28 (page 6) to line 24 (page 8), leave out the clauses, insert the following clauses:
Counting votes: exclusion from distribution of seats

``18. (1) The total number (called the `base number') of first preference votes received by each party and by each independent candidate shall be counted, and, for this purpose, where an elector has expressed a first preference for a candidate of a party, the party is treated as receiving one first preference vote.

``(2) The sum of the base numbers shall be divided by a number equal to the sum of 1 and the number of members to be elected to the Assembly and the result of that division (disregarding any remainder) shall be increased by 1.
``(3) All parties and independent candidates whose base numbers are less than the result of the calculation under subsection (2) shall be excluded from participation in the distribution of seats.

``(4) Where a ballot-paper indicates a first preference vote for an excluded party or independent candidate, the vote given by that ballot-paper shall be transferred to, and added to the base number of, the party, the party of the candidate, or the independent candidate, not excluded, for whom the ballot-paper indicates the next available preference (if any).
``(5) Where:
(a) a party is excluded;

(b) a ballot-paper that indicates a first preference vote for that party or a candidate of that party does not indicate a preference for another party, a candidate of another party, or an independent candidate; and

(c) that excluded party has a party voting ticket registered for the purposes of the election that indicates a next available preference for a party, a candidate of a party, or an independent candidate, not excluded;
The vote shall be transferred to, and added to the base number of, the party, the party of the candidate, or the independent candidate, with that preference.
Counting votes: provisional election of candidates
``19. (1) The provisional distribution of seats among parties and independent candidates shall be determined in accordance with section 19c.
``(2) If an independent candidate receives a seat under subsection (1), the candidate is provisionally elected.
``(3) If the number of seats received by a party under subsection (1) equals the number of candidates of the party, the candidate is, or candidates are, provisionally elected.

``(4) If the number of candidates of a party exceeds the number of seats received by the party under subsection (1), the candidate or candidates of the party is or are provisionally elected to those seats by distributing the votes among the candidates as provided by the Electoral Act.
Counting votes: transfer of preferences of provisionally unsuccessful candidates etc
``19a. (1) Where a ballot-paper indicates a first preference for:
(a) a party:
(i) that was not excluded under section 18; but
(ii) did not receive a seat under subsection 19 (1); or
(b) a candidate:
(i) of a party that was not excluded under section 18; and
(ii) who was not provisionally elected under subsection 19 (3) or (4);
that vote given by that ballot-paper shall be transferred to:
(c) where the ballot-paper indicates a next available preference for another party, or a candidate of another party, not excluded-that other party; or
(d) where the ballot-paper indicates a next available preference for an independent candidate not excluded-that candidate.
``(2) Where a ballot-paper indicates a first preference for an independent candidate who:
(a) was not excluded under section 18; but
(b) did not receive a seat under subsection 19 (1);
the vote given by that ballot-paper shall be transferred to:
(c) where the ballot-paper indicates the next available preference for a party, or a candidate of a party, not excluded-that party; or
(d) where the ballot-paper indicates the next available preference for another independent candidate not excluded-that candidate.
``(3) Where a ballot-paper indicates:
(a) a first preference for a candidate:
(i) of a party that was not excluded under section 18; and
(ii) who was not provisionally elected under subsection 19 (3) or (4); and
(b) a next available preference for another candidate of that party,
that next available preference shall be taken to be the first preference.
``(4) For the purposes of subsections (1), (2) and (3):

(a) where a ballot-paper indicates a vote that has been transferred under subsection 18 (4) or (5) because of a next available preference for a party, a candidate of a party or an independent candidate, the ballot-paper shall be taken to indicate the first preference for that party, candidate of that party, or independent candidate, as the case may be; and
(b) where subsection 18 (5) applies to a ballot-paper, preferences indicated by the party voting ticket shall be taken to be indicated by the ballot-paper.
``(5) The base number within the meaning of subsection 18 (1) as increased under subsections 18 (4) and (5) of each party and independent candidate shall be adjusted by:
(a) adding to the base number the votes transferred to the party or independent candidate under subsections (1) and (2); and

(b) deducting from the base number the votes for that party or independent candidate that were transferred under subsection (1) or (2) to another party or an independent candidate or to a party or another independent candidate, as the case may be.
Counting votes: election of candidates
``19b. (1) The distribution of seats among parties and independent candidates shall be determined in accordance with section 19c.
``(2) If an independent candidate receives a seat under subsection (1), the candidate is elected.
``(3) If the number of seats received by a party under subsection (1) equals the number of candidates of the party, the candidate is, or candidates are, elected.

``(4) if the number of candidates of a party exceeds the number of seats received by the party under subsection (1), the candidate or candidates of the party is or are elected to those seats by distributing the votes among the candidates as provided by the Electoral Act.
Counting votes: distribution of seats among parties and independent candidates
``19c. (1) In this section:
`adjusted base number', in relation to a party or independent candidate, means:
(a) in the case of a determination for the purposes of subsection 19 (1)-the base number of the party or candidate as increased under subsection 18 (4) and (5); or
(b) in the case of a determination for the purposes of subsection 19b (1)-the base number of the party or candidate as increased under those subsections and adjusted under subsection 19a (5);
`base number' has the same meaning as in subsection 18 (1).
``(2) The adjusted base numbers of the parties and independent candidates not excluded under section 18 shall be divided by 1, then by 2, then by 3 and so on.

``(3) The numbers worked out by dividing all the adjusted base numbers by 1 are `quotients' on the first and highest `rank' and the numbers worked out by dividing all the adjusted base numbers by 2 (disregarding any remainders) are `quotients' on the second `rank' and so on.
``(4) If any 2 quotients on different ranks are equal, the quotient on the higher rank shall be taken to be the higher quotient.

``(5) If 2 or more quotients on the same rank are equal, the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer shall, by ballot, decide the order in which they shall be treated for the purposes of subsection (6).

``(6) The party or independent candidate receiving the highest quotient receives the first seat, the party or independent candidate receiving the next highest quotient receives the next seat, and so on until all the seats to be filled have been distributed.
``(7) When the number of seats received by a party is equal to the number of candidates for that party, any further quotient received by that party shall be disregarded.
``(8) When an independent candidate receives a seat, any further quotient received by that candidate shall be disregarded.
``(9) An example of a distribution under this section is set out in Schedule 2.''.

These proposed new clauses reflect the Opposition's suggested amendment concerning the consolidated d'Hondt system. I shall briefly state the changes, and then no doubt a debate will ensue. The changes make the consolidated d'Hondt result provisional. They identify first preference votes for unsuccessful parties, party candidates or Independents, transfer these votes to the voter's next available preference and recalculate the electoral result, which is the final count. I will allow the debate to go on before I say any more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here dealing with the basic exercise in the Bill. Proposed new clause 18 (1) proposes a system of tallying up the party votes that go to individual candidates. This is certainly a novel system to be used on the Australian electoral scene. It does not have to be used. Alternative systems that are currently in place could be used. The only basic reason that has ever been provided to us is the argument about having a predictable House of Assembly with regard to the Executive.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment in Australia the Executive of the day does not control the parliaments of Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, Tasmania or New South Wales, or the Federal Parliament. The only Parliament where the Executive controls the House totally is in Queensland, where there is one House in a rorted system. It is interesting that the establishment in Australia is such that the Executive does not control any Parliament other than the Queensland Parliament. It seems to me that the notion that one has to have some type of system that will rort the votes so that there is a predictable majority result is in no way acceptable to anybody who is interested in democratic theory, let alone democratic practice.

Having fought for so long in Queensland against a rorted system that is still in place there because of the shameful exercise of the opposition parties in regard to the last referendum-at least the people in Queensland constituted the highest percentage of those who voted to get rid of that system-we now have in Queensland an exercise which flows directly from the electoral system. That illustrates the corruption that exists from top to bottom in that State. It is a direct result of the fact that people cannot, by expressing their views through the ballot box, change the political party in power. It is that important. It corrupts the judiciary, the police and every other level of public office. Anybody who knows the position in Queensland will know that each of those levels will finally be brought to account. That is why the electoral system is of such fundamental importance in any democratic society. That is why we should seek a system which will reflect the votes in the Australian Capital Territory rather than contrive a system that will entrench the political party in power.

I remember Senator Richardson saying on the first committee in which I took his wise advice, as a person more experienced in politics than I, that if we try to think up a system that will suit ourselves one year, we are sure to find that that system will destroy us the following year. Unfortunately, that wise advice has not been taken in regard to this Bill. Trying to think up a system that takes out the Independents in the Australian Capital Territory will only allow a voter apartheid, meaning that if one does not belong to a major political party one will not count. I intend to demonstrate that as we go through this amendment. Proposed new clause 18 (3) deals with an exclusion process. It reads:
All parties and independent candidates whose base numbers are less than the result of the calculation under subsection (2) shall be excluded from participation in the distribution of seats.

There will be a very odd operation in this respect. There is a real possibility of excluding at this level people who receive a higher percentage of votes than people who at a later point will win seats. This points to the arbitrariness of the exercise. It is interesting to look at some of the votes cast in the last election as they affect people in this chamber. For example, Senator Hill got 0.03 per cent of the vote in the Senate election in South Australia, Senator Richardson got 0.05 per cent of the vote in New South Wales, Senator Jenkins got 4.5 per cent of the vote in Western Australia, and I got 5.6 per cent of the vote in Queensland. It is interesting that we are told that people will have to be excluded because they are not representative. It is absolute nonsense. But the worst aspect of proposed new clause 18 (3) is that we will take out at this stage people who will have a higher percentage of votes than people who will win a seat at the end of the exercise.

I shall give an example. Party A, with 32 per cent of the vote, would get eight seats under the system suggested here. Party B, with 24 per cent of the vote, would get five seats. Any Independents with, say, 13 per cent, 12 per cent and 10 per cent-this was not unusual in the system that applied to previous Assembly elections-would get three seats. Party F, with 5 per cent of the vote, would get one seat and party G, with 4 per cent, would also get one seat.

Under the d'Hondt distribution, party F would take the fourteenth seat. The quotient for party A would be 4.56, after six seats, and the quotient for party B would be 4.5 after four seats. Let us suppose that, while F and G swap preferences, they mainly put party A before party B. In these circumstances, the combined vote for the three Independents would be the same as for party A. However, under this system party A gets nine seats, the Independents three seats and all the other votes are wasted. The same votes will end up giving one set of people nine seats and the other set of people three seats. I am not going to accept that, having fought against such a situation in Queensland all my life. I will not actually vote for a Bill that seeks to impose that on the national capital of this country.

What is going on here in terms of this amendment is the essential fallacy of the problem of trying to introduce this preferential system into the d'Hondt system without rewriting it from top to bottom. If possible, I would like the Minister to give an explanation in relation to the following example pertaining to the ACT. I shall take the 1974 example quite purposefully, because, in fact, that was one of the low periods for the Labor Party, and I presume that the Labor Party will accept that there may be low periods again at some time in the future. In that election the Labor Party got 24 per cent of the vote and four seats, the Liberal Party of Australia got 34 per cent of the vote and seven seats, the Australia Party got two seats, and the Independents got five seats. This type of example is not fanciful. This example is very close to the sorts of voting figures that have occurred in the ACT. I remind the Minister that, in relation to the last Senate vote, of all the States and Territories, other than Tasmania, the ACT is the least likely to use the party system. In other words, people are committed to moving themselves around. Secondly, in the previous Assembly there have always been Independents and minority teams. Can the Minister say what provision has been made under proposed clause 18 (3) for the possibility that, after this exclusion has taken place, there might be fewer candidates available for election than the number of vacancies to be filled? How would that work? Can the Minister indicate where in the Bill there is a provision that prevents our ending up, by going through a series of exclusions, required by proposed clause 18 (3), with not having enough people to fill the 17 seats?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to what Senator Macklin has had to say. I should refer again to what I said at the end of the second reading debate-that is, that this system was not the first preference or the second preference of the Government. It came about after a long period of negotiation with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The reality is that in a chamber like this no-one has a majority to impose the system that he may seek. If one regards the granting of self-government to the ACT as important, one must negotiate a workable system. The system might not be exactly what the Government or the Opposition wants, but this process delivers a system that is workable in the first place and, most importantly, it makes sure that self-government is achieved and that we are not side-tracked or stopped. That is the point from which both the Opposition and the Government proceeded in these negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin gave a number of examples, and I will respond to just a few of them. One cannot equate the situation in relation to upper Houses around the country with the situation in relation to the ACT Legislative Assembly. The fact is that executive government has the confidence of the people's House in every State in the Commonwealth. I hope that situation will apply here in the ACT. Certainly, it would have to apply in the election of the Chief Minister, which would be done by the members of the Assembly in the same way as the House of Representatives and the Senate would elect their Speaker and President. The reality is that in every State of Australia the executive government is entitled to expect the confidence of the people's House, and that is what we are going to get here.

Senator Macklin gave the example of the 1974 ACT Assembly elections. I have the final polling booth count figures for that election. I will be happy to make those figures available to the honourable senator, but they do not correspond with the ones that he provided earlier. However, I do not think that that negates the honourable senator's argument; it just means that the figures given were not right.

Let me go through the honourable senator's arguments. I can see where some Independents get very significant support. It is also obvious that, had the system been applied in the election referred to, other candidates would not have been dragged in, and the votes, as the honourable senator put it, would have been wasted once they had been elected. Because of the system that applied, there was no point in running other candidates. The whole point of the proposed system is to ensure that this happens. Any Independent running in the election in the ACT who believes that he or she has significant support will certainly run another candidate.

However, let us say that, for whatever reason, they do not do that-perhaps a person may think that he is so talented, as so many people in the ACT think they are, that he will not find anyone good enough to run with him-and votes are wasted. It is still not the case that in some way we might finish up not being able to elect 17 members. The facts are that the casual vacancy provisions then come into play, and we can still fill the 17 seats.

I do not know how Senator Macklin could make the claims that he has made. I also do not understand how he can talk about fallacy. It seems to me that the whole speech that he just made was based on that fundamental fallacy of equating this situation with what applies to upper Houses, when the reality is that the executive government is entitled to the confidence of the people's House-and, in this case, it is a people's House that we are seeking to elect. I repeat: I do not regard this system as perfect. However, I do regard it as adequate and workable. It works all around the world, and there is no reason to suggest that it cannot work in the ACT.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer again to the figures that I gave for the 1974 election. I will be very interested if the Minister has different figures. The figures that I have indicate that the Australian Labor Party got 24.28 per cent of the vote and that the Liberals got 33.69 per cent. In fact, I do not have the figures for the Australia Party votes or the Independent votes. However, it was the two major party groups that I was relying upon, because candidates outside both of those groups received 42.11 per cent of the vote. I would be very surprised if the Minister had got some other figures. I would be interested to know where he got those from. The Minister did not in fact answer my question.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get to that, I can hardly see what the Minister is getting at when referring to the analogy that I was drawing with regard to the Executive Government. As well as the two States where provisions with regard to the upper House and the Budget are different from what they are here, this chamber is quite capable of destroying any government-and has done so in the past. I really do not see what the Minister's point is. My point was the relationship between the Parliament and the Executive.

I come to the analogy that I drew, which the Minister interestingly enough did not dissociate himself from; that is, that this is awfully close to the Queensland system, a one-chamber parliament which is rorted. The question that I asked the Minister at the end was: What provision has been made in the Bill for the possibility that fewer candidates are available for election, after the exclusion in 18 (3) takes place, than there are vacancies to be filled?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin has once again likened this system to the Queensland system. He referred to there being a rort in Queensland and a rort here. He reminded me of something that I said about five years ago-that one should not try to invent a system to suit oneself, because it might suit one this year but not next year. The facts are that the Government is not looking for a system to suit it this year, next year or any other year; it is looking for a workable system to develop self-government-and that, I believe, is something it has delivered. Senator Macklin well knows-in fact, better than I-that the rort in Queensland is the gerrymander. It is not the system of counting; it is the gerrymander. By introducing the system which I hope this chamber will pass tonight, I think we are making the system immune from gerrymander. It is going to be virtually impossible to fiddle with the system. If we are looking for certainty, for a system that has an inbuilt integrity because of that certainty, that is what this system will deliver. I thought that is what we ought to be all about.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Macklin's query on the figures, I am quite happy to have an attendant take this document to him so he can look at it. As I said, I do not use the discrepancy in the figures as any reason to interrupt the debate, because we could still have the debate on the principles of the figures he has given us. I think at the end of his speech-although I was distracted-he referred once again to the possibility of finishing up with not enough candidates to fill the 17 seats. I referred to a `casual vacancy' in what might be called a generic sense. What we are talking about here is that, if we did not have enough candidates elected, section 181 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, as modified in its application to the ACT, would provide for a supplementary election to be held. I believe, by the way, that the possibility of there not being enough candidates elected is something like that system I was shown today, with 20 candidates each with five per cent of the vote. The chances of this happening are billions to one and it is just not worth taking up the chamber's time discussing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the method that is proposed to be used in this system. Despite the fact that we would have 17 or more candidates standing, it is proposed that we take out more, rather than leave 17, and then have another election down the road to fix up that exercise. That is the most extraordinary proposal for any electoral system that I have ever come across.
—It is a billion to one chance of it ever happening.

—There is not necessarily a billion to one chance of it happening. With a slight modification of the figures taken in 1974, it in fact actually does arise. The reason I read out what happened in 1983 is that it struck a bell in my mind. I went back to that particular debate. This is remarkably similar to that exercise and it could be fixed up by saying that, if along the way the number of continuing candidates is equal to the number of remaining unfilled vacancies, those candidates should then automatically be declared elected, and that is the election. That is a very simple procedure to put in.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's suggested procedure is to continue to eliminate candidates until we get down to 15 or 16, to get those elected, and then to have another election to get the extra place. That is an incredible proposition for a system. There is a much simpler way of dealing with that item: if on the way we get down to 17 and we have 17 vacancies, then those 17 vacancies are filled. I cannot see why anyone would not have that catch-all phrase there, as we included in the Senate count for precisely the same reason-that we could have got down to the point on the elimination of having fewer candidates than there were places that needed to be filled; and hence we would find ourselves operating those other parts in the Electoral Act to which the Minister has drawn attention. Why not put the same provision in here? It seems to me extraordinary that we should go that particular way.

The problem with this area is that quota preferential elections avoid these problems in the normal course of events by giving precedence to the election of candidates who have enough votes to be certain of success, no matter what happens. This problem arises from trying to marry this preference system with the pure d'Hondt system in a way that is not used by any other country. Although there are plenty of modified d'Hondt systems operating this exercise is not tried, because exclusions up front seem to introduce greater vote wastage and, I would suggest, remove control over the orderly process by which the system is able to fill the vacancies which are available to it.

If the Government is intending to proceed on that line, I do not suppose there is much that can be done. But I would have thought that the simpler, more straightforward catch-all method would have been the one to use rather than having the possibility remaining of a number of stages in the election. It is quite possible, under some unforeseen circumstances such as a spray of votes, for a number of candidates not to be elected under one particular organisation. But then again, I think Senator Richardson would have scoffed at the idea, as I would have, of somebody in New South Wales being elected to the Senate with just a little over one per cent of the vote to start with. It is an occurrence which is highly unlikely under the Senate counting system, but it did occur. The problem is that these things can occur in the system, and they could have been eliminated by the legislation actually having the catch-all phrases to deal with those particular items that may occur.

I think what we have got overall on 18 (3) are some worrying items, because we could end up with not simply one or two elections but in fact a series of elections if at the end of the day we had some strong Independents running, which is not unusual in the circumstances that we are looking at. While the Northern Territory has not fostered independents, I would suggest-and I am sure Senator Ray knows the political situation there as well as I do, if not better-that many of those people who run under party tickets have in fact gained their positions virtually as Independents in those electorates despite being adopted by political parties. If the political parties had not adopted them, they would have run anyway and probably won. I think that the compact type of electorate that we have in the Australian Capital Territory could mean in fact that we run down that path. I am not saying that it will mean that, but I am saying that it could. I believe that we should always write our electoral laws to take care of all eventualities. That is what we have done at the Commonwealth level to date. I would have hoped that it would be a tradition that we would continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to answer every point Senator Macklin has just raised because I have already answered most of them before. Unfortunately Senator Macklin does not accept what I have had to say on all those points. I will take up a couple of the things he has just said. Firstly, up-front exclusions are hardly rare. If we look at a 5 per cent exclusion figure in West Germany or Sweden we see that democracy seems to work reasonably well. If we look at Israel, where that exclusion does not apply at all, we have the spectacle of Mr Shamir running around all the ultra religious parties for three weeks after the election and still being unable, on the basis of the last information I read, to come up with a majority. That is because people with very small votes very often get elected.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin referred to Senator Robert Wood's election in New South Wales on such a small vote. I have to say that it was not an election that I welcomed. It was not even an election that I would have thought likely. But having said that, it was always possible; it was always something that, in the preparation of any model that one wanted to do for an election one could see how it could occur. Therefore, naturally one would allow for that. What Senator Macklin really is suggesting here, the crux of the argument, that in some way we will not get 17 people elected in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT)-comparing it to the same likelihood of someone with Senator Wood's vote getting elected-really is ridiculous. There is no comparison whatsoever between those two circumstances. The odds are totally different.

I look at Senator Macklin's arguments. I would have thought that there is even less chance of only 10 people nominating in New South Wales for election to the Senate next time, thus leaving a couple of vacancies to fill, than there is of our having not enough people elected in the ACT in either its first or subsequent elections. The facts are that Senator Macklin is talking up a ridiculously improbable chance on the basis really that this whole system does not fit in with Australian Democrat self-interest. That really is the crux of this. That is what it is about. It is about whether the Australian Democrats get a system that suits them. Yet, Senator Macklin has been standing there accusing me of trying to devise a system that suits the Australian Labor Party. As I have said, the facts are that this is not the Labor Party's first choice. However, it is not a system that is rorted. It is a system that provides an adequate, workable compromise and delivers self-government to the ACT. That, I hope, is what everyone in the chamber is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister in regard to the point I made at the very beginning-he has not actually referred to this-how we can justify at the beginning knocking out people with less than 5 per cent of the vote when at the end of the count we will be letting in people with a far lower percentage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember Senator Macklin's performance on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. He showed considerable expertise, and considerable diligence in looking at all systems thoroughly. However, Senator Macklin is not applying the same diligence tonight. He is asking me to give an answer on a mathematical fallacy. There is no point in my doing so.
—Madam Chair, I seek some clarification. Has the Government moved a number of amendments or just the amendment to clause 18?
—I moved Government amendments in relation to clauses 18, 19, 19a, 19b and 19c. I moved the lot.

—I have some questions in regard to the Government amendment to clause 19. I refer in particular to clause 19a (1). Can the Minister give an example of a party which, having not been excluded under clause 18, does not receive a seat under clause 19a (1)? He was talking about mathematical impossibilities. I believe that that is a mathematical impossibility. Perhaps the Minister could give an example to show how that will work.
—Would you repeat that please?

—I am referring to clause 19a (1). The Minister just referred to mathematical impossibilities. I did not bother responding to that because I believe that we have an example of a mathematical impossibility here, the example of a party that was not excluded under clause 18 not receiving a seat under clause 19a (1). The reason for that I think is fairly obvious in terms of any quota, particularly in regard to anyone using the droop quota.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what the problem is. I think what Senator Macklin is saying is that if someone gets more than 5.5 per cent of the vote but fails to get enough votes to get elected, then we have a system that gives that person another chance. I do not see that there is anything wrong in what is being suggested. However, I do not quite follow what Senator Macklin is saying.

—As I have said, I believe that it is not possible not to be excluded under clause 18 and not to get a seat. Perhaps the Minister is referring to a person who does not get a seat under clause 19a (1). In terms of a party, as distinct from an Independent, that does not seem to me to be possible. If there are 17 people to be elected one could, in fact, have 16 people ahead of one. One could not, however, have 17 people ahead of one under that exercise. One would not have been excluded but would have come under the droop quotient. One would have survived the first exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Macklin understands. Earlier tonight we were arguing about several scenarios put forward by Senator Macklin which I described as billion to one chances and therefore not worth the Government, the Opposition, the Committee, or anyone else wasting too much time on. However, what we are talking about here with this scenario is a real possibility, although, I concede, not likely. It is definitely a mathematical possibility. It must, therefore, be allowed for in the Bill. I am not going to put a billion to one figure on it. It may be a hundred to one shot. It may even be a thousand to one shot. Nonetheless, at those odds it must be covered because that is the sort of thing that can come up.

—I was in fact asking how that situation could arise. I was not seeking to look at the situation of Independents, which is an even more intriguing exercise. I was quite happy to stay within the party structures-remembering that this system is biased in terms of groups rather than individuals. I am talking about a group which has got a droop quotient but has not got a seat. I am interested in the circumstance that we are trying to deal with in regard to this particular clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say anything more than I have just said three times. Obviously, there is a problem here. I cannot convince Senator Macklin, although I have just said it three times. I do not know any other way to put it. I will have to hope that the Opposition understands.
—No, we don't.
—It is supposed to tonight, for once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extraordinary that we are writing these things into the legislation when we cannot be given an example of how they might operate. I go now to proposed new clause 19a (1) (d) and whether such votes would be of any use. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: the vote given by that ballot-paper shall be transferred to:
(d) where the ballot-paper indicates a next available preference for an independent candidate not excluded . . .

I presume that the Minister would be relying on proposed new clause 19a (1) (b) as to whether that person should still be included in the distribution process. I am interested in how an independent, with a droop quota under the exclusions in proposed new clause 18 (3), still has not managed to get a seat, but an example of that could not be given to us. In fact, that person will now receive further preferences which will be discounted later on. Perhaps the Minister can explain where those votes coming across will make a difference to that particular candidate. That may illuminate the point that I was trying to make earlier about 19a (1) (a).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how much success I am having as a communicator, but it seems to me that what we are talking about here is a preference going to someone who gets elected. That is what the system is here to deliver. That is precisely what it is there for. I cannot understand what it is that Senator Macklin has not seen.
—Perhaps I can pose a simple question that winds it back a bit. Let us take an independent who has the quota. Will he or she be elected?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Until the d'Hondt count was done we would not know. That is the simple answer to the simple question.
—Perhaps the Minister can tell me how the droop quota is to be calculated and how a person who has one can manage to get more preferences. What exercise is being operated here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The quota is not the determinant of the election: it is the exclusion point. That is where I think Senator Macklin is having difficulty. I think he is putting too much weight on the quota point. That is not where an election is decided.

—I know that an election is not decided there. It is decided in the exercise of the count. I did not ask that. I asked whether the Minister could explain to me how a person could not manage to get elected if he received the quota?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered that question four or five times now. I just do not see any advantage in my repeating what I have said on all the other occasions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not satisfied, but I would like it to be noted that somebody has now suggested that, in the way in which the system will operate mathematically, a person will be able to come up with a quota and still not get elected. I think that that exercise will have some very interesting ramifications down the line. No explanation has been given for that. I think that there will be a fascinating court case arising out of that exercise. But obviously that is something the Minister will have to pay for later on.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up a point that I signalled some time ago regarding the words `next available preference', which appear throughout the legislation, and what their definition might be. Can the Minister explain who will be eligible to receive the next available preference? Will it be the candidates not excluded under proposed new clause 18 (3), or are candidates not provisionally elected ineligible? I say by way of illustration that it is pretty clear from the Senate's scrutiny that, under the definition, only continuing candidates will be eligible in such circumstances. What is happening in terms of the definition of `next available preference'? Which of those two possibilities applies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of the term `next available preference' causes no difficulty in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The Australian Electoral Commissioner has no difficulty with it. I just do not understand any difficulty with it in this context. I fail to see how there can possibly be a problem with an accepted term, the meaning of which is obvious in its context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree totally with the Minister. The term `next available preference' is very clear in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. In fact, I said that there is no problem with it in the Senate's scrutiny. However, I think there is an ambiguity here. I was seeking some clarification as to which of the two possibilities might apply. Unless this is clearly defined, I am not sure that the Australian Electoral Commission will be able to carry out the instructions. Are we talking about provisionally elected candidates only? If so, what is the point of having provisionally elected candidates? Are they actually to be elected? As to the term `next available preference' as far as I can see, nothing has been suggested in the legislation that candidates who are not provisionally elected are to be treated in any specific way in that context.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I can spell out what I see as a problem. If the next available preference is to be available only to those who are provisionally elected, what is the relevance of that exercise? Will the candidates not excluded under proposed new clause 18 (3)-the ones the Minister has indicated that they will not necessarily be elected-be the recipients of the next available preference? Is that to be the total group?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —On this general question of the next available preference, all the legal advice that we have received from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel suggests that there is no difficulty with the translation of the term `next available preference' from the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I would have thought that was a much better assurance than mine, because all of those people who make a living out of knowing suggest that there is no problem. Obviously the provisional election concept takes into account amendments suggested by Senator Hill. While the Government, as I said earlier, may not regard that as perfect or ideal, it is nonetheless workable. However, the difficulty is that if Senator Macklin simply does not approve-and he obviously does not approve; I do not think he needs to ask us to note it as we got the message-he is continuing to ask the same questions about next available preference and provisional election. I am continuing to give the same answers. I do not really believe-and I have thought about it carefully in the last few minutes-that there is anything useful I can add beyond that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know that the next available preference is not actually delineated to those provisionally elected but is able to be distributed to all those not excluded. That presumably means to all those candidates of the party. For the life of me I do not see what the rationale could be for taking votes away from candidates where the voter most strongly supports moving them to where there are less. That is a matter of the philosophy of the actual operation itself. I move to proposed new clause 19c (4). It is part of the amendment that the Minister has moved.
—I moved amendments in relation to proposed new clauses 18, 19, 19a, 19b and 19c.

—I am looking at 19c (4) where we get quotients on different ranks. They are equal. The quotient on the higher rank should be taken to be the higher quotient. That could be important if we are dealing with the last place. If there were places prior to that the subsequent exercise might not make all that much difference. If we are dealing with an exercise here it seems to me that we would have several possibilities. On the higher rank one of the major parties may have had a number of seats previously gained and have left over a relatively small percentage of the vote, whereas a smaller group may have gained one seat and have a larger percentage left over.

SPEECH.PARA: I am wondering whether the Minister sees that as a possibility. If he does what is the rationale that the Government had in mind for breaking the particular problem we have here? I acknowledge that under the counting system there is a problem because we have to choose one or another. Why did the Government choose the higher rank? Is there any particular reason to choose the higher rank rather than the other, given the fact that the quotients are equal at that particular point?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the d'Hondt system the reason we choose the higher rank is that that is where the most number of votes are recorded in the first place. As I understand it, that is what it is supposed to be. I do not understand how the d'Hondt system is worked any other way. Part of what Senator Macklin was suggesting has nothing to do with this part of the count of the different ranks. If we do not have this method then the system is not workable. It is the only possible way it can work. We really do have a problem of communication.

—I acknowledge that there needs to be a system for breaking the exercise. This is fairly obvious when we actually get into a count context. The point I was trying to make relates to the philosophy behind it. Certainly, I accept that the higher rank obviously is, by definition, the one with the most votes. It may also be satisfied by more seats. I was thinking particularly of the last exercise, when we are looking for the last seat, and why would it go there rather than to the other group? Is that just simply the arbitrary way of doing it? The likelihood of it arising is anybody's guess but if it did arise it could well be the determining factor in the overall composition of the Assembly-taking that extra seat from one spot to another. Is there any particular reason for this, other than to reflect that it is moving where most of the other seats have moved rather than moving to where the other percentages may suggest in terms of votes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —From what I think Senator Macklin is saying, I think we are arguing about whether we would give an eighteenth seat to somebody. That is what he seems to be saying.
—I mean the last seat, the seventeenth seat.

—If there are two people tying at that point there has to be a way of giving it to someone. I do not know of any other mathematical way, other than this, to do it. We must have a method of resolution at the end point. If we did not have this method of resolution at the end point I wonder what one Senator Macklin is suggesting we would have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not suggesting any method. I was trying to elucidate the thought the Government had behind taking it in one way rather than the other. Obviously the thought is to move the seat to the number which had gained the highest number of seats, thereby enhancing the chance that there would be a majority. I presume that was the philosophy behind the exercise-in other words, giving the extra impetus that could possibly arise in the circumstances. In terms of the proposed subclauses 19c (7) and (8), the point I want to raise is not so much the one dealing with the numbers but I again express the Australian Democrats' concern, particularly with subclause (8), where there is an independent candidate. In looking at some of the past exercises around Australia I looked at the one that Senator Harradine was involved in during the Tasmanian election in 1980. He gained 21 per cent of the vote and did not have a running mate. Senator Harradine is an extant example so I cannot be accused of actually thinking up fanciful examples. It is quite possible that some such person might emerge.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking into account the number of votes that will be needed for the counting exercise, certainly the number will not be very much more than five, even acknowledging the point that somehow one could get the quota and still not get a seat. That will mean that something like 16 per cent of the votes `shall be disregarded'. It is an extraordinary system which would disregard 16 per cent of the vote. The party system will enable that exercise to continue because further candidates are available within the party structure. However, such an outcome will not result from the exercise that I have suggested involving Senator Harradine. I think it is a pity that we would alight on a system that has that possibility built within it.

The Australian Capital Territory has shown that it is likely to favour a number of independent candidates. I hoped that we may have actually come up with a system which would have been more sympathetic to that possibility, particularly in the case of a number of independent candidates who, for whatever reason, may wish to run on their own. The advice that the Minister would want to give to any person thinking of doing that is probably the advice Senator Harradine took of actually having another person running for election with him. I think it is a pity that we still come up with such a system-I do not know why Senator Harradine did not run with a candidate in 1980; it may be that he did not want to-under which a high profile person would be able to disadvantage people who vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, Senator Macklin himself gave the answer when he said that Senator Harradine ran with someone else the next time and the time thereafter. The system which we are advocating tonight in fact encourages independents to make sure that they run with a party partner. But if they do not-that is obviously a choice that they can make-then Senator Macklin is right; a large number of votes are wasted. But what is new or unusual about that? It happens every day in the House of Representatives. Every time there is an election votes can be wasted. There is nothing unusual or new about that, but there has to be a system that delivers a result. If an independent were to choose to run on his own, what Senator Macklin says is right. But this will not affect the end result. We have made sure that there is a system in place to take account of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The d'Hondt is a proportional system. When one reads about the d'Hondt system-I will quote from a history on electoral systems-one finds it is criticised because it favours the largest parties and `does not ensure that the seats which are allocated to parties are proportional to the votes which they have gained'. This is really what a lot of this argument has been about. There are figures everywhere that prove just that. A number of countries in Europe do have a d'Hondt system, but most of them have modified it in other ways from the way that the Government is seeking to modify it now. I will just quote briefly from an account of Norway:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party themselves had by 1927 . . . almost enjoyed the advantage which the D'Hondt system confers on large parties.
This is an accepted fact. I also find it surprising--

TALK.START.PARA: —Accepted by whom? Blimey, you will believe anything.
—Don't be intimidated, Senator; you carry on.

—I am not intimidated; I am just surprised at the level of interjection. I was about to say that I am surprised, nonetheless, that two major parties which are on record as supporting systems which are both proportional and preferential, should lean towards a proportional system when they have the chance actually to put a system of their choice into operation for a new assembly which, in reality, is not preferential. I did quote in debate yesterday the resolution of the Australian Labor Party which states quite categorically that the Labor Party's policy is in favour of a proportional and preferential system. Mr N. A. Brown, the shadow Attorney-General in the other place, is also on record during the ACT self-government debate as saying that the Liberal Party favours a proportional preferential system and that is why he is not in favour of the d'Hondt system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have amendments to clause 18, which I intend to move on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I am not sure how I stand as the Government has moved to deal with clause 18 and clause 19 at the same time. The Committee has to decide whether it will be in favour of a proportional system, which is also preferential, which will allow an Assembly to have reflected in its various composition the proportions of the votes received by various candidates. For the life of me, I really cannot understand why both major parties here seem to be afraid to have candidates who reflect a sizeable vote, albeit a minority vote, and an opinion which is not of the majority parties. I cannot for the life of me understand why the two major parties here seem to be afraid to have those candidates sit within the Assembly. Surely it would be much better to have opinions, which are held in the community, actually reflected in the Assembly. Those opinions can then be put in the Assembly. This is preferable to those views being covered up and having to rely on groups outside the Parliament to express them. I would not have thought that this Senate, which is elected by the Senate-style fully proportional preferential system, wants to deny that favour to the people of the ACT.
Amendment agreed to.

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. In an attempt to accommodate the wishes of the Government and the Opposition to exclude from the Assembly people who do not belong to major parties, the Australian Democrats will put forward our fifth option, which is for a Senate-style election with optional preferential voting both above and below the line. In fact, in the Government's own amendments, already passed, it has stated that it prefers an optional preferential form of voting. In this way people who wish to vote for only their own Party and for one or two other lists or candidates can do this. People who wish to vote right across the board can do this. Parties that wish to lodge a card with the Electoral Office with only part of the preferences filled in can do this. But the count would be a Senate-style count. SPEECH.PARA: (1) Pages 6 to 8, clause 18, line 28 (page 6) to line 14 (page 8) leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Counting votes: distribution of seats among parties and independent candidates

``18. (1) The total number (called the `base number') of votes received by each party and independent candidate shall be counted, and, for this purpose, where an elector has voted in relation to a registered party in a way or ways referred to in paragraph 17 (d) (ii), the party shall be treated as receiving a single vote.

``(2) The sum of the base numbers shall be divided by a number equal to the sum of 1 and the number of members to be elected and the result of that division (disregarding any remainder) shall be increased by 1, the number so ascertained being called the `quota'.
``(3) The quota shall be divided by 2 and the result of that division (disregarding any remainder) is called a `half-quota'.

``(4) Where the number of votes for a party or independent candidate is less than a half-quota, that party or candidate having the lowest number of votes shall be excluded and each ballot-paper that indicates a vote for that party or candidate shall be transferred to the party, the party of the candidate or the independent candidate not excluded for whom the elector indicated his or her next available preference (if any).

``(5) Where the next available preference indicated on a ballot-paper indicating a vote for an excluded party or independent candidate cannot be determined because the same number appears in more than one square on the ballot-paper:
(a) where only one of those squares is opposite the name of a party or an independent candidate, that number shall be taken to express the next available preference;
(b) where 2 or more of those squares are opposite the names of parties or independent candidates, the vote given by that ballot-paper shall not be transferred;
(c) where all those squares are opposite the names of candidates of a particular party, the next available preference shall be taken to be given to that party; and
(d) where all those squares are opposite the names of candidates of parties and 2 or more of them are opposite the names of candidates of different parties, the vote shall not be transferred.
`(6) Where:
(a) a party is excluded;
(b) a ballot-paper that indicates a vote for that party does not indicate a preference for a party, a candidate of another party, or an independent candidate; and

(c) that excluded party has a party voting ticket registered for the purposes of the election that indicates a next available preference for a party, a candidate of another party, or an independent candidate, not excluded;
the vote is transferred to the party, the party of the candidate, or the independent candidate, with that preference.
``(7) Where, under subsection (4) or (6), a vote is transferred to a party or independent candidate, that vote shall be added to the base number of that party or candidate.

``(8) Where, after the procedure set out in subsections (4), (5), (6) and (7) has been carried out in respect of an excluded party or candidate, the number of votes for another party or independent candidate is still less than a half-quota, that procedure shall be repeated until the number of votes for each party and independent candidate equals or exceeds a half-quota.

``(9) Seats shall then be distributed among the candidates for parties and the independent candidates not then excluded in like manner as they would be allocated if they were candidates for election as senators, the number of senators to be elected equalled the number of members to be elected and the votes had been cast at an election of senators.
``(10) The Regulations may make such modifications of the Electoral Act as are necessary or convenient to be made for giving effect to this section.''.
(2) Page 49, Schedule 2, leave out the Schedule.
Amendments negatived.
Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
