TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move an amendment to insert after clause 22 new clauses from 22a onwards, as have been circulated in the Australian Democrats' first option. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 9, after clause 22, insert the following new clauses:
Referendum concerning electoral systems

``22a (1) There shall be submitted, on or before the date on which the second ordinary election is held, to the electors qualified to vote for the election of members questions approved by the Assembly for the purpose of ascertaining the preferences of those electors in respect of the following electoral systems for the election of members, that is to say:
(a) the system provided for by this Act;
(b) any other electoral system agreed to by the Assembly;
(c) the election of members for electoral divisions based on discrete communities;
(d) an electoral system similar to that by which Senators are elected for the Territory;
(e) another electoral system (if any) preferred by the Labor Party;
(f) another electoral system (if any) preferred by the Liberal Party;
(g) any other electoral system (if any) which the Assembly is satisfied has substantial community support in the Territory.
(2) The vote shall be taken on the questions submitted to electors in pursuance of subsection (1) in such manner as the Assembly determines.
Legislature may alter electoral system
``22b (1) Subject to section 22c, the Assembly may make laws:
(a) altering the electoral system provided for by this Act; or
(b) substituting a different electoral system for the electoral system provided for by this Act.
(2) A law by the Assembly under subsection (1) may:
(a) make alterations to this Act;
(b) make provisions to operate in conjuction with the provisions of this Act, or of these provisions as altered by that law; or
(c) repeal this Act and make provisions to operate in substitution for the provisions of this Act.
(3) The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 applies to and in relation to a law made under subsection (1) as if it were an Act.
Procedure
``22c (1) A law proposed to be made under subsection 22b (1) shall not be introduced into the Assembly unless:
(a) the Assembly has resolved to consider altering the electoral system;
(b) notice of the resolution has been published in the Territory Gazette and in a newspaper circulating in the Territory;

(c) the notice so published invited persons to furnish to an address specified in the notice, before a reasonable date specified in the notice, suggestions or comments, or both, on the changes that might be made to the electoral system;
(d) a draft enactment has been prepared after consideration of suggestions and comments received in accordance with the notice;

(e) copies of the draft enactment and of particulars of suggestions and comments so received that have not been given effect to by the draft enactment, have been made available to the people of the Territory;
(f) there has been adequate time for consideration of the draft enactment by the people of the Territory and for the furnishing of comments and suggestions concerning it; and
(g) any comments and suggestions so received have been duly considered and any changes arising from them have been made to the draft before it is introduced into the Assembly.

``(2) Where a law proposed to be made under subsection 22b (1) has been duly introduced into the Assembly, and has been passed by the Assembly, a copy shall be laid before each House of the Parliament.

``(3) A House of the Parliament may, within 21 sitting days of that House after a copy of the law has been laid before the House, resolve that the House does not accept that law and, if a House so resolved, the law shall not come into effect.
``(4) Where:
(a) neither House of the Parliament has passed a resolution referred to in subsection (3);
(b) the respective times within which each House may pass such a resolution have expired; and
(c) the Governor-General is satisfied that there has been adequate consideration of the proposed changes to the electoral system by the people of the Territory;
the Governor-General may, on behalf of the Commonwealth approve the law by notice published in the Gazette.

``(5) Where a notice approving a law made under subsection 22b (1) is published in the Gazette, the law comes into force on the day on which the notice is so published or, if the law fixes or provides for fixing another date, being a date after the publication of that notice, on the date so fixed.
Legislative powers of electors
``22d (1) The electors in the Territory qualified to vote for the election of members shall, subject to section 22e, have power to make laws:
(a) altering the electoral system; or
(b) substituting a different electoral system for the electoral system for the time being applying in the Territory.
``(2) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), a law made under subsection (1) may:
(a) make alterations to an enactment;
(b) make provisions to operate in conjunction with the provisions of an enactment or of those provisions as altered by that law; or
(c) repeal an enactment and make provisions to operate in substitution for the provisions of that enactment.
``(3) For the purposes of subsection (2), this Act shall be deemed to be an enactment.
Mode of exercising legislative powers of electors
``22e. (1) The power of the electors referred to in section 22d to make laws shall be exercised in the manner provided by the succeeding subsections.

``(2) A proposed law shall be proposed by petition to the Assembly signed, within the period of 6 months immediately preceding the presentation of the petition, by electors qualified to vote for the election of members, to a number not less than 5 per centum of the total number of those electors.

``(3) The proposed law shall be submitted not less than 2, or more than 12, months after presentation of the petition, to the electors in the territory who are qualified to vote for the election of members.
``(4) Where a proposed law is so submitted to the electors, the vote shall be taken in such a manner as the Assembly prescribes.

``(5) If a majority of all the electors voting approve the proposed law, the chief Minister, or another person authorised by enactment for the purposes of section 24 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, shall notify the proposed law in the Territory Gazette and it then takes effect on the day of notification or, if the proposed law otherwise provides, as so provided.
Assembly not to repeal or amend laws

``22f. (1) The Assembly and the Governor-General do not have power to repeal or amend a law made by virtue of section 22d except in so far as that law otherwise provides or as is provided in this section.
``(2) A proposed law to repeal or amend a law made by the Assembly by virtue of section 22d must be passed by an absolute majority of the Assembly.

``(3) Where a proposed law to repeal or amend a law is made by the Assembly or by the Governor-General by virtue of section 22d, it shall be submitted to the electors who are qualified to vote for an election of members not less than 2, and not more than 12, months after it is so made.
``(4) When a proposed law is so submitted to the electors, the vote shall be taken in such manner as the Assembly prescribes.

``(5) If a majority of all the electors voting approve the proposed law, it shall come into operation on the date on which the result of the vote is declared or, if the law fixes, or provides for the fixing of, another date, being a date after that declaration is made, on the date so fixed.
Inconsistency of laws

``22g. If a law of the Territory made otherwise than by virtue of section 22d is inconsistent with a law made by virtue of that section, the latter shall prevail and the former shall, to the extent of the inconsistency, be invalid.
References to laws of the Territory
``22h. A reference in a law of the Commonwealth or in an enactment to a law of the Territory shall be construed as intending a reference to a law made by virtue of section 22d.''.

The reason for this amendment is that it looks as if the people of the Australian Capital Territory are going to have the d'Hondt system for their first election. What we suggest in the interests of democracy is that during the term of that first Assembly a referendum should be held concerning electoral systems. During this period the people of the ACT would have the opportunity to acquaint themselves with the d'Hondt system and the results of it. They have had other systems in the past. Their previous Assembly was a straight Senate-style system. Therefore, we suggest that the systems to go to a referendum of the people of the ACT should be the system provided by this Act; any other electoral system agreed to by the Assembly; the election of members of electoral divisions based on discrete communities, which was the Australian Democrats' preferred option circulated in my draft Bill last May; an electoral system similar to that by which senators are elected for the Territory; another electoral system, if any, preferred by the Labor Party; another electoral system, if any, preferred by the Liberal Party; and any other electoral system, if any, which the Assembly is satisfied has substantial community support in the Territory.

In this way, and if the votes were to be taken on preferential count, the people of the ACT would then have a say in their electoral system because, as was said earlier in the debate today and yesterday, in a sense we are in a catch-22 situation: we are saying that the people of the ACT should have their own Assembly but we must impose certain measures on them while we can give them a choice in certain others. This is one way that we could do that. I hope that, as the Government and the Opposition have their way with the d'Hondt system, they will support this referendum proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment of Senator Jenkins. Quite some time ago when the whole issue of an Australian Capital Territory government was first raised the contentious issue between the political parties was undoubtedly the electoral system that would have to be provided. The first time around it proved insurmountable, but that is not so on this occasion. However, it was interesting that on that first occasion the Minister said that unless the electoral system that was then proposed was adopted-and the reason no change could be made-it would delay self-government. That was over a couple of years ago. There are two ways of giving the people of the ACT a final say in the system of government which is to govern them: firstly, we can allow the Assembly to operate in such a way that it is able to change its electoral base-as, for example, any State government is permitted to do; or, secondly, we can simply say that at some time in the next three years the people of the ACT will have the opportunity to affirm the system that is installed-and they will have seen it operating-or some other system. I think that most of the systems that they will be asked to vote on will be those that they have seen in operation either in the ACT, such as proportional representation, or at the Federal level with the preferential system, single member electorates or whatever. In other words, the people of the ACT are given a final say as to the system that will govern them from thereon in.

SPEECH.PARA: The adoption of this proposal will in no way affect the operation or timing of self-government and it will not affect the first election-the system that has been agreed to by the Government and the Opposition. However, it would mean that it would go back to the people themselves to reaffirm that that is the system that they want, or they could say that they want some other system. I think that that basic right should be given to the people of the Territory. We have tried to set up a proposal that would allow each of the major contending systems to be introduced. For example, one choice might be what is called in the ACT the Mackerras system, but there are a number of proposals that float around. I believe that they can compete on their merits and that the people of the ACT would then have the final say as to the system that should govern them from then on.

The only other option if that is not acceptable is to give them a system that allows them to change their electoral system at will. The Government seems unwilling to go down that track, but surely it must be happy to accept the final verdict of the people with respect to the system that will govern the Territory rather than have the Federal Government impose it on them after the thing is up and running. We have always acknowledged the need to get the thing up and running. It has foundered on the electoral system, but that will no longer be the case. We make an appeal that the people of the ACT be allowed to contribute to the exercise. Indeed, our first submission to the Government a number of years ago when this was first raised was that the simplest, cleanest and most democratic way of dealing with this issue was to ask the people of the ACT what system they wanted and surely, once they had chosen their system, it could not be a matter of contention.

We have suggested these items here. Obviously a number of items will have to operate on a preferential system of voting. It will be the system most preferred by the people of the ACT which will become their system. I believe that that is a fair and reasonable approach and, if it is adopted, I think it would solve many of the problems that may arise over the next year or so when people still wish to contend around the electoral system. It may be a political argument, but I thought that it should be addressed, that there is a vast number of issues for the ACT which should be the subject of an election campaign rather than the issue of the electoral system itself.

Including the referendum proposal I think would defuse that political campaign and would remove it to a time on its own. It would be an item whereby the first territorial election, hopefully, would surround issues of concern to the Territory instead of having to linger on the contentious issue of whether or not the electoral system was the one that they wanted themselves.

Obviously we accept the determination that Parliament can make on this. It has made it. That will be the system that operates for the first election. I appeal to both the Government and the Opposition to allow the people of the Territory themselves to have a say in what happens after that.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Government and the Opposition do not see fit to support this proposal for a referendum, they show themselves, either separately or together, to be both grossly inconsistent and hypocritical because, on the one hand they say that they wish to give the people of the ACT self-government and, on the other hand, if they vote against this proposal they are saying that they are not prepared to allow the people of the ACT, having achieved self-government, to decide for themselves what form of election process they want. The Australian Democrats will call for a division on this, so I request the Government and the Opposition to consider very seriously supporting this very fair and democratic proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) presented to the Parliament today the most dishonest and deliberately misleading report from a government agency to come before this Parliament in my 13 years in this place. It is the glossiest and most costly of reports-and totally unnecessarily so-which seeks to hide the disastrous results of the Trust in the 12 months to June behind a facade of pretty pictures and irrelevant prose. It is only by a close, detailed examination of the accounts printed at the back of the annual report that the extent of the disastrous year for the Trust, and the retired public servants whose money it has, is revealed, because the printed report does not do so. On the contrary, it seeks dishonestly to hide it.

SPEECH.PARA: The report does not reveal that the Trust suffered an incredible turnaround in equity earnings of more than half a billion dollars in the year to June 1988-$530m to be precise-from the 1987 profit of $344m to a loss of $187m. The report does not admit that total income dropped from $918m to $730m and would have fallen by a further $154m but for an abnormal item, which was the gain on revaluation of property that emerged because the Trust sacked its cautious and conservative government valuers, the Australian Valuation Office, and got some independent commercial valuers to provide it with a hugely boosted valuation which saved the Trust from a fall of $340m in net income.
24-25 November 1988 SENATE
SENATE 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 SENATE

The annual report does not disclose that the compound rate of return for the Fund was more than cut in half to 13.4 per cent from 1987's 27.3 per cent, nor does it reveal or explain how management costs jumped by 60 per cent to $11.7m, or that the amount available for allocation to contributors was slashed by $288m, or by 35 per cent, to $514m, or that it had made a loss on equity investments offshore-as this government agency decided it would invest its money offshore-of $66.3m. On top of that, having lost that money, it has now decided to spend another $200m, saying:
. . . a strategy of increasing exposure to offshore equities markets was pursued and the Trust approved an allocation of $A200 million to a global-indexed pooled fund.

This report goes on and on, and is a disaster from beginning to end. The intriguing part is that none of the disasters are admitted in the written report which came to this Parliament, which is signed by Mr L. J. Willett and which was received by Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance. I want to know what the Minister for Finance has done about this deceptive and dishonest report. I am intrigued by the fact that the Minister for Finance has done nothing about the wasteful, incompetent and deceptive nature of this report. This report has used, in its printing, the most expensive and glossy typographical devices I have ever seen, as if they were photographic reproductions of the highest quality. The cost must have been enormous.

This whole report is, I believe, a total disgrace. I pointed out that, according to last year's report, the Trust's investments seemed heavily concentrated on what I think is now described as part of Western Australia Incorporated. I read in last year's report that it had 11.1 million shares in the Bell Group, two million shares in Bell Resources, with 5.9 million preference shares-and so it goes on. I raised a question on this with the Minister for Finance last year. I asked him what sorts of loses the Fund had suffered in the share market crash last year as a result of its extraordinary concentration of shares in the Bell Group. At that stage that was Mr Holmes a Court's Bell Group, before it was merged into other parts of WA Inc. The Minister for Finance on 18 December 1987 admitted that from that one single set of investments WA Inc. had lost approximately $86m. Of course, since then what has happened to WA Inc.?
24-25 November 1988 SENATE
SENATE 24-25 November 1988
24-25 November 1988 SENATE

TALK.START.PARA: —It has moved from black ink to red ink!
—That is exactly so.
—And very quickly too.

—Indeed so. All I have to say on this matter is that it is now incredible that this crooked report has excluded this year its list of investments so that one does not in fact have the opportunity to find out what its exposure to WA Inc. is this year. The report has gone from massive detail, boring perhaps as it may be to many people-but detail which revealed its curious investment policy last year-to the glossy document which does not provide the information but which in fact hides information that should, and must be, made available. To my mind it is absolutely disgraceful that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, having been criticised for some of its investments last year, has chosen not to print the sort of information it printed last year. More disgraceful than that is the fact that it has set out to mislead those people who benefit or otherwise from the activities of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. For example, the Chairman's report says about the Trust's results for the year:

SPEECH.PARA: In the volatile market conditions during 1987-88, SFIT achieved a return of 13.4 per cent, making it one of the top performing funds according to the published market surveys.
It does not reveal that that involves a cutting in half of its return for the previous year. The report goes on to talk about its investment performance. It states:
Despite the obvious negative impact of the sharemarket crash on equities, investment in other sectors enabled SFIT to achieve a commendable return for the year . . .
24-25 November 1988 SENATE
SENATE 24-25 November 1988

There is no admission that its return had fallen by so much-that the amount available to contributors had in fact fallen by $288m. As I said, one has to find the facts by looking at the detailed document of the audited accounts at the end of the report. There is nothing about this in the printed report which went to the Minister, and about which the Minister has made no complaint whatsoever. This report made to him is simply deceptive and misleading. I think it is a measure of this Minister's incompetence that, having been put on notice last year by my questions about the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, he has been prepared to accept the report, to table it without comment in this place and, by the way, ensure that it was right at the bottom of the list of reports tabled today so that there would be no opportunity to discuss it when it should properly have been discussed during the tabling of reports. I must say that I believe that this disgraceful performance both by the SFIT and by the Minister, whose indolence in regard to this matter this year equals his indolence in regard to it last year, should properly be brought to the attention not only of the Senate but of the Australian people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What programs are in place or planned with the express aim of:
(a) Controlling the proliferation of the following feral animals in Australia's national parks:
(i) goats
(ii) pigs
(iii) cats
(iv) rabbits
(v) donkeys
(vi) buffalo
(vii) camels
(viii) other; and
(b) Controlling the incidence of feral animals in other areas where they compete with livestock.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Commonwealth is responsible for management of only a limited number of national parks. Generally, responsibility for management of national parks in Australia lies primarily with the States and the Northern Territory.
Advice on the programs was sought from the relevant agencies whose advice is as follows:
Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service

The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) is responsible for managing Kakadu, Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga), Christmas Island and Norfolk Island National Parks. As part of the ANPWS wildlife management strategy, feral animal control programs are carried out in all parks.
(i) Goats-There are no feral goats in national parks managed by the ANPWS.

(ii) Pigs-In Kakadu National Park there are substantial feral pig populations in some areas and opportunistic shooting is carried out by park staff. A commercial live capture program is also being trialled.

(iii) Cats-Feral cats occur in all the national parks managed by the ANWPS. Opportunistic shooting is undertaken in Kakadu and Christmas Island National Parks, while feral cat numbers are controlled by trapping in Norfolk Island National Park.
(iv) Rabbits-An extensive rabbit control program is carried out at Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park and involves poisoning, gassing and destruction of burrows.
In 1986, after a seven year program, rabbits were eradicated from Philip Island, a 190 hectare island near Norfolk Island.
(v) Donkeys-A small population of feral donkeys, found in Kakadu National Park, was recently shot.

(vi) Buffalo-A major buffalo control program has been operating in Kakadu National Park for the past eight years. Since 1980 in excess of 29,000 buffalo have been removed from the Park by commercial shooters, using live capture and shooting, and by park staff by shooting.
Control of buffalo will continue in accordance with the Kakadu National Park plan of management and the requirements of the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign.
(vii) Camels-Camels are found in Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park, however they are not considered a major problem at this time and no control program has been undertaken.

(viii) Other-In Norfolk Island National Park, introduced rats and the introduced crimson rosellas are a problem for native wildlife. Poisoned baits and traps are used to control rats while the crimson rosellas are removed by shooting.

In the Australian Capital Territory the ACT Parks and Conservation Service is responsible for the management of Namadgi National Park. The Service funds, plans and executes all feral animal control programs in accordance with the Namadgi National Park management plan. The objectives of this program are:
to achieve effective control over introduced species;
to reduce the impact of introduced species already within the Park;
to restrict any further introductions of species into the Park; and
to minimise the susceptibility of park environments to invasion by introduced species.
(i) Goats-Feral goats are controlled by shooting. In 1987 nearly 100 feral goats were shot in Namadgi National Park.

(ii) Pigs-Feral pigs are controlled by using poison bait. Where poisoning is not appropriate traps are used. The poisoning program is believed to control up to 90% of feral pigs in a given area during the program.
(iii) Cats-Feral cats are shot by rangers.
(iv) Rabbits-An extensive program is being implemented to control rabbits. A variety of methods are being used including:
(v) (vi) and (vii) donkeys, buffalo, camels-There are no feral donkeys, buffalo or camels in Namadgi National Park.

(viii) Other feral animals include horses, cattle, foxes and wild dogs. Feral horses, cattle and foxes are shot by park staff. A system of tracking feral cattle by radio transmitters has been used successfully. Wild dogs are trapped within 1 km inside the park boundary following reports of lost or killed sheep or domestic livestock.
Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management

This Department has active programs of control of feral animals on national parks, nature reserves and state forests, although the degree of control that can be achieved is constrained by staff and financial resources. Examples of areas to which priority attention is directed are as follows:
eradication of feral animals (e.g. rats, goats) from island nature reserves where endangered native species are at risk;
measures to prevent introduction of feral animals to island nature reserves;
control of foxes in a number of parks and reserves where endangered native species are at risk from fox predation;

control of introduced herbivores causing environmental degradation-e.g. cattle and donkeys at Bungle Bungle National Park; feral goats at Kalbarri and Cape Range National Parks; rabbits in many parks and reserves;
pig control in Kalbarri National Park and the south-west of the State.
South Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service
(i) Goats-Regular Programs in Gammon Ranges National Park and Danggali Conservation Park. Programs time to time in Ngarkat Conservation Park and Para Wirra Recreation Park.
(ii) Pigs-Programs in Flinders Chase National Park (Kangaroo Island) and the reserves of the Murray River.
(iv) Rabbits-site specific programs e.g. Wilpena area of Flinders Ranges National Park and other specific areas but problem regarded as beyond control.
(vii) Camels-not considered a problem although frequent incidence in north-east desert parks.
The Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service undertakes control or eradication programs of feral animals on mainland and island national parks as opportunities present themselves.

The programs have been developed over many years, with considerable assistance from the Stock Routes and Rural Lands Protection Board in Queensland. The success rate has been greater with the island national parks due to both the size of the parks and the reduced risk of reinfestation by pest animals. Humane methods are used at all times.
The Conservation Commission is the authority responsible in the Northern Territory for co-ordination of feral animal control programs under the advice of the Feral Animals Committee.
Specific programs in place regarding feral animal control on national parks are as follows:
(i) Goats-No park control program. There are currently no feral goats in Northern Territory parks.
(ii) Pigs-Opportunistic shooting in areas of highest concentration. Research is planned to determine most appropriate methods to effect pig control over broad areas, particularly the wetlands.
(iii) Cats-Opportunistic shooting and trapping in areas of highest concentration.

(iv) Rabbits-Warren ripping and fumigation undertaken in worst affected areas. The Commission is supporting biological control work being undertaken by South Australia to find a suitable vector for control in arid areas.
(v) Donkeys-Extensive shooting program in the Victoria River District conducted by rangers supplemented with supply of ammunition to pastoralists. Escalated program proposed for 1988-89.
(vi) Buffalo-Eradication of feral buffalo from all parks and reserves currently under way under the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign (BTEC) due for completion December 1989.
(vii) Camels-No formal program. Camels at present are not a major feral problem on parks and reserves.

(viii) Horses-Shooting is undertaken in conjunction with the BTEC on parks and reserves in the Top End. In Central Australia, mustering and shooting is undertaken where populations are at high levels. A program aimed at removing feral horses from Central Australian reserves is being developed in conjunction with management programs on pastoral leases.

In summary, the Conservation Commission has programs in place to control populations of buffalo, donkeys and horses on parks; is conducting research to form the basis for control programs for rabbits and pigs; and currently has no formal programs for cats, camels or goats.
(i) Goats-Small herds of feral goats occur scattered around Tasmania. Unsuccessful attempts have been made to shoot out a herd in the Mount William National Park.
(ii) Pigs-Feral pigs only occur on Flinders Island where they are subject to periodic control using shooting and trapping in Strzelecki National Park.

(iii) Cats-Feral cats are ubiquitous in Tasmania, a substantial problem in many reserves and, given available techniques, beyond control in most national parks. Control programs are in place and proving effective in Macquarie Island Nature Reserve and several smaller island reserves.

(iv) Rabbits-Rabbits are widespread but only occur in problematic numbers in Asbestos Range National Park on mainland Tasmania. They are subject to limited shooting control in this area. Myxomatosis has been used to great effect to control rabbits on Macquarie Island.
(v) (vi) (vii)-Fortunately Tasmania does not suffer feral herds of donkeys, buffalo or camels.
New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service
Feral vertebrate pests and their control in national parks is a major issue for the Service.

Species of principal concern are rabbits, pigs, goats, cats, wild dogs and foxes; of lesser concern are hares, wild horses and rusa deer. Because of the natural distribution of these animals, each park has a different set of problems.
Where pests are present in environmentally sensitive park areas, control or eradication is given as high a priority as resources permit.
Where species are primarily agricultural pests and a park is acting as a reservoir for them, control is confined to the perimeter of the park and is, in general, considered on a case-by-case basis.
The Government is committed to effective control and management of pest species on Service lands in the most efficient, economic and environmentally sound manner.
The Government will also fund research into alternative methods of control of feral dogs and other pest animals which affect farmers whose properties border national parks.

The Service is reviewing its feral pest control program and will be appointing a wildlife management officer to develop policies, procedures and field management guidelines for pest species on a statewide basis.
Victorian Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands

In Victoria the most significant pest animals in national parks are the species that modify habitats; rabbits, pigs and goats. By far the most potentially damaging species is the rabbit. A statewide program and statewide plan exist to control rabbits on all land, the species being declared vermin. In parks, systematic monitoring and control is done. Generally 1080 is used as a knockdown control to be followed by a sequence of control methods, such as warren destruction and fumigation. Myxoma virus is released when environmental conditions are favourable. Co-operative agreements are sought with adjacent land holders to do collective and simultaneous work on infestations.

Pigs are present in about 6% of Victoria's national and state parks. Monitoring and trapping programs are applied where the need arises, supplemented by shooting. Remote sensing of pigs from aircraft is being trialled.

Goats have established in the semi-arid parks, in the north west of the State and in some mountainous parks. A system of radio telemetry (Judas goat tracking technique) with subsequent mustering is employed. Some success has been made with trap yards using water as a lure. Goats are also shot by park staff on an ad hoc basis.
Brumbies are a potential threat to some alpine parks. Small numbers are removed on an ad hoc basis by authorised brumby-running clubs. A control policy is being investigated.

The carnivorous pest animals are fox, dog and cat. Fox is thought to be the most significant in terms of impact on native wildlife. Control in parks concentrates on protecting specific native species during breeding. The control method used is the buried meat-bait technique using 1080 poison. Foxes are considered to be very well entrenched and eradication is not attempted. Protection of particular indigenous species and breeding sites is the major thrust of fox control. Cats are widespread, but in low numbers, although recognised as a problem, no control program is in place. Control is on an ad hoc basis with shooting and trapping being the methods.
In parks, dogs are a sporadic problem. The largest problem is domestic dogs in urban parks. Live-trapping is used as the major control measure.

Dogs are controlled on public land by doggers who can also operate in peripheral areas of the parks. Dogs are snared, poisoned, or shot. Dingoes are recognise as endemic in parks and control of them is focused on protection of farming enterprises. A protection policy limits control of dingoes in core areas of remote parks.

(b) Programs to control the numbers of feral animals where they compete with livestock are administered by the State Vertebrate Pest Control Authorities. They have the objective of minimisation of the agricultural and environmental impact of vertebrate pests and the economic loss associated with an exotic animal disease outbreak.

The Commonwealth contributes by co-ordinating programs and liaising with State authorities through the Vertebrate Pests Committee of the Standing Committee on Agriculture. The Bureau of Rural Resources in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy conducts a continual review of significant vertebrate pests in Australia, with particular emphasis on their management and control.

The Commonwealth is also co-ordinating the development and review of contingency plans to respond to exotic animal diseases in wildlife. They are based on exercises and projects jointly funded by the States and the Commonwealth Wild Animal Exotic Disease Preparedness Program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 11 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service liaised with the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service to establish the importance of the Mount Etna Caves in Central Queensland as habitat for the endangered species of bat known as the ghost bat, or Macroderma gigas; if so, what conclusions were made with respect to the Mount Etna Caves (and particularly the cave known as `Speaking Tube') as a habitat for the ghost bat.

(2) If no such project has been undertaken to date, will the Minister now request the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to liaise with the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service to determine the importance of the Mount Etna Caves (and in particular the cave known as `Speaking Tube') as a habitat for the endangered species of bat known as the ghost bat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) has been in contact with the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service (QNPWS) regarding ghost bats at Mount Etna. Over the period 1976-78 ANPWS funded a researcher at the Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education to undertake a detailed study of the Mt Etna ghost bats. The series of reports describing this research, and noting the importance of several caves at Mt Etna, including `Speaking Tube', to ghost bats, was completed shortly after the researcher joined the QNPWS in 1979.

In 1983, in reply to a request from ANPWS for advice on the conservation status of ghost bats in Queensland, the QNPWS indicated that the Mt Etna colony was one of the largest in Queensland and that it was threatened by limestone mining.

On 20 January 1988 the Queensland Government declared a scientific reserve protecting more than 80 per cent of the caves at Mt Etna. I visited the area on 6 February 1988 and on 20 April 1988 wrote to Mr Muntz, Queensland Minister for the Environment, Conservation and Tourism, expressing concern that two caves excluded from the scientific reserve, namely Speaking Tube and Elephant Hole, are important roost sites for the ghost bat.

The General Manager of Central Queensland Cement (CQC) wrote to me on 29 August 1988 seeking my assurance that the Government would not take action in relation to Mt Etna without first consulting the Company. This assurance was given without reservation and I was therefore shocked by the action of CQC in destroying Speaking Tube on 2 November 1988.

While there is little more the Commonwealth can do in relation to this matter I have indicated to the company my concerns for the remaining threatened caves of Mt Etna. I have also asked the recently formed Advisory Committee on Endangered Species to consider the status of the ghost bat at their inaugural meeting set down for 29-30 November 1988 with a view to recommending appropriate action to be pursued by the Endangered Species Unit being established within ANPWS.
